weakness.name: CWE-691
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-691: Insufficient Control Flow Management The code does not sufficiently manage its control flow during execution, creating conditions in which the control flow can be modified in unexpected ways.

weakness.name: CWE-707
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-707: Improper Neutralization The product does not ensure or incorrectly ensures that structured messages or data are well-formed and that certain security properties are met before being read from an upstream component or sent to a downstream component.

weakness.name: CWE-914
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-914: Improper Control of Dynamically-Identified Variables The product does not properly restrict reading from or writing to dynamically-identified variables. Many languages offer powerful features that allow the programmer to access arbitrary variables that are specified by an input string. While these features can offer significant flexibility and reduce development time, they can be extremely dangerous if attackers can modify unintended variables that have security implications.

countermeasure.name: Configure the virus scan interface properly using the virus scan adapter for SAP ABAP
countermeasure.desc:
SAP ABAP systems can be vulnerable to various security threats, including those arising from known software vulnerabilities. Performing regular security patches can help protect the system from these vulnerabilities by addressing known security flaws.

Remediation:
Regularly review and apply security patches for SAP ABAP systems to ensure that they are up-to-date and protected against known vulnerabilities. This can involve scheduling regular maintenance windows to allow for updates to be applied, and ensuring that the updates are thoroughly tested before being rolled out to production systems.

Use the Security Optimization Service (SOS) for a more thorough security analysis of your system, including missing security patches.
This service is available as a self-service within SAP Solution Manager, as a remote service, or as an on-site service.
SAP recommends that you use the service regularly (for example, once a year) and in particular after significant system changes or in preparation for a system audit.

Impact:

References:

  • Configuration of the Virus Scan Interface

countermeasure.name: Perform authorization checks on users for SAP ABAP
countermeasure.desc:
The Virus Scan Interface is a crucial component in safeguarding the SAP system from potential malware attacks. In SAP ABAP platform, it is recommended to use the Virus Scan Adapter rather than the Virus Scan Server for better performance and stability. Proper configuration of the Virus Scan Adapter is necessary to ensure that it is working as intended and is effectively protecting the system.

Remediation:
Review the current configuration and ensure that the adapter is being used in accordance with SAP guidelines and best practices. This may involve updating the configuration settings or implementing additional security measures as necessary.

To configure the VSI properly using the Virus Scan Adapter for SAP ABAP, you need to follow these steps:

1. Install and configure the Virus Scan Adapter: Install the Virus Scan Adapter for SAP ABAP and configure it according to the vendor's documentation.
2. Enable the VSI: Enable the VSI in the SAP ABAP system and configure it to use the Virus Scan Adapter.
3. Configure virus scan profiles: Configure virus scan profiles to specify which file types should be scanned and how they should be handled.

References:

  • Configuration of the Virus Scan Interface

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Attackers abusing privileges
threat.desc:
General threat description
This threat involves adversaries exploiting excessive or misconfigured privileges within the SAP ABAP environment. By taking advantage of these overly broad permissions, attackers can access sensitive data, alter business processes, or manipulate system configurations without proper authorization. This abuse of privileges often bypasses intended security controls, enabling attackers to perform actions that can compromise the integrity and confidentiality of critical business applications.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include disgruntled insiders, external attackers who gain initial access through compromised credentials, or opportunistic hackers who exploit misconfigurations in access control settings. Common attack vectors involve exploiting default or excessive role-based permissions, leveraging known vulnerabilities in the SAP authorization mechanisms, or using privilege escalation techniques to move from a low-level account to one with administrative rights.

Impacts
If attackers abuse privileges, they may access confidential business data, manipulate transactional records, or disrupt critical system operations. The resulting impacts can include data breaches, financial losses, disruption of business processes, and reputational damage. Additionally, the ability to modify system configurations or code could lead to persistent vulnerabilities and further exploitation.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An attacker with compromised credentials identifies misconfigured role-based access controls in the SAP ABAP system, escalates their privileges, and gains access to sensitive financial information, which is then exfiltrated.
  • A disgruntled insider leverages excessive access rights to modify critical business application configurations, resulting in service disruptions and data integrity issues.
  • An external hacker exploits a vulnerability in the authorization framework of SAP ABAP to escalate privileges from a standard user to an administrator, enabling unauthorized system changes and potential installation of malicious code.

threat.name: Attackers exploiting vulnerabilities to gain unauthorized access to data
threat.desc:
General threat description
This threat involves adversaries taking advantage of software vulnerabilities in the SAP ABAP environment to bypass security controls and gain unauthorized access to sensitive data. Vulnerabilities such as unpatched flaws, misconfigurations, or coding errors can be exploited to circumvent authentication or authorization mechanisms, allowing attackers to retrieve, modify, or exfiltrate confidential business information. This type of exploitation undermines the integrity of data security measures and can lead to significant breaches of sensitive information.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include external cybercriminals, state-sponsored hackers, and opportunistic attackers who employ automated vulnerability scanning tools to identify weaknesses in the SAP ABAP system. Attack vectors may involve exploiting SQL injection flaws, buffer overflows, or misconfigured access controls. In some cases, insider threats may also abuse their access privileges to deliberately expose vulnerabilities for unauthorized data access.

Impacts
Successful exploitation can lead to unauthorized disclosure of sensitive financial records, personal data, intellectual property, or operational information. This breach of data confidentiality can result in financial losses, regulatory fines, reputational damage, and disruption of critical business processes. Additionally, attackers may leverage accessed data to further compromise the network, escalating their attack to more critical systems.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An external attacker uses an automated scanner to identify an unpatched vulnerability in the SAP ABAP system. By exploiting this flaw, the attacker bypasses authentication controls and gains access to confidential customer data, which is subsequently exfiltrated for malicious purposes.
  • A cybercriminal exploits a coding error in a custom SAP ABAP module, allowing them to perform SQL injection attacks. This enables the attacker to extract sensitive business records from the database, leading to a significant data breach and subsequent regulatory investigation.
  • An insider with authorized access identifies misconfigured role-based permissions and leverages a known vulnerability to access data beyond their clearance. The insider then exports sensitive data for personal gain or to sell on the dark web.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Attackers reverse engineering executables to expose hidden functionality
threat.desc:
General threat description
This threat involves adversaries reverse engineering compiled SAP ABAP executables to uncover hidden or undocumented functionality. By decompiling or disassembling these binaries, attackers may reveal backdoors, debug interfaces, or other non-public features that were intended for internal testing or emergency access. The exposure of such functionality can provide attackers with new vectors to compromise the system or bypass security controls.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include skilled external attackers, state-sponsored groups, and even insiders with reverse engineering expertise. Attack vectors typically involve the use of reverse engineering tools such as IDA Pro, Ghidra, or similar disassemblers to analyze the executable code. Attackers may also leverage static and dynamic analysis techniques to study the behavior of the software and locate hidden functions that can be exploited.

Impacts
If attackers successfully expose hidden functionality, they could leverage these insights to bypass authentication, escalate privileges, or perform unauthorized actions within the SAP ABAP environment. The disclosure of proprietary or sensitive functionality may also lead to intellectual property theft and could facilitate further exploitation of systemic vulnerabilities, ultimately resulting in data breaches, operational disruptions, or loss of customer trust.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An external attacker downloads a public SAP ABAP executable, reverse engineers the binary, and discovers an undocumented debug mode that allows bypassing security checks, leading to unauthorized access to sensitive business data.
  • A state-sponsored group conducts a thorough analysis of SAP ABAP update packages and finds hidden administrative functions that were meant solely for testing. The group exploits these functions to gain elevated privileges and manipulate critical application workflows.

weakness.name: CWE-20
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-20: Improper Input Validation The product receives input or data, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input has the properties that are required to process the data safely and correctly.

weakness.name: CWE-250
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-250: Execution with Unnecessary Privileges The product performs an operation at a privilege level that is higher than the minimum level required, which creates new weaknesses or amplifies the consequences of other weaknesses.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-384
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-384: Session Fixation Authenticating a user, or otherwise establishing a new user session, without invalidating any existing session identifier gives an attacker the opportunity to steal authenticated sessions.

weakness.name: CWE-494
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-494: Download of Code Without Integrity Check The product downloads source code or an executable from a remote location and executes the code without sufficiently verifying the origin and integrity of the code. An attacker can execute malicious code by compromising the host server, performing DNS spoofing, or modifying the code in transit.

weakness.name: CWE-522
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-522: Insufficiently Protected Credentials The product transmits or stores authentication credentials, but it uses an insecure method that is susceptible to unauthorized interception and/or retrieval.

weakness.name: CWE-749
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-749: Exposed Dangerous Method or Function The product provides an Applications Programming Interface (API) or similar interface for interaction with external actors, but the interface includes a dangerous method or function that is not properly restricted.

weakness.name: CWE-764
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-764: Multiple Locks of a Critical Resource The product locks a critical resource more times than intended, leading to an unexpected state in the system. When a product is operating in a concurrent environment and repeatedly locks a critical resource, the consequences will vary based on the type of lock, the lock's implementation, and the resource being protected. In some situations such as with semaphores, the resources are pooled and extra locking calls will reduce the size of the total available pool, possibly leading to degraded performance or a denial of service. If this can be triggered by an attacker, it will be similar to an unrestricted lock (CWE-412). In the context of a binary lock, it is likely that any duplicate locking attempts will never succeed since the lock is already held and progress may not be possible.

countermeasure.name: Enforce strong authentication and authorization
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of the Android Device Client, it is imperative to implement secure authentication and authorization protocols. Begin by choosing established standards such as OAuth 2.0 and OpenID Connect to enable reliable and robust authentication mechanisms.

  1. Understand the Basic Concepts: Start by familiarizing yourself with the fundamental principles of OAuth 2.0 and OpenID Connect. These resources provide essential background knowledge and are crucial for correct implementation.
  2. Select a Suitable OAuth 2.0 Flow:
    • Determine the appropriate OAuth 2.0 flow for your use case. For mobile clients, the Authorization Code Flow with PKCE is recommended to enhance security without exposing client secrets.
  3. Implement OAuth 2.0:
    1. Register your Android device client with the OAuth 2.0 provider to obtain client credentials.
    2. Setup the authorization server endpoints for authorization and token issuing.
    3. Incorporate SDKs or libraries available for Android that encapsulate OAuth 2.0 protocol to streamline integration.
    4. Include the Proof Key for Code Exchange (PKCE) extension to prevent interception of authorization codes.
  4. Integrate OpenID Connect for User Information:
    • Extend OAuth 2.0 by integrating OpenID Connect to obtain user identity details, by configuring OpenID Connect-specific scopes.
    • Validate the ID token's authenticity using the keys from your OpenID provider.
  5. Enforce Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA): Where applicable, incorporate an additional layer of security by enabling multi-factor authentication. Consider using APIs offering SMS-based OTPs or integrating with third-party MFA providers.
  6. Secure Sensitive Operations:
    • Ensure that operations involving sensitive data or privileged actions prompt re-authentication, potentially requiring a step-up authentication to verify the user's identity robustly.
  7. Secure Data Transmission: Protect the communication between the Android client and authorization servers by utilizing TLS (Transport Layer Security) to prevent interception and eavesdropping attacks.
  8. Continuous Monitoring and Logging: Implement logging for authentication events and monitor for suspicious activities, such as repeated failed login attempts, using established mobile device management systems.
  9. Regular Security Audits: Conduct regular security audits and pentesting to validate the integrity of the implemented authentication and authorization mechanisms.

References

  • OAuth 2.0 Specifications
  • OpenID Connect
  • Google Identity Platform

countermeasure.name: Ensure secure dependencies management
countermeasure.desc:
Updating third-party libraries and monitoring for vulnerabilities are crucial steps to ensure the security of the Android Device Client. Follow these guidelines to implement this countermeasure effectively:

  1. Inventory and Audit Dependencies:
    • List all third-party libraries currently used in your Android project by examining your build configuration files such as build.gradle.
    • Remove any dependencies that are no longer needed or used, thus minimizing the attack surface.
  2. Integrate Dependency Scanning Tool:
    • Choose and integrate a suitable dependency scanning tool like OWASP Dependency-Check. This tool helps identify vulnerabilities by scanning the libraries used in your project.
    • Configure the tool to run automatically in your Continuous Integration (CI) pipeline to ensure ongoing monitoring.
  3. Periodically Review and Update Dependencies:
    • Set a schedule to review and update dependencies frequently, ideally each sprint cycle. Consider using tools like Dependabot to automatically check for new versions.
    • Verify that updates do not break existing functionality by running automated tests after updating libraries.
  4. Monitor Vulnerability Reports and Alerts:
    • Stay informed of vulnerabilities through known databases such as the National Vulnerability Database (NVD) and security advisories from library maintainers.
    • Respond to alerts by assessing the impact on your application and planning for necessary patching or updates.
  5. Document Changes and Decisions:
    • Maintain detailed records of changes made to dependencies and the reasons for updating or removing them, aiding in traceability.
    • Keep logs of security tools' findings and remediation steps taken.

References

  • OWASP Dependency-Check
  • Dependabot
  • National Vulnerability Database (NVD)

countermeasure.name: Implement anti-tampering and obfuscation techniques
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of the Android Device Client software component, it is essential to implement robust code obfuscation, integrity checks, and runtime protection mechanisms. The following steps detail how to effectively apply these techniques:

1. Code Obfuscation

Obfuscating your code can significantly complicate reverse engineering attempts.

  1. Integrate ProGuard or a similar tool into your build process:
    • Open your project's build.gradle file.
    • Ensure the following line is included within the android block: buildTypes { release { minifyEnabled true proguardFiles getDefaultProguardFile('proguard-android-optimize.txt'), 'proguard-rules.pro' } }.
  2. Customize the proguard-rules.pro file to avoid obfuscating critical components necessary for reflection, such as classes used by third-party libraries.
  3. Test the obfuscated build to ensure full functionality.

2. Integrity Checks

Implement integrity checks to detect unauthorized code modifications.

  1. Calculate a checksum or hash of critical files at build time.
  2. Embed the expected hash within the application code securely.
  3. Implement runtime verification logic to compare the current hash with the expected hash regularly.
  4. Trigger an alert or disable critical functionalities if tampering is detected.

3. Runtime Protection

Prevent dynamic analysis by implementing runtime protection mechanisms.

  1. Integrate anti-debugging techniques:
    • Regularly check for debugger presence using Debug.isDebuggerConnected().
    • Invoke process.exit(1) if a debugger is detected.
  2. Utilize root and emulator detection to prevent execution in compromised environments:
    • Check for the presence of su binary and common root management apps.
    • Detect emulator signatures by examining device characteristics such as build model and hardware information.
  3. Consider employing third-party libraries that offer robust runtime protection features like DexGuard, which extends ProGuard’s capabilities with runtime checks.

By following these steps, you can significantly enhance the security resilience of the Android Device Client against common tampering and reverse engineering threats.

References

  • Code Shrinking, Obfuscation, and Optimization with R8
  • DexGuard Features

countermeasure.name: Minimize and justify permissions
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing the Principle of Least Privilege in Android Applications

Ensuring that your Android Device Client follows the principle of least privilege is crucial for enhancing security. This involves requesting only the permissions necessary for the application's core functionality and using Android's permission request system to provide users with control and transparency regarding data access. Follow the steps below to implement this countermeasure effectively:

  1. Identify Required Permissions:
    • Review the Android Developer documentation to understand the various permissions available and their impacts.
    • Determine which permissions are essential for the application’s primary features, and list them accordingly.
    • Avoid adding permissions that are not directly required for immediate app functionalities.
  2. Configure Permissions in the Manifest:
    • Edit the AndroidManifest.xml file to declare only those permissions you have identified as necessary.
    • Example: 
      <manifest xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android"
    package="com.example.app">
    <uses-permission android:name="android.permission.INTERNET"/>
    <!-- Add only essential permissions -->
</manifest>
  3. Implement Runtime Permission Requests:
    • For permissions categorized as "dangerous" by Android, request them at runtime.
    • Use ContextCompat.checkSelfPermission() to check if the app currently has the required permission.
    • Use ActivityCompat.requestPermissions() to prompt the user for permission if necessary.
  4. Handle User Responses Appropriately:
    • Override onRequestPermissionsResult() to handle the user’s response to the permission request.
    • Provide a clear explanation (if needed) for why the permission is needed before requesting it again if the user initially denies it.
  5. Educate Users on Permissions:
    • Use in-app notifications or settings to inform users about why certain permissions are required.
    • Offer users options to modify permission settings at any time via the app’s settings interface.
  6. Regularly Review and Update Permissions:
    • Periodically revisit your app's permission requirements to ensure compliance with the latest Android security guidelines and remove any unnecessary permissions.
    • Stay updated on new Android OS versions and changes to permission protocols by following Android’s developer guides and security best practices.

References

  • Android Developer Guide: Permissions Overview
  • Request App Permissions - Android Developers
  • Best Practices for Permissions - Google Play Console Help

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties

countermeasure.name: Secure all network communications
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of the Android Device Client, it is essential to enforce TLS 1.2 or higher for all network communications and implement certificate pinning. This will help prevent Man-In-The-Middle (MITM) attacks and ensure secure endpoint authentication. Below are the steps for implementing these security measures:

  1. Update Network Security Configuration: Ensure that your application targets at least Android API level 21 or higher to support TLS 1.2 by default. Create or update the res/xml/network_security_config.xml file to specify the minimum TLS version. Here’s a simple example:

    <network-security-config>
    <domain-config>
        <domain includeSubdomains="true">yourdomain.com</domain>
        <trust-anchors>
            <certificates src="system"/>
        </trust-anchors>
    </domain-config>
    <base-config>
        <tls-version>TLSv1.2</tls-version>
    </base-config>
</network-security-config>

  2. Enable Strict TLS Connections: Within your application's logic, ensure that the HttpClients or similar network handling objects are configured to use TLS 1.2 or higher. This can be done as follows using OkHttp:

    OkHttpClient client = new OkHttpClient.Builder()
    .sslSocketFactory(getSSLSocketFactory(), getTrustManager())
    .build();

  3. Implement Certificate Pinning: Use certificate pinning to bind your app to specific server certificates. With OkHttp, you can achieve this by adding certificate pinning in the client configuration:

    CertificatePinner certificatePinner = new CertificatePinner.Builder()
    .add("yourdomain.com", "sha256/AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA=")
    .build();
OkHttpClient client = new OkHttpClient.Builder()
    .certificatePinner(certificatePinner)
    .build();

    Remember to obtain the correct SHA-256 hashes of the server's certificate public keys.

  4. Test Implementation: Conduct both positive and negative testing of your network communication to confirm TLS 1.2+ enforcement and successful certificate pinning. Ensure that connections to compromised or non-pinned certificates are appropriately rejected.

  5. Stay Updated: Regularly review and update pinned certificates ahead of expiry, and be aware of updates to TLS standards or Android platform changes affecting network security.

Implementing these steps will significantly bolster the security posture of the Android Device Client by ensuring encrypted communications and protecting against unauthorized network interception.

References

  • Android Developers - Security with HTTPS and SSL
  • Network Security Configuration
  • Android 9 Changes in Network Security

countermeasure.name: Secure session and token management
countermeasure.desc:
1. Secure Storage for Tokens:
    • Utilize Android's SharedPreferences with encryption or use the Android Keystore system for securely storing sensitive tokens. These methods help protect tokens from unauthorized access or tampering.
    • Consider using libraries like React Native Keychain or Android Keystore which are designed to securely store sensitive information.
  2. Enforce Short Token Lifetimes:
    • Implement logic on the server to ensure issued tokens have a short expiration time, balancing security and usability. A typical duration might be around 15-30 minutes, depending on the application needs.
    • Ensure your Android client checks token expiration regularly and initiates a refresh process before they expire.
  3. Implement Secure Logout Mechanisms:
    • Upon user logout, ensure that all tokens are securely erased from local storage. Use methods like SharedPreferences.Editor.clear() and calling commit() or apply() to delete stored data.
    • Invalidate the user's session on the server-side to prevent unauthorized use of any remaining session tokens.
  4. Secure Use of Refresh Tokens:
    • Securely store refresh tokens using methods similar to access tokens, ensuring they are not exposed inadvertently.
    • Implement refresh token rotation to enhance security. For every access token refresh, issue a new refresh token and invalidate the old one.
  5. Avoid Exposing Tokens in URLs:
    • Ensure that tokens are not included in URLs where they could be logged or gleaned from web server logs or user browser history. Use HTTP headers for token transmission.
    • Review and update client code to ensure URLs are free from token parameters, leveraging HTTPS for secure transport.

References

  • Android Keystore System
  • Shared Preferences Data Storage
  • Auth0 - Securing Tokens
  • OAuth 2.0 Security Best Current Practice

standard.ref: PR.AC-5: Network integrity is protected (e.g., network segregation, network segmentation)
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected

countermeasure.name: Secure storage of sensitive data
countermeasure.desc:
1. Integrate Android Keystore for Secure Storage:
    1. Begin by ensuring your development environment is set up with Android Studio and necessary SDKs.
    2. In your project, use the KeyStore API to generate and store cryptographic keys. Add the following sample code in your Android client application to initialize and load the Android Keystore:
      3. KeyStore keyStore = KeyStore.getInstance("AndroidKeyStore");
keyStore.load(null);
    3. Create a new key using KeyGenerator or KeyPairGenerator, specifying the desired type (e.g., AES, RSA). For instance:
      4. KeyGenerator keyGenerator = KeyGenerator.getInstance(KeyProperties.KEY_ALGORITHM_AES, "AndroidKeyStore");
keyGenerator.init(new KeyGenParameterSpec.Builder("KeyAlias",
        KeyProperties.PURPOSE_ENCRYPT | KeyProperties.PURPOSE_DECRYPT)
        .setBlockModes(KeyProperties.BLOCK_MODE_GCM)
        .setEncryptionPaddings(KeyProperties.ENCRYPTION_PADDING_NONE)
        .build());
SecretKey secretKey = keyGenerator.generateKey();
    4. Use the generated key to encrypt and decrypt sensitive data locally within your app.
  2. Restrict Access to Private App Storage:
    1. Store sensitive files in the getFilesDir() directory, which is designated for internal storage of app data. This storage is secured such that other apps cannot access it by default.
    2. When writing data, use context private mode to ensure restricted access: 
      FileOutputStream fos = openFileOutput("sensitive_data", Context.MODE_PRIVATE);
fos.write(data.toByteArray());
fos.close();
  3. Disable Backup for Sensitive Files:
    1. Prevent Android's automatic backup services from capturing sensitive data by excluding these files. Add the following to your AndroidManifest.xml within the <application> tag:
      2. android:allowBackup="false"
    2. If you wish to exclude only specific files while allowing others, utilize the res/xml/backup.xml file to specify these exclusions:
      3. <full-backup-content>
    <exclude domain="file" path="sensitive_data_path" />
</full-backup-content>

References

  • Android Keystore System
  • App-specific storage
  • Android Auto Backup for Apps

standard.ref: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

countermeasure.name: Secure WebView implementation
countermeasure.desc:
1. Identify Required WebView Instances: Begin by reviewing your Android application to identify all instances where WebView is used.

  2. Disable JavaScript by Default: In each WebView instance, ensure that JavaScript is disabled by default to prevent unnecessary script execution. This can be achieved by obtaining the settings of the WebView and setting the JavaScript setting to false:

    WebView myWebView = findViewById(R.id.webview);
WebSettings webSettings = myWebView.getSettings();
webSettings.setJavaScriptEnabled(false);

  3. Enable JavaScript Only When Necessary: If a specific WebView operation requires JavaScript, explicitly enable it in a controlled manner and disable it immediately after the operation completes. Clearly document this in the code to mitigate potential security risks.

  4. Restrict Content to Trusted Sources: Limit the URLs that your WebView can load. Implement a custom WebViewClient and override the shouldOverrideUrlLoading method. Utilize this method to filter and allow only trusted domains that you deem safe.

    myWebView.setWebViewClient(new WebViewClient() {
    @Override
    public boolean shouldOverrideUrlLoading(WebView view, String url) {
        return !url.startsWith("https://trusted.domain");
    }
});

  5. Disable File Access: Disable file access within WebView settings to prevent unauthorized file exposure or manipulation:

    webSettings.setAllowFileAccess(false);
webSettings.setAllowFileAccessFromFileURLs(false);
webSettings.setAllowUniversalAccessFromFileURLs(false);

  6. Testing: Implement comprehensive testing to ensure these security configurations are enforced across all possible scenarios in the application. This includes testing for loading content from untrusted sources, attempting unauthorized file access, and ensuring JavaScript is disabled when not needed.

References

  • Android WebView - JavaScript Settings
  • Android Developers - WebView Overview
  • Android WebViewClient Documentation

standard.ref: PR.DS-6: Integrity checking mechanisms are used to verify software, firmware, and information integrity
SI-6 Security and Privacy Function Verification
SI-7 Software, Firmware, and Information Integrity

customField.value: ATT&CK Mobile - M1013 - Application Developer Guidance
SI-7 Software, Firmware, and Information Integrity

countermeasure.name: Validate and sanitize all inputs
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of the Android Device Client, it is crucial to ensure that all inputs received by the application are properly validated and sanitized before being processed. This helps prevent common vulnerabilities like SQL injection, cross-site scripting, and other injection attacks. Follow these detailed steps to implement robust input validation and sanitation:

  1. Identify All Data Entry Points: Begin by reviewing the Android Device Client to identify all locations where data is input from external sources, such as user input fields, network requests, and data files.

  2. Implement Input Validation: For each data entry point, implement strict validation logic to ensure that the data matches expected formats and types. This can include:

    • Using regular expressions to validate email addresses, phone numbers, and other structured data.
    • Checking numerical ranges for integer or float inputs.
    • Enforcing minimum and maximum lengths for string data.

    Use Android’s InputFilter and TextUtils classes to assist with input validation at the component level.

  3. Sanitize Data: Once input passes validation, sanitize data to remove or escape potentially harmful characters. This includes:

    • Escaping special characters in strings that may affect SQL queries or HTML output.
    • Using libraries like org.apache.commons.text.StringEscapeUtils for escaping HTML and JavaScript.

  4. Use Parameterized Queries: For database interactions, ensure that all SQL queries use parameterized queries or prepared statements instead of directly concatenating strings to form queries. This prevents SQL injection attacks by treating input data as parameters, not executable code.

    
           // Example in Java
           String sql = "SELECT * FROM users WHERE username = ?";
           PreparedStatement pstmt = connection.prepareStatement(sql);
           pstmt.setString(1, username);
           ResultSet rs = pstmt.executeQuery();

  5. Avoid Dynamic Code Execution: Avoid executing code based on input from untrusted sources. This includes dynamically loading classes or methods using reflection or executing shell commands. If dynamic behavior is necessary, ensure that the input is strictly controlled and validated.

  6. Conduct Regular Security Audits: Periodically review and test the application’s input validation and sanitization logic to ensure robustness against evolving threat patterns. Use tools like OWASP ZAP or Burp Suite for penetration testing.

Implementing these steps will significantly enhance the security posture of your Android Device Client by mitigating risks associated with unvalidated and unsanitized inputs.

References

  • Android Security Tips
  • OWASP Input Validation Cheat Sheet
  • OWASP Top Ten
  • Java Prepared Statements

standard.ref: PR.DS-6: Integrity checking mechanisms are used to verify software, firmware, and information integrity

customField.value: ATT&CK Mobile - M1013 - Application Developer Guidance

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Excessive permissions and privacy risks
threat.desc:
General threat description
The application has the potential to over-request permissions beyond its functional needs, which can result in undue privacy risks for users and an expanded opportunity for attackers to exploit vulnerabilities.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious developers or attackers can exploit the permissions granted to the application to access sensitive user information or system functionalities that should remain restricted.
Impacts
This situation may lead to unauthorized access to personal data, such as contacts, location, and messages, causing privacy invasions or identity theft, and can also open pathways for further attacks on the device.
Example Attack Scenarios
An installed application requests access to a user's contact list under the pretense of enhancing user experience but instead uses that access to collect and sell contact information to third parties without user consent. Another scenario could involve an application that demands location data but uses it to track user movements for malicious intents.

customField.value: ATT&CK Mobile - T1401 - Device Administrator Permissions

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to user data
threat.desc:
General threat description
An attacker could exploit weaknesses in the application's access control systems or inefficient authentication processes to unlawfully access confidential user data.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Cybercriminals exploiting security loopholes or leveraging inadequate user verification protocols to penetrate the system.
Impacts
Unauthorized exposure and potential misuse of private user information, leading to privacy violations and potential legal repercussions.
Example Attack Scenarios
A hacker identifying a flaw in the security settings of the application and accessing user data without permission, or malicious actors using weak authentication processes to gain entry to sensitive information.

threat.name: Insecure use of WebView
threat.desc:
General threat description
An Android application with improperly configured WebView components risks exposing itself to attacks that can include cross-site scripting (XSS), JavaScript bridge vulnerabilities, and subsequent data leaks. This issue arises when developers fail to secure the WebView environment properly.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors can exploit these vulnerabilities through crafted links or embedding malicious script content in WebView. Additionally, inadequate input validation within WebView can permit dangerous JavaScript execution.
Impacts
Successful exploitation may lead to unauthorized access to sensitive data, execution of arbitrary code, compromise of user accounts, and loss of integrity, confidentiality, and availability in the application.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker creates a malicious link that a user clicks on, leading to the execution of harmful JavaScript within the application’s WebView, resulting in the theft of session data. Another situation could involve the exposure of device data due to an improperly configured JavaScript bridge in WebView, allowing attacker control.

customField.value: ATT&CK Mobile - T1623 - Command and Scripting Interpreter

threat.name: Data leakage through insecure storage
threat.desc:
General threat description
Sensitive information might be revealed due to inadequate storage methods, which include storing credentials without encryption or permitting access to shared storage areas.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Cybercriminals and other malicious actors may exploit these vulnerabilities by accessing unsecured storage locations to retrieve confidential information.
Impacts
Compromise of user credentials, unauthorized access to private data, and potential legal repercussions due to non-compliance with data protection regulations.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker could retrieve a user’s login credentials stored in plaintext format on a device. Another scenario could involve an app unintentionally permitting read access to its data on shared storage, allowing a malicious app to browse and steal sensitive information.

threat.name: Interception of network traffic
threat.desc:
General threat description
The risk involves the interception of network communication between the device client and the server, potentially leading to unwanted data exposure and unauthorized session control.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors may employ techniques to eavesdrop on unsecured network transmissions or manipulate the communication flow to execute attacks.
Impacts
Such activities can result in the exposure of sensitive information, unauthorized access to user sessions, and compromise of data integrity.
Example Attack Scenarios
An adversary positions themselves within the network path between the user device and the server, capturing login credentials and session tokens to impersonate the user or access confidential transactions.

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Session hijacking and token theft
threat.desc:
General threat description
Attackers could illegally obtain authentication tokens or session cookies, granting them the ability to masquerade as legitimate users, thereby gaining unauthorized access to user accounts and sensitive data.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Cybercriminals may leverage various techniques such as man-in-the-middle attacks, cross-site scripting, or malware to intercept and capture these authentication credentials during transmission or from the device.
Impacts
This threat can lead to significant breaches of confidential information, unauthorized transactions, privacy violations, financial loss, and damage to the integrity and reputation of affected users and organizations.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker positions themselves on an unsecured Wi-Fi network to intercept token exchanges. Alternatively, they inject malicious scripts into a vulnerable web page that steals cookies from unsuspecting visitors, allowing them to assume the victims’ identities on various platforms.

customField.value: ATT&CK Mobile - T1635 - Steal Application Access Token

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Tampering and reverse engineering
threat.desc:
General threat description
Attackers could tamper with or decompile the app's code to undermine built-in security protocols, access confidential data, or develop malicious replicas.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Individuals with malicious intent leveraging reverse engineering tools and code modification techniques.
Impacts
Breach of sensitive information, compromised data integrity, and potential distribution of counterfeit app versions.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker might reverse engineer the app to disable its authentication process or manipulate the app to extract and misuse user credentials. Another scenario could involve creating a fake version of the app to trick users into installing it, leading to data theft.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter

threat.name: Untrusted input handling
threat.desc:
General threat description
The application could be compromised through manipulation techniques that exploit weaknesses in the input validation process, leading to potential unauthorized access and data breaches.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious users or external attackers may craft and submit specially crafted inputs to target and exploit the application's validation vulnerabilities, including SQL injection, command injection, and insecure deserialization.
Impacts
The consequences of these attacks could involve unauthorized data access, unauthorized command execution, data loss, or data corruption, undermining the application's integrity and confidentiality.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker could inject malicious SQL code within a user input field to extract sensitive information from the database. Alternatively, the attacker might provide crafted data that, when deserialized insecurely, permits remote code execution to gain control over the application server.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

threat.name: Insecure third-party dependencies
threat.desc:
General threat description
Using outdated or vulnerable third-party libraries in an Android application can introduce significant security risks. These libraries may have known exploits that attackers can take advantage of, leading to possible compromises of the application and the device. Additionally, the use of these libraries can result in dependency hijacking, where attackers replace the legitimate library with a malicious one.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include cybercriminals and malicious entities who exploit known vulnerabilities in third-party libraries used by the Android application. The attack vector involves leveraging these vulnerabilities, which may be publicly accessible, or employing dependency confusion techniques to insert malicious code.
Impacts
The impacts of using outdated or vulnerable third-party libraries include unauthorized access to sensitive user data, application crashes or malfunctioning, unauthorized actions performed in the background, and potential dissemination of malicious software. This could lead to loss of user trust, brand damage, and financial losses for the application developers.
Example Attack Scenarios
An example attack scenario might involve an attacker scanning for Android applications using a specific outdated library with a known Remote Code Execution (RCE) vulnerability. Once identified, the attacker exploits this vulnerability to gain control over the device. In another scenario, an attacker could upload a malicious version of an existing popular library to a public repository, causing the application to unknowingly integrate compromised code when the library is retrieved.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation

weakness.name: CWE-1125
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1125: Excessive Attack Surface The product has an attack surface whose quantitative measurement exceeds a desirable maximum.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-250
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-250: Execution with Unnecessary Privileges The product performs an operation at a privilege level that is higher than the minimum level required, which creates new weaknesses or amplifies the consequences of other weaknesses.

weakness.name: CWE-276
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-276: Incorrect Default Permissions During installation, installed file permissions are set to allow anyone to modify those files.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-352
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-352: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) The web application does not, or can not, sufficiently verify whether a well-formed, valid, consistent request was intentionally provided by the user who submitted the request. When a web server is designed to receive a request from a client without any mechanism for verifying that it was intentionally sent, then it might be possible for an attacker to trick a client into making an unintentional request to the web server which will be treated as an authentic request. This can be done via a URL, image load, XMLHttpRequest, etc. and can result in exposure of data or unintended code execution.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

countermeasure.name: Consider encryption of data at rest
countermeasure.desc:
You have the following options for protecting data at rest in Amazon S3:

  • Server-side encryption – All Amazon S3 buckets have encryption configured by default, and all new objects that are uploaded to an S3 bucket are automatically encrypted at rest. Server-side encryption with Amazon S3 managed keys (SSE-S3) is the default encryption configuration for every bucket in Amazon S3. To use a different type of encryption, you can either specify the type of server-side encryption to use in your S3 PUT requests, or you can set the default encryption configuration in the destination bucket.

Amazon S3 also provides these server-side encryption options:

  • Server-side encryption with AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) keys (SSE-KMS)
  • Dual-layer server-side encryption with AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) keys (DSSE-KMS)
  • Server-side encryption with customer-provided keys (SSE-C)

For more information, see Protecting data with server-side encryption.

  • Client-side encryption – Encrypt data client-side and upload the encrypted data to Amazon S3. In this case, you manage the encryption process, the encryption keys, and related tools. As with server-side encryption, client-side encryption can help reduce risk by encrypting the data with a key that is stored in a different mechanism than the mechanism that stores the data itself.

Amazon S3 provides multiple client-side encryption options. For more information, see Protecting data by using client-side encryption.

standard.ref: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information
SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

countermeasure.name: Consider using S3 Cross-Region Replication
countermeasure.desc:
Although Amazon S3 stores your data across multiple geographically diverse Availability Zones by default, compliance requirements might dictate that you store data at even greater distances. With S3 Cross-Region Replication (CRR), you can replicate data between distant AWS Regions to help satisfy these requirements. CRR enables automatic, asynchronous copying of objects across buckets in different AWS Regions. For more information, see Replicating objects.

Note

CRR requires both the source and destination S3 buckets to have versioning enabled.

Also consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-replication-enabled managed AWS Config rule.

standard.ref: Business Continuity Management and Operational Resilience
DE.AE-3: Event data are collected and correlated from multiple sources and sensors

PR.IP-4: Backups of information are conducted, maintained, and tested
PR.IP-8: Effectiveness of protection technologies is shared
PR.IP-9: Response plans (Incident Response and Business Continuity) and recovery plans (Incident Recovery and Disaster Recovery) are in place and managed

PR.PT-5: Mechanisms (e.g., failsafe, load balancing, hot swap) are implemented to achieve resilience requirements in normal and adverse situations

RS.AN-2: The impact of the incident is understood
RS.AN-4: Incidents are categorized consistent with response plans
RS.CO-1: Personnel know their roles and order of operations when a response is needed
RS.CO-3: Information is shared consistent with response plans
RS.CO-4: Coordination with stakeholders occurs consistent with response plans
RS.IM-1: Response plans incorporate lessons learned
RS.RP-1: Response plan is executed during or after an incident

countermeasure.name: Consider using S3 Object Lock
countermeasure.desc:
With S3 Object Lock, you can store objects by using a "Write Once Read Many" (WORM) model. S3 Object Lock can help prevent accidental or inappropriate deletion of data. For example, you can use S3 Object Lock to help protect your AWS CloudTrail logs.

For more information, see Using S3 Object Lock.

countermeasure.name: Disable access control lists (ACLs) and use bucket policies to manage permissions
countermeasure.desc:
S3 Object Ownership is an Amazon S3 bucket-level setting that you can use to control ownership of objects uploaded to your bucket and to disable or enable ACLs. By default, Object Ownership is set to the Bucket owner enforced setting and all ACLs are disabled. When ACLs are disabled, the bucket owner owns all the objects in the bucket and manages access to data exclusively using access management policies.

A majority of modern use cases in Amazon S3 no longer require the use of access control lists (ACLs). We recommend that you disable ACLs, except in unusual circumstances where you must control access for each object individually. To disable ACLs and take ownership of every object in your bucket, apply the bucket owner enforced setting for S3 Object Ownership. When you disable ACLs, you can easily maintain a bucket with objects uploaded by different AWS accounts.

When ACLs are disabled access control for your data is based on policies, such as the following:

  • AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) user policies
  • S3 bucket policies
  • Virtual private cloud (VPC) endpoint policies
  • AWS Organizations service control policies (SCPs)

Disabling ACLs simplifies permissions management and auditing. ACLs are disabled for new buckets by default. You can also disable ACLs for existing buckets. If you have an existing bucket that already has objects in it, after you disable ACLs, the object and bucket ACLs are no longer part of the access-evaluation process. Instead, access is granted or denied on the basis of policies.

Before you disable ACLs, make sure that you do the following:

  • Review your bucket policy to ensure that it covers all the ways that you intend to grant access to your bucket outside of your account.
  • Reset your bucket ACL to the default (full control to the bucket owner).

After you disable ACLs, the following behaviors occur:

  • Your bucket accepts only PUT requests that do not specify an ACL or PUT requests with bucket owner full control ACLs. These ACLs include the bucket-owner-full-control canned ACL or equivalent forms of this ACL that are expressed in XML.
  • Existing applications that support bucket owner full control ACLs see no impact.
  • PUT requests that contain other ACLs (for example, custom grants to certain AWS accounts) fail and return an HTTP status code 400 (Bad Request) with the error code AccessControlListNotSupported.

For more information, see Controlling ownership of objects and disabling ACLs for your bucket.

countermeasure.name: Discover sensitive data by using Amazon Macie
countermeasure.desc:
Amazon Macie is a security service that discovers sensitive data by using machine learning and pattern matching. Macie provides visibility into data security risks, and enables automated protection against those risks. With Macie, you can automate the discovery and reporting of sensitive data in your Amazon S3 data estate to gain a better understanding of the data that your organization stores in S3.

To detect sensitive data with Macie, you can use built-in criteria and techniques that are designed to detect a large and growing list of sensitive data types for many countries and regions. These sensitive data types include multiple types of personally identifiable information (PII), financial data, and credentials data. You can also use custom criteria that you define—regular expressions that define text patterns to match and, optionally, character sequences and proximity rules that refine the results.

If Macie detects sensitive data in an S3 object, Macie generates a security finding to notify you. This finding provides information about the affected object, the types and number of occurrences of the sensitive data that Macie found, and additional details to help you investigate the affected S3 bucket and object. For more information, see the Amazon Macie User Guide.

countermeasure.name: Enable Amazon S3 server access logging
countermeasure.desc:
Server access logging provides detailed records of the requests that are made to a bucket. Server access logs can assist you in security and access audits, help you learn about your customer base, and understand your Amazon S3 bill. For instructions on enabling server access logging, see Logging requests with server access logging.

Also consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-logging-enabled AWS Config managed rule.

countermeasure.name: Enable AWS Config
countermeasure.desc:
Several of the best practices listed in this topic suggest creating AWS Config rules. AWS Config helps you to assess, audit, and evaluate the configurations of your AWS resources. AWS Config monitors resource configurations so that you can evaluate the recorded configurations against the desired secure configurations. With AWS Config, you can do the following:

  • Review changes in configurations and relationships between AWS resources
  • Investigate detailed resource-configuration histories
  • Determine your overall compliance against the configurations specified in your internal guidelines

Using AWS Config can help you simplify compliance auditing, security analysis, change management, and operational troubleshooting. For more information, see Setting Up AWS Config with the Console in the AWS Config Developer Guide. When specifying the resource types to record, ensure that you include Amazon S3 resources.

Important

AWS Config managed rules only supports general purpose buckets when evaluating Amazon S3 resources. AWS Config doesn’t record configuration changes for directory buckets. For more information, see AWS Config Managed Rules and List of AWS Config Managed Rules in the AWS Config Developer Guide.

For an example of how to use AWS Config, see How to Use AWS Config to Monitor for and Respond to Amazon S3 Buckets Allowing Public Access on the AWS Security Blog.

ID.AM-2: Software platforms and applications within the organization are inventoried

countermeasure.name: Enable S3 versioning
countermeasure.desc:
S3 Versioning is a means of keeping multiple variants of an object in the same bucket. You can use versioning to preserve, retrieve, and restore every version of every object stored in your bucket. With versioning, you can easily recover from both unintended user actions and application failures.

Also consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-versioning-enabled managed AWS Config rule.

For more information, see Using versioning in S3 buckets.

countermeasure.name: Enforce encryption of data in transit
countermeasure.desc:
You can use HTTPS (TLS) to help prevent potential attackers from eavesdropping on or manipulating network traffic by using person-in-the-middle or similar attacks. We recommend allowing only encrypted connections over HTTPS (TLS) by using the aws:SecureTransport condition in your Amazon S3 bucket policies.

Important

We recommend that your application not pin Amazon S3 TLS certificates as AWS doesn’t support pinning of publicly-trusted certificates. S3 automatically renews certificates and renewal can happen any time before certificate expiry. Renewing a certificate generates a new public-private key pair. If you’ve pinned an S3 certificate which has been recently renewed with a new public key, you won’t be able to connect to S3 until your application uses the new certificate.

Also consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-ssl-requests-only managed AWS Config rule.

countermeasure.name: Ensure that your Amazon S3 buckets use the correct policies and are not publicly accessible
countermeasure.desc:
Unless you explicitly require anyone on the internet to be able to read or write to your S3 bucket, make sure that your S3 bucket is not public. The following are some of the steps that you can take to block public access:

  • Use S3 Block Public Access. With S3 Block Public Access, you can easily set up centralized controls to limit public access to your Amazon S3 resources. These centralized controls are enforced regardless of how the resources are created. For more information, see Blocking public access to your Amazon S3 storage.
  • Identify Amazon S3 bucket policies that allow a wildcard identity such as "Principal": "*" (which effectively means "anyone"). Also look for policies that allow a wildcard action "*" (which effectively allows the user to perform any action in the Amazon S3 bucket).
  • Similarly, look for Amazon S3 bucket access control lists (ACLs) that provide read, write, or full-access to "Everyone" or "Any authenticated AWS user."
  • Use the ListBuckets API operation to scan all of your Amazon S3 buckets. Then use GetBucketAcl, GetBucketWebsite, and GetBucketPolicy to determine whether each bucket has compliant access controls and a compliant configuration.
  • Use AWS Trusted Advisor to inspect your Amazon S3 implementation.
  • Consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-public-read-prohibited and s3-bucket-public-write-prohibited managed AWS Config Rules.

For more information, see Identity and Access Management for Amazon S3.

countermeasure.name: Identify and audit all of your Amazon S3 buckets
countermeasure.desc:
Identification of your IT assets is a crucial aspect of governance and security. You need to have visibility of all your Amazon S3 resources to assess their security posture and take action on potential areas of weakness. To audit your resources, we recommend doing the following:

  • Use Tag Editor to identify and tag security-sensitive or audit-sensitive resources, then use those tags when you need to search for these resources. For more information, see Searching for Resources to Tag in the Tagging AWS Resources User Guide.
  • Use S3 Inventory to audit and report on the replication and encryption status of your objects for business, compliance, and regulatory needs. For more information, see Amazon S3 Inventory.
  • Create resource groups for your Amazon S3 resources. For more information, see What are resource groups? in the AWS Resource Groups User Guide.

countermeasure.name: Identify potential threats to your Amazon S3 buckets by using Amazon GuardDuty
countermeasure.desc: Amazon GuardDuty is a threat detection service that identifies potential threats to your accounts, containers, workloads, and the data within your AWS environment. By using machine learning (ML) models, and anomaly and threat detection capabilities, Amazon GuardDuty continuously monitors different data sources to identify and prioritize potential security risks and malicious activities in your environment. When you enable GuardDuty, it offers threat detection for foundational data sources that includes AWS CloudTrail management events, VPC flow logs, and DNS logs. To extend threat detection to data plane events in S3 buckets, you can enable the GuardDuty S3 Protection feature. This feature detects threats such as data exfiltration and suspicious access to S3 buckets via Tor nodes. GuardDuty also establishes a normal baseline pattern in your environment and when it identifies a potentially anomalous behavior, it provides contextual information to help you remediate the potentially compromised S3 bucket or AWS credentials. For more information, see GuardDuty.

countermeasure.name: Implement least privilege access
countermeasure.desc:
When granting permissions, you decide who is getting what permissions to which Amazon S3 resources. You enable specific actions that you want to allow on those resources. Therefore, we recommend that you grant only the permissions that are required to perform a task. Implementing least privilege access is fundamental in reducing security risk and the impact that could result from errors or malicious intent.

The following tools are available to implement least privilege access:

  • Policy actions for Amazon S3 and Permissions Boundaries for IAM Entities
  • How Amazon S3 works with IAM
  • Access control list (ACL) overview
  • Service Control Policies

For guidance on what to consider when choosing one or more of the preceding mechanisms, see Identity and Access Management for Amazon S3.

countermeasure.name: Implement monitoring by using AWS monitoring tools
countermeasure.desc:
Monitoring is an important part of maintaining the reliability, security, availability, and performance of Amazon S3 and your AWS solutions. AWS provides several tools and services to help you monitor Amazon S3 and your other AWS services. For example, you can monitor Amazon CloudWatch metrics for Amazon S3, particularly the PutRequests, GetRequests, 4xxErrors, and DeleteRequests metrics. For more information, see Monitoring metrics with Amazon CloudWatch and Monitoring Amazon S3.

For a second example, see Example: Amazon S3 Bucket Activity. This example describes how to create a CloudWatch alarm that is triggered when an Amazon S3 API call is made to PUT or DELETE a bucket policy, a bucket lifecycle, or a bucket replication configuration, or to PUT a bucket ACL.

countermeasure.name: Use AWS CloudTrail
countermeasure.desc:
AWS CloudTrail provides a record of actions taken by a user, a role, or an AWS service in Amazon S3. You can use information collected by CloudTrail to determine the following:

  • The request that was made to Amazon S3
  • The IP address from which the request was made
  • Who made the request
  • When the request was made
  • Additional details about the request

For example, you can identify CloudTrail entries for PUT actions that affect data access, in particular PutBucketAcl, PutObjectAcl, PutBucketPolicy, and PutBucketWebsite.

When you set up your AWS account, CloudTrail is enabled by default. You can view recent events in the CloudTrail console. To create an ongoing record of activity and events for your Amazon S3 buckets, you can create a trail in the CloudTrail console. For more information, see Logging data events in the AWS CloudTrail User Guide.

When you create a trail, you can configure CloudTrail to log data events. Data events are records of resource operations performed on or within a resource. In Amazon S3, data events record object-level API activity for individual buckets. CloudTrail supports a subset of Amazon S3 object-level API operations, such as GetObject, DeleteObject, and PutObject. For more information about how CloudTrail works with Amazon S3, see Logging Amazon S3 API calls using AWS CloudTrail. In the Amazon S3 console, you can also configure your S3 buckets to Enabling CloudTrail event logging for S3 buckets and objects.

AWS Config provides a managed rule (cloudtrail-s3-dataevents-enabled) that you can use to confirm that at least one CloudTrail trail is logging data events for your S3 buckets. For more information, see cloudtrail-s3-dataevents-enabled in the AWS Config Developer Guide.

countermeasure.name: Use IAM roles for applications and AWS services that require Amazon S3 access
countermeasure.desc:
In order for applications running on Amazon EC2 or other AWS services to access Amazon S3 resources, they must include valid AWS credentials in their AWS API requests. We recommend not storing AWS credentials directly in the application or Amazon EC2 instance. These are long-term credentials that are not automatically rotated and could have a significant business impact if they are compromised.

Instead, use an IAM role to manage temporary credentials for applications or services that need to access Amazon S3. When you use a role, you don't have to distribute long-term credentials (such as a username and password or access keys) to an Amazon EC2 instance or AWS service, such as AWS Lambda. The role supplies temporary permissions that applications can use when they make calls to other AWS resources.

For more information, see the following topics in the IAM User Guide:

  • IAM Roles
  • Common Scenarios for Roles: Users, Applications, and Services
