countermeasure.name: Enable and regularly review Cloud Connector audit logging
countermeasure.desc:
Enabling audit logging for the Cloud Connector is essential for monitoring and detecting unusual or suspicious network and system behavior. Audit log data provides valuable information for validating security policy enforcement, identifying potential security incidents, and performing root-cause analysis in the event of a security breach. Regularly reviewing the audit log data helps ensure compliance with legal requirements and company policies, enhancing the overall security posture of the organization.

Remediation:
Follow these steps to enable and regularly review Cloud Connector audit logging:

1. Enable Audit Logging: Permanently enable audit logging in productive scenarios to capture essential information about access between the cloud and the Cloud Connector and track configuration changes.
2. Set Logging Level: Under normal circumstances, set the logging level to "Security," which is the default configuration value. This level provides sufficient information for monitoring and security analysis.
3. Adjust Logging Level (Optional): If required by legal requirements or company policies, set the logging level to "All." This level allows detailed logging, aiding in forensic analysis during security incidents or detecting unauthorized access attempts.
4. Verify Digital Signatures: Ensure that the written audit log files are digitally signed by the Cloud Connector, ensuring their integrity and authenticity.
5. Copy Log Files to External Storage: Regularly copy the Cloud Connector audit log files to an external and persistent storage location, following local regulations and data retention policies.
6. Review Audit Logs: Periodically review the Cloud Connector audit logs using the provided auditor tool to identify any unusual or suspicious activities, configuration changes, or security-related incidents.

References:

  • Audit Logging
  • Manage Audit Logs

countermeasure.name: Implement centralized operation for Cloud Connector
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure secure access to highly sensitive on-premise systems, it is essential to implement a centralized operation for the Cloud Connector. Centralizing the Cloud Connector under the supervision of the IT department allows for better control and monitoring of network communication. Additionally, setting up trust between the on-premise system and the Cloud Connector, and only accepting requests from trusted Cloud Connectors, adds an extra layer of security to prevent unauthorized access.

Remediation:
Follow these steps to implement a centralized operation and ensure secure access with trusted Cloud Connectors:

1. Centralized Operation: Operate the Cloud Connector centrally under the supervision of the IT department. Install the Cloud Connector in the DMZ of the company network to provide an additional layer of isolation and security.
2. Establish Trust: Set up a trust relationship between the on-premise systems and the Cloud Connector. This involves configuring mutual authentication and ensuring that only authenticated and authorized connections are allowed.
3. Trusted Cloud Connectors: Allow requests only from trusted Cloud Connectors that have been authenticated and authorized by the on-premise system. Reject requests from untrusted or unauthorized Cloud Connectors to prevent potential security breaches.
4. Network Zone Selection: Based on the specific needs of the project and the security requirements of the on-premise systems, decide whether to set up the Cloud Connector in the DMZ (for highly secure systems) or the intranet (for less sensitive systems).

References:

  • Network Zones

PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1052 - User Account Control

countermeasure.name: Implement high availability for Cloud Connector
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure high availability and continuous connectivity in case of Cloud Connector failure, it is recommended to install and configure a redundant shadow instance. The main instance of the Cloud Connector, known as the master, is paired with the shadow instance to create a failover setup. The master pushes its configuration to the shadow, keeping it synchronized. The shadow continuously pings the master and takes over its role if the master becomes unreachable. By setting up a failover instance, you create a robust and reliable cloud integration environment.

Remediation:
Follow these steps to implement high availability with the Cloud Connector shadow instance:

1. Prepare the Master Instance:
a. Open the Cloud Connector UI and go to the master instance.
b. From the main menu, choose "High Availability."
c. Choose "Enable" to activate high availability.

2. Install and Set Up the Shadow Instance:
a. Install the shadow instance in the same network segment as the master instance.
b. Use the same distribution package as the master.
c. During the first start-up, select "Shadow" as the instance type and save the configuration.
d. From the main menu, choose "Shadow Connector" and provide connection data for the master instance (host and port).
e. Establish the connection using the master instance's username and password for authentication.
f. Upon successful connection, the master pushes its entire configuration and relevant information to the shadow.

3. Monitor High Availability:
a. The master's UI displays information about the connected shadow instance under "High Availability."
b. Check for any alerts or inconsistencies in the configuration data between the master and shadow.

References:

  • Install a Failover Instance for High Availability

standard.ref: DE.CM-1: The network is monitored to detect potential cybersecurity events
PR.DS-4: Adequate capacity to ensure availability is maintained
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1039 - Environment Variable Permissions

countermeasure.name: Implement secure access control and trusted application configuration of on-premise systems in Cloud Connector
countermeasure.desc:
Configuring the access to on-premise systems in the Cloud Connector requires careful consideration to prevent exposure of sensitive information and unauthorized access. By implementing secure access control and restricting access to required resources, you can enhance the protection of on-premise systems. Additionally, configuring the list of trusted applications allows access only for authorized SAP BTP subaccount applications, reducing the attack surface and improving overall security.

Remediation:
1. Hostname Mapping:
- When configuring access to an internal system, use hostname mapping to associate virtual host names with physical host names. This prevents the exposure of sensitive information about physical systems to the cloud.
- Implement hostname mapping in the access control of the Cloud Connector for both HTTP and RFC communication.
2. Restrict Access to Required Resources:
- During the configuration of access to an internal system, restrict access to only those resources that are necessary for cloud applications. Avoid exposing the complete system unnecessarily.
- Narrow access to on-premise systems to only the resources required by relevant cloud applications in the access control settings of the Cloud Connector for both HTTP and RFC communication.
3. Configure Trusted Applications:
- To allow access exclusively for trusted applications from your SAP BTP subaccount to on-premise systems, configure the list of trusted applications in the Cloud Connector.
- Limit the list of cloud applications permitted to use the on-premise tunnel to those that genuinely require on-premise connectivity. Set up trust accordingly in the Cloud Connector for secure communication.

References:

  • Configure Access Control (HTTP)
  • Configure Access Control (RFC)

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1018 - User Account Management

countermeasure.name: Implement secure practices for Cloud Connector administration UI
countermeasure.desc:
The Cloud Connector's administration UI serves as a crucial entry point for managing and configuring the connector's settings. To enhance security and protect against unauthorized access, it is essential to implement measures that strengthen the authentication process and user management. Changing the initial password of the Administrator user immediately after installation and integrating the corporate LDAP system for user management ensure that only authenticated users can access the administration UI, reducing the risk of potential security breaches.

Remediation:
Implement the following countermeasures to strengthen Cloud Connector Administration UI security:

1. Change Administrator Password: After the Cloud Connector installation, immediately change the password of the Administrator user. Select a strong and unique password that adheres to secure password guidelines. Avoid using default or easily guessable passwords to prevent unauthorized access.
2. Enforce Strong Password Policy: Implement a strong password policy that includes a combination of uppercase and lowercase letters, numbers, and special characters. Require periodic password changes to further enhance security.
3. Configure Corporate LDAP System: Integrate the corporate LDAP system for user management of Cloud Connector administrator users. This ensures that only authenticated users from the corporate LDAP system can access the administration UI, adding an extra layer of authentication and traceability.

References:

  • Recommendations for Secure Setup
  • Use LDAP for User Administration

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1018 - User Account Management

countermeasure.name: OS-Level Protection for Secure Cloud Connector Operation
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of the Cloud Connector and protect sensitive data, it is crucial to implement OS-level protection measures. The Cloud Connector is a security-critical component that handles inbound access to on-premise systems, making it essential to restrict access to the operating system and ensure it is dedicated solely to running the Cloud Connector. Hard-drive encryption adds an extra layer of data protection, preventing unauthorized access to the Cloud Connector's configuration data. Additionally, enabling the audit log on the operating system level allows for monitoring file operations and detecting any suspicious activities.

Remediation:
Implement the following OS-level protection measures for secure Cloud Connector operation:

1. Restricted Access: Limit access to the operating system on which the Cloud Connector is installed to a minimal set of users who are authorized to administer the Cloud Connector. This helps prevent unauthorized access and potential security breaches.
2. Dedicated Machine: Use a dedicated machine solely for running the Cloud Connector. Avoid reusing the same machine for other scenarios, as it reduces the risk of potential security vulnerabilities from other applications or services.
3. Hard-Drive Encryption: Enable hard-drive encryption for the machine running the Cloud Connector. This ensures that the Cloud Connector's configuration data remains encrypted and inaccessible to unauthorized users, even if they gain physical access to the hard drive.
4. Enable Audit Log: Turn on the audit log on the operating system level to monitor file operations related to the Cloud Connector. This enables the detection of any suspicious or unauthorized file access attempts.

References:

  • Security Guidelines

SI-6 Security and Privacy Function Verification
SI-7 Software, Firmware, and Information Integrity

customField.value: SI-7 Software, Firmware, and Information Integrity

countermeasure.name: Use separate Cloud connector instances
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure a secure and stable environment, it is essential to segregate productive and non-productive scenarios effectively. Mixing productive Cloud Connector usages with development or test scenarios can lead to potential security risks and may impact the stability of the system. By using different Cloud Connector instances for productive and non-productive scenarios, you can maintain clear boundaries and enhance overall system security.

Remediation:
1. Separate Cloud Connector Instances:
- Deploy distinct Cloud Connector instances for productive and non-productive scenarios within the SAP BTP landscape.
- Each instance should be dedicated to a specific set of subaccounts that correspond to a particular usage, such as development, testing, or production.
2. Limit Subaccount Access:
- Assign the appropriate subaccounts to the respective Cloud Connector instances based on their usage type (e.g., productive or non-productive).
- Ensure that subaccounts for development or test scenarios are linked to the relevant non-productive Cloud Connector instance, while subaccounts for production scenarios are linked to the dedicated productive Cloud Connector instance.
3. Regular Maintenance:
- Periodically review and update the assignment of subaccounts to the appropriate Cloud Connector instances to maintain segregation.

References:

  • Security Guidelines

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Attackers try to take advantage of a wide attack surface
threat.desc:
General threat description
This threat involves adversaries targeting the numerous exposed endpoints, misconfigured interfaces, and unpatched vulnerabilities present in the SAP Cloud Connector. A wide attack surface arises from extensive connectivity between on-premise systems and the cloud, unnecessary services being enabled, and default or weak configuration settings. This increases the potential for attackers to probe, identify, and exploit weak points, leading to unauthorized access or disruption of service.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include external hackers, opportunistic cybercriminals, and state-sponsored actors. They may use automated vulnerability scanners, port scanning, and manual probing techniques to identify misconfigured endpoints, exposed APIs, and other vulnerabilities. Attackers can exploit default settings, misconfigured firewall rules, or unpatched software to infiltrate the system.

Impacts
Exploitation of a wide attack surface can result in unauthorized access to sensitive data, disruption of cloud connectivity, and compromise of critical business processes. Such breaches may lead to data leaks, financial loss, reputational damage, and potential regulatory non-compliance.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An attacker deploys automated tools to scan the SAP Cloud Connector, discovering misconfigured APIs that allow them to access confidential data without proper authorization.
  • A cybercriminal identifies multiple weak points in the connector’s network configuration and launches a coordinated attack, exploiting these vulnerabilities to disrupt service availability.
  • State-sponsored actors conduct targeted probing of exposed management interfaces, ultimately exploiting a misconfiguration to gain unauthorized access and manipulate system settings.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

threat.name: Attackers perform a Denial of Service (DoS)
threat.desc:
General threat description
This threat involves adversaries deliberately overwhelming the SAP Cloud Connector with excessive traffic or resource-intensive requests, rendering the service unavailable. By targeting system resources and exploiting potential vulnerabilities in the connector's handling of network traffic, attackers aim to disrupt connectivity between on-premise systems and cloud services.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include external hackers, organized cybercriminal groups, and state-sponsored actors. Common attack vectors include distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks using botnets, application-layer floods, and exploitation of resource exhaustion vulnerabilities within the SAP Cloud Connector.

Impacts
If successful, this attack can lead to extended service downtime, degraded system performance, and disruption of critical business operations. The loss of connectivity can result in delayed or failed data transfers, financial losses, and reputational damage due to an inability to reliably access cloud-integrated services.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An attacker deploys a botnet to send a massive volume of requests to the SAP Cloud Connector, overwhelming its processing capacity and causing the service to become unresponsive.
  • A cybercriminal exploits a resource exhaustion vulnerability by repeatedly sending malformed or excessive requests, depleting system resources and triggering a service outage.
  • State-sponsored actors coordinate a sustained DDoS attack, strategically flooding the connector to disrupt data flow between on-premise systems and cloud services, thereby impacting overall business operations.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Dictionary-based or brute force password attack
threat.desc:
General threat description
This threat involves adversaries using automated tools to systematically guess or crack passwords on the SAP Cloud Connector. By employing dictionary-based methods—where common words and known passwords are tested—or brute force techniques that try every possible combination, attackers can eventually discover valid credentials. Weak password policies, default credentials, and lack of account lockout mechanisms increase the likelihood of a successful attack.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include external hackers, opportunistic cybercriminals, and script kiddies. They typically utilize automated password cracking tools, exploit dictionaries of common passwords, or perform credential stuffing with leaked password databases to gain unauthorized access.

Impacts
If successful, these attacks can lead to unauthorized access to the SAP Cloud Connector, allowing attackers to view or manipulate sensitive data, alter configuration settings, and potentially pivot to other parts of the network. This can result in data breaches, service disruption, and reputational damage.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An attacker uses an automated brute force tool against the Cloud Connector's login interface, eventually guessing a weak password and gaining administrative access.
  • A cybercriminal deploys a dictionary attack by systematically testing common passwords against the Cloud Connector, successfully compromising an account that lacks proper password complexity.
  • An opportunistic attacker leverages credential stuffing by using passwords obtained from previous breaches, gaining unauthorized access due to poor password reuse practices.

threat.name: Attackers gain access to the system and are not detected
threat.desc:
General threat description
This threat involves adversaries infiltrating the SAP Cloud Connector and then operating covertly without triggering the system's detection mechanisms. Due to insufficient logging, monitoring, or misconfigured alerting settings, attackers can maintain persistent access and execute malicious activities over an extended period while remaining undetected.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include external hackers, state-sponsored actors, and malicious insiders. Attack vectors involve exploiting vulnerabilities in the system’s authentication or configuration settings, tampering with or disabling logging and monitoring functions, and using stealthy techniques (such as rootkits or advanced malware) to hide their presence.

Impacts
Undetected access can result in prolonged data exfiltration, unauthorized configuration changes, and lateral movement within the network. The continued presence of an attacker increases the risk of further system compromise, significant data breaches, financial losses, and reputational damage, as the lack of detection prevents timely incident response.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An attacker gains access through compromised credentials and disables logging features, allowing them to harvest sensitive data over several weeks without detection.
  • A malicious insider uses legitimate credentials to access critical functions, then subtly alters system settings while masking their activities from standard monitoring tools.
  • A state-sponsored actor deploys stealth malware that evades traditional security controls, remaining hidden in the SAP Cloud Connector and gradually exfiltrating data while leaving minimal traces for forensic analysis.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Attackers could gain access to sensitive data through a man in the middle attack
threat.desc:
General threat description
This threat involves adversaries intercepting and potentially altering communications between legitimate endpoints of the SAP Cloud Connector. By positioning themselves between the client and the server, attackers can eavesdrop on data in transit and capture sensitive information. Weak or misconfigured encryption protocols, unsecured networks, and improper certificate management can all facilitate such attacks.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include external cybercriminals, state-sponsored hackers, and opportunistic attackers. Common attack vectors involve techniques such as ARP poisoning, DNS spoofing, and exploiting misconfigured SSL/TLS settings to intercept communications. Attackers may also target insecure Wi-Fi networks or compromise intermediary network devices to insert themselves into the communication path.

Impacts
Successful man in the middle attacks can result in unauthorized disclosure or modification of sensitive data, including credentials, configuration details, and business information. This can lead to financial loss, reputational damage, regulatory penalties, and further exploitation through lateral movement within the network.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An attacker on an unsecured public network uses ARP poisoning to intercept data exchanged between the SAP Cloud Connector and its clients, capturing login credentials and sensitive configuration data.
  • A cybercriminal exploits weak SSL/TLS configurations to perform DNS spoofing, redirecting traffic to a rogue server where sensitive data is intercepted and possibly altered before reaching its intended destination.
  • A state-sponsored actor compromises a network router in the communication path, inserting themselves into the data flow between the SAP Cloud Connector and a cloud service, thereby capturing confidential business information during transit.

threat.name: Sensitive data is compromised through unauthorized access to data
threat.desc:
General threat description
This threat involves unauthorized parties gaining access to sensitive data managed by the SAP Cloud Connector. It occurs when attackers exploit weaknesses in access controls, authentication mechanisms, or configuration settings, enabling them to retrieve, modify, or exfiltrate confidential information without proper authorization.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include external hackers, cybercriminal groups, and malicious insiders. Attack vectors may involve brute force attacks, exploitation of weak or default credentials, social engineering to bypass security controls, and exploiting vulnerabilities in remote access or firewall configurations.

Impacts
If exploited, this threat can lead to significant data breaches, financial losses, regulatory non-compliance, and reputational damage. Unauthorized data access may expose confidential business information, customer data, and intellectual property, disrupting operations and undermining stakeholder trust.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An external attacker uses brute force techniques to crack weak passwords, gaining access to the SAP Cloud Connector and retrieving sensitive configuration data.
  • A malicious insider leverages excessive privileges or misconfigured access controls to extract confidential data from the system without detection.
  • Attackers employ credential stuffing using leaked credentials, successfully bypassing authentication controls and accessing restricted data, which is then exfiltrated.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1531 - Account Access Removal

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-434
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-434: Unrestricted Upload of File with Dangerous Type The product allows the attacker to upload or transfer files of dangerous types that can be automatically processed within the product's environment.

weakness.name: CWE-521
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-521: Weak Password Requirements The product does not require that users should have strong passwords, which makes it easier for attackers to compromise user accounts. Authentication mechanisms often rely on a memorized secret (also known as a password) to provide an assertion of identity for a user of a system. It is therefore important that this password be of sufficient complexity and impractical for an adversary to guess. The specific requirements around how complex a password needs to be depends on the type of system being protected. Selecting the correct password requirements and enforcing them through implementation are critical to the overall success of the authentication mechanism.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

countermeasure.name: Configure firewalls for SAP BOBJ
countermeasure.desc:
Configuring the BI platform to work in a firewalled environment is crucial for maintaining secure communication between components and ensuring the platform's availability and integrity. Firewalls act as a barrier to unauthorized network traffic and can help protect against external threats. By properly configuring the BI platform for firewalls, the system can operate smoothly while adhering to security requirements and minimizing the risk of unauthorized access or data breaches.

Remediation:
To configure the BI platform for firewalls, follow these steps:

1. Determine which BI platform components need to communicate across the firewall.
2. Manually configure the request port for each BI platform server that requires communication across the firewall.
3. Configure a port range for job server children that need to communicate across the firewall by adding the "-requestJSChildPorts" - and "-requestPort" parameters to the server's command line.
4. Configure the firewall to allow communication to the request ports and job server port range on the BI platform servers configured in the previous steps.
5. (Optional) If Network Address Translation (NAT) is enabled on the firewall, configure the hosts file on each machine hosting a BI platform server that needs to communicate across the firewall.

References:

  • SAP BusinessObjects Business Intelligence Platform: Configure the hosts file for firewalls that use NAT
  • SAP BusinessObjects Business Intelligence Platform: Configuring the BI platform for firewalls
  • SAP BusinessObjects Business Intelligence Platform: Debugging a firewalled deployment
  • SAP BusinessObjects Business Intelligence Platform: Specifying the firewall rules

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1037 - Filter Network Traffic

countermeasure.name: Configure SSL for SAP BOBJ backend servers
countermeasure.desc:
Enabling SSL (Secure Sockets Layer) for backend servers in a BI platform deployment is crucial to establish secure communication between BI clients and BI servers. By implementing SSL, the confidentiality, integrity, and authenticity of data transmitted between the clients and servers can be ensured, mitigating the risk of unauthorized access, tampering, and data breaches. Configuring SSL provides a strong security foundation and builds trust with users, enhancing the overall security posture of the BI platform.

Remediation:
To configure backend servers for SSL in the BI platform, follow these steps:

1. Deploy the BI platform with SSL enabled to ensure secure communication across the network.
2. Generate or obtain the required key and certificate files for each machine involved in the deployment.
3. Configure the Central Configuration Manager (CCM) and the web application server to specify the location of these key and certificate files.
4. If applicable, configure SSL for thick clients (e.g., Crystal Reports) connecting to the CMS to avoid errors when attempting to connect to an SSL-configured CMS from a non-configured thick client.

References:

  • SAP BusinessObjects Business Intelligence Platform: Configuring backend servers for SSL

ID.AM-3: Organizational communication and data flows are mapped
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected
SC-16 Transmission of Security and Privacy Attributes

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information

countermeasure.name: Enable virus scan for SAP BOBJ
countermeasure.desc:
Enabling virus scan for files committed to the BI platform's input and output file repository servers is crucial to enhance the security of the platform. Virus scanning helps detect and prevent the spread of malicious content or infected files, reducing the risk of malware infections and potential compromise of the BI platform. By implementing virus scan capabilities, the integrity and safety of the files stored and accessed within the platform can be maintained, ensuring a secure environment for data handling and processing.

Remediation:
To enable virus scan for the BI platform's input and output file repository servers, follow these steps:

1. Download the Virus Scan Adapter (VSA) library from an SAP certified vendor.
2. Log on to the Central Management Console (CMC).
3. Navigate to Servers -> Servers List.
4. Right-click on the input file repository server and select "Properties" from the dropdown menu to open the Properties window.
5. In the "Input Filestore Service" section, select the "Enable Virus Scan" checkbox.
6. In the "Virus Scan Adapter File Location" field, enter the absolute path to the virus scan adapter library file.
7. Click "Save & Close" to apply the changes.

Note: By default, virus scan is disabled for all files committed to the BI platform in BI 4.2 SP4. Virus scan can be enabled using either the GUI or CLI. The command line argument required for enabling virus scan on the file repository servers is "vsaFileLoc". It is important to enable virus scan on each input and output file repository server if multiple servers are being used. After enabling virus scan, restart the file repository servers to ensure the changes take effect.

References:

  • SAP BusinessObjects Business Intelligence Platform: Enabling Virus Scan
  • SAP Certified Vendors for Virus Scan

standard.ref: ID.BE-5: Resilience requirements to support delivery of critical services are established for all operating states (e.g. under duress/attack, during recovery, normal operations)
ID.SC-2: Suppliers and third party partners of information systems, components, and services are identified, prioritized, and assessed using a cyber supply chain risk assessment process
PR.IP-2: A System Development Life Cycle to manage systems is implemented
SA-15 Development Process, Standards, and Tools

countermeasure.name: Implement environment protection for SAP BOBJ
countermeasure.desc:
No matter how secure a system is, there is often at least one location that is vulnerable to attack: the location where users connect to the system. It is nearly impossible to protect this location completely, because the process of simply guessing a valid user name and password remains a viable way to attempt to "crack" the system. The BI platform implements several techniques to reduce the probability of a malicious user achieving access to the system. The various restrictions listed below apply only to Enterprise accounts--that is, the restrictions do not apply to accounts that you have mapped to an external user database (LDAP or Windows AD). Generally, however, your external system will enable you to place similar restrictions on the external accounts.

Remediation:
To Protect against malicious logo attempts, follow these steps:

1. Password restrictions ensure that users authenticating the default Enterprise authentication create passwords that are relatively complex. You can enable the following options:
- Enforce mixed-case passwords
This option ensures that passwords contain at least one upper-case and one lower-case character in the password.
- Enforce numeral(s) passwords
This option ensures that passwords contain at least one numeric character.
- Enforce special character passwords
This option ensures that passwords contain at least one special character.
2. Logon restrictions serve primarily to prevent dictionary attacks (a method whereby a malicious user obtains a valid user name and attempts to learn the corresponding password by trying every word in a dictionary). With the speed of modern hardware, malicious programs can guess millions of passwords per minute. To prevent dictionary attacks, the BI platform has an internal mechanism that enforces a time delay (0.5-1.0 second) between logon attempts. In addition, the platform provides several customizable options that you can use to reduce the risk of a dictionary attack:
- Disable accounts after N failed attempts to log on
- Reset failed logon count after N minute(s)
- Re-enable account after N minute(s)
3. User restrictions ensure that users authenticating the default Enterprise authentication create new passwords on a regular basis. You can enable the following options:
- Must change password every N day(s)
- Cannot reuse the N most recent password(s)
- Must wait N minute(s) to change password
4. Disable the Guest account entirely.

References:

  • Guest account restrictions
  • Logon restrictions
  • Password restrictions
  • Protection against malicious logon attempts

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Attackers try to take advantage of a wide attack surface
threat.desc:
General threat description
This threat involves adversaries exploiting the numerous exposed endpoints, misconfigured services, and unpatched vulnerabilities present within the SAP BOBJ environment. A wide attack surface increases the risk that attackers will find and exploit weaknesses to gain unauthorized access or disrupt business intelligence operations.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include external hackers, cybercriminals, and automated vulnerability scanners. They may use techniques such as port scanning, probing for misconfigurations, exploiting unpatched software, or targeting default configurations to identify weak points in the SAP BOBJ system.

Impacts
If attackers successfully exploit a wide attack surface, the organization could face data breaches, unauthorized system access, and disruption of critical reporting functions. This may result in financial losses, reputational damage, and non-compliance with regulatory requirements.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An attacker uses automated scanning tools to detect open ports and discovers an unpatched service running on SAP BOBJ, which is then exploited to access sensitive data.
  • A cybercriminal identifies a misconfigured administrative interface exposed to the internet and leverages it to gain unauthorized control over the system.
  • Multiple vulnerabilities are exploited in concert, allowing an attacker to bypass security controls and infiltrate various components of SAP BOBJ, ultimately compromising the entire business intelligence platform.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Attackers could gain access to sensitive data through a man in the middle attack
threat.desc:
General threat description
This threat involves adversaries intercepting and potentially altering communications between SAP BOBJ endpoints. By positioning themselves between clients and SAP BusinessObjects servers, attackers can capture sensitive data and credentials in transit. Weak or misconfigured encryption, outdated SSL/TLS configurations, or compromised network infrastructure can enable such interception.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include external cybercriminals, state-sponsored hackers, and opportunistic attackers. They may employ techniques such as ARP poisoning, DNS spoofing, session hijacking, or exploitation of weak SSL/TLS configurations to position themselves between communicating parties.

Impacts
If successful, a man in the middle attack can lead to unauthorized disclosure and manipulation of sensitive business intelligence data. This may result in financial losses, reputational damage, regulatory non-compliance, and further system compromise by enabling lateral movement within the network.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An attacker exploits a misconfigured SSL/TLS setting in SAP BOBJ, intercepting data exchanged between a user's workstation and the server, and capturing confidential information such as login credentials and report data.
  • On an unsecured network, a cybercriminal uses ARP poisoning to intercept communications between SAP BOBJ endpoints, subsequently manipulating the data stream to alter critical business insights.
  • A state-sponsored actor uses DNS spoofing to redirect traffic destined for the SAP BusinessObjects server to a rogue server, enabling the interception and potential modification of sensitive data transmitted in clear text.

threat.name: Dictionary-based or brute force password attack
threat.desc:
General threat description
This threat involves adversaries using automated tools to systematically guess user passwords on the SAP BOBJ system. Attackers leverage lists of common words (dictionary attacks) or iterate through numerous character combinations (brute force attacks) to compromise accounts. Weak password policies, default credentials, or predictable password patterns increase the likelihood of a successful attack.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include external hackers, opportunistic cybercriminals, and script kiddies using automated password cracking tools. Common attack vectors involve leveraging dictionary lists of common passwords, brute force algorithms, and credential stuffing techniques to gain unauthorized access.

Impacts
If successful, these attacks can lead to unauthorized access to sensitive business intelligence data, system compromise, and potential lateral movement within the network. The consequences may include data breaches, financial loss, regulatory non-compliance, and reputational damage.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An attacker deploys an automated brute force tool against the SAP BOBJ login interface, eventually guessing weak or default passwords to gain administrative access.
  • A cybercriminal uses a dictionary attack with common password combinations to compromise user accounts, leading to unauthorized access to sensitive reports and data.
  • A script kiddie employs credential stuffing techniques using leaked passwords from other sources, successfully infiltrating the system due to inadequate password complexity.

threat.name: Reverse engineer an executable to expose assumed hidden functionality or content
threat.desc:
General threat description
This threat involves adversaries reverse engineering executables to uncover hidden or undocumented functionalities that are not intended for production use. Such hidden features may include debug interfaces, backdoors, or legacy code that can be exploited to bypass security controls or gain unauthorized access to the system. The process often reveals sensitive implementation details that can facilitate further attacks.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include skilled external attackers, state-sponsored groups, and knowledgeable insiders with reverse engineering expertise. Attack vectors involve using specialized tools such as disassemblers and decompilers (e.g., IDA Pro, Ghidra, OllyDbg) to analyze binary code. Attackers may also leverage static and dynamic analysis techniques to trace hidden code paths and discover undocumented functionalities.

Impacts
Successful exploitation can lead to unauthorized system access, bypassing of authentication or authorization controls, and manipulation of critical business functions. Additionally, exposure of proprietary code can result in intellectual property theft and compromise the overall integrity and confidentiality of the system, potentially leading to data breaches and operational disruptions.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An external attacker decompiles a SAP BusinessObjects executable to reveal a hidden administrative interface that bypasses authentication, allowing unauthorized access to sensitive reports.
  • A state-sponsored group employs dynamic analysis on a legacy component, discovering undocumented debug functions that can be used to manipulate system behavior and exfiltrate confidential data.
  • An insider uses reverse engineering techniques to extract proprietary business logic, subsequently exploiting the knowledge to facilitate fraud or unauthorized modifications to the system.

weakness.name: CWE-269
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-269: Improper Privilege Management The product does not properly assign, modify, track, or check privileges for an actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

weakness.name: CWE-862
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-862: Missing Authorization The product does not perform an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

countermeasure.name: Apply IAM policies to restrict access to cloud functions
countermeasure.desc:
Define and implement IAM policies that ensure GCP Cloud Functions are invoked only by authorized users and services. Use the principle of least privilege to grant the minimal set of permissions necessary for each user, service, or application. Regularly review and audit IAM policies to confirm that access is properly restricted and aligned with business needs, and that unnecessary permissions are removed. This control helps protect cloud functions from unauthorized access and potential misuse.

For more information, refer to:

  • GCP IAM Best Practices

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1026 - Privileged Account Management

countermeasure.name: Assign a unique service account to each cloud function
countermeasure.desc:
Configure each GCP Cloud Function to use a unique service account to limit the scope of access and privileges. This practice ensures that each function operates with a dedicated identity, restricting access to only the resources necessary for that specific function. By isolating service accounts, you minimize the risk of privilege escalation and prevent the misuse of elevated permissions across multiple functions. Regularly audit the service accounts and their associated roles to ensure they follow the principle of least privilege.

For more information, refer to:

  • GCP Cloud Functions Identity Best Practices

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1026 - Privileged Account Management

countermeasure.name: Enforce HTTPS for all cloud function endpoints to encrypt data in transit
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure that all GCP Cloud Function endpoints are configured to use HTTPS to secure data transmission and prevent interception. This control mandates the use of encrypted communication channels, ensuring that any data exchanged between your cloud functions and external services is protected from unauthorized access or tampering. Review and configure function triggers to ensure they enforce HTTPS and reject HTTP traffic. Regularly audit your functions to confirm compliance with this security requirement.

For more information, refer to:

  • GCP Cloud Functions Security Documentation

countermeasure.name: Store and retrieve secrets securely using Google Secret Manager
countermeasure.desc:
Use Google Secret Manager to securely store and manage sensitive information such as API keys, credentials, and tokens. Configure GCP Cloud Functions to retrieve secrets securely at runtime, ensuring that sensitive data is not hardcoded or exposed in environment variables or code. Regularly audit and rotate secrets to minimize the risk of compromise, and ensure that access to secrets is restricted to only authorized functions or users.

For more information, refer to:

  • GCP Secret Manager Best Practices

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Inadequate access control on functions
threat.desc:
General threat description
Inadequate access control on GCP Functions can allow unauthorized users or services to invoke functions, potentially leading to data exposure, service misuse, or unauthorized access to sensitive cloud resources. Misconfigured IAM policies or broad permissions can increase the risk of such attacks.

Threat agents/Attack vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, compromised accounts.
  • Attack Vectors: Exploiting weak IAM policies, using over-privileged accounts or services to invoke cloud functions, or brute-forcing unsecured function endpoints.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive data, resource exploitation, and service disruptions.

Example attack scenarios

  1. An attacker gains access to an over-privileged service account and uses it to invoke a sensitive cloud function, exfiltrating data.
  2. A malicious insider with overly broad permissions invokes internal cloud functions to manipulate business-critical processes without detection.

threat.name: Improper use of shared service accounts for functions
threat.desc:
General threat description
Using shared service accounts for multiple GCP Functions can expose sensitive resources to broader access than necessary, increasing the risk of unauthorized access or privilege escalation. Shared service accounts may accumulate more permissions over time, leading to potential misuse.

Threat agents/Attack vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, external attackers, or compromised services.
  • Attack Vectors: Exploiting overly-permissive service accounts used by multiple functions, or compromising a function that has broad access due to a shared service account.

Impacts

  • Privilege escalation, unauthorized access to sensitive resources, data breaches, and potential service disruption.

Example attack scenarios

  1. A compromised cloud function with access to a shared service account is used by an attacker to escalate privileges and access sensitive data in other services.
  2. An insider with access to a shared service account misuses elevated permissions to modify critical cloud infrastructure across multiple functions, bypassing security controls.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unencrypted data transmission
threat.desc:
General threat description
Transmitting data between GCP Functions and other services without encryption exposes sensitive information to interception by attackers. Unencrypted communication channels, such as HTTP, allow malicious actors to eavesdrop, manipulate data, or carry out man-in-the-middle (MitM) attacks.

Threat agents/Attack vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, network eavesdroppers.
  • Attack Vectors: Intercepting unencrypted data over HTTP or other unsecured communication protocols, exploiting weak or misconfigured transport layer security.

Impacts

  • Data breaches, loss of confidentiality, unauthorized access, and data manipulation.

Example attack scenarios

  1. A GCP Function sends sensitive data to an external API over HTTP instead of HTTPS, allowing an attacker to intercept and steal the data using a packet sniffer.
  2. An attacker performs a man-in-the-middle attack on unencrypted traffic between cloud functions, modifying the data in transit to manipulate the service behavior.

threat.name: Insecure management of secrets
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improper management of secrets, such as API keys, credentials, or tokens within GCP Functions, can lead to unauthorized access if they are exposed or compromised. Storing secrets in unsecured locations, such as environment variables, increases the risk of leaks.

Threat agents/Attack vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders.
  • Attack Vectors: Exploiting secrets stored in function environment variables, code repositories, or logs, or intercepting unsecured secrets during transmission.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized access to cloud resources, data breaches, and potential manipulation of services or databases.

Example attack scenarios

  1. A cloud function stores API keys in environment variables, which are accessed by an attacker exploiting a vulnerability in the function, leading to unauthorized access to external services.
  2. A developer inadvertently pushes secrets to a public repository, allowing an attacker to use the compromised secrets to access critical cloud resources.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-250
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-250: Execution with Unnecessary Privileges The product performs an operation at a privilege level that is higher than the minimum level required, which creates new weaknesses or amplifies the consequences of other weaknesses.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-327
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-327: Use of a Broken or Risky Cryptographic Algorithm The product uses a broken or risky cryptographic algorithm or protocol.

countermeasure.name: Deactivate the DBADMIN User for SAP HANA Cloud Database
countermeasure.desc:
The DBADMIN user is a default superuser account that has unrestricted access to the entire SAP HANA system, including all databases and data. Leaving the DBADMIN user active poses a significant security risk, as it can be exploited by attackers to gain full control of the system. By deactivating the DBADMIN user for SAP HANA Cloud, it ensures that there is no default superuser account with unrestricted access.

Remediation:
It is highly recommended that you do not use DBADMIN for day-to-day activities in production environments. Instead, use it to create database users with the minimum privilege set required for their duties (for example, user administration, system administration). Then deactivate DBADMIN. You may temporarily reactivate the DBADMIN user for emergency or bootstrapping tasks.

Note
It is not possible to delete the DBADMIN user.

Procedure
To deactivate DBADMIN user, execute the following SQL statement:
ALTER USER DBADMIN DEACTIVATE USER NOW;

Note
You can still use the DBADMIN user as an emergency user, even if it has been deactivated. Any user with the system privilege OPERATOR for the user group DEFAULT can reactivate DBADMIN with the statement ALTER USER DBADMIN ACTIVATE USER NOW. To ensure that an administrator does not do this surreptitiously, it is recommended that you create an audit policy monitoring ALTER USER statements. Also change the password of the DBADMIN user after reactivating it.

References:

  • Deactivate the DBADMIN User

PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1042 - Disable or Remove Feature or Program

countermeasure.name: Implement data masking for SAP HANA Cloud
countermeasure.desc:
Sensitive data in SAP HANA Cloud databases such as Personally Identifiable Information (PII) or financial information can be exposed to unauthorized access, leading to data breaches and compliance violations. Data masking is a security technique that can be used to protect sensitive data by obscuring or masking it, while maintaining its format and structure.

Masking is defined as part of the table or view. The mask mode specifies how access to masked data is determined in object hierarchies, and the mask expression specifies how the data in a column should be returned to unauthorized users.

Remediation:
Implementing data masking for SAP HANA Cloud involves the following steps:
1. Identify the sensitive data that needs to be masked.
2. Determine the masking techniques to be used based on the data type, sensitivity, and business requirements.
3. Configure and apply the masking rules to the database tables and columns containing sensitive data.
4. Test the data masking implementation to ensure that the masked data is still usable and functional for business operations.

Note:
Column masking is defined directly in the table or view using the CREATE TABLE and CREATE VIEW statements, for example:

CREATE VIEW () AS 
WITH [DEFAULT | SESSION USER] 
MASK ( USING '');

For column masking, you define:

Mask mode
When data in masked columns is accessed through object hierarchies, the mask mode specifies how the user accessing the data is determined for the authorization check. There are two mask modes: DEFAULT and SESSION USER.

With DEFAULT mask mode, the privileges of the owner of the next higher-level object with definer security mode are checked. With SESSION USER mask mode, the session user is always subject to the authorization check.

If you do not set a mask mode, DEFAULT mode is automatically applied.

For more detailed information about how these mask modes impact the authorization process, see Authorization in Masked Tables and Views.

Mask expression
The mask expression specifies how the data in a specific column should be returned to unauthorized users. It can be specified using any SQL expression that SAP HANA supports, such as SQL functions or user-defined functions. However, it must return data of the same type and length as the original data. This ensures that masked data appears real and consistent.

References:

  • Data Masking

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1057 - Data Loss Prevention

countermeasure.name: Implement data storage security for SAP HANA Cloud
countermeasure.desc:
Data storage security is an essential aspect of securing sensitive data in SAP HANA Cloud. Without proper data storage security, data may be susceptible to unauthorized access, modification, or destruction, leading to a severe impact on confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data. Therefore, implementing data storage security controls is necessary to safeguard the data stored in SAP HANA Cloud.

Remediation:
To implement data storage security in SAP HANA Cloud, the following countermeasures can be taken:

To protect data saved to disk from unauthorized access, the SAP HANA database uses the following encryption services:
- Storage encryption features of the relevant Infrastructure-as-a-Service (IaaS) provider (for example, Amazon EBS volume encryption)
- SAP HANA data encryption
To protect data saved to disk from unauthorized access at operating system level, the SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA database uses native SAP HANA data encryption in the persistence layer. Data volume encryption protects the data area on disk, while redo log encryption protects the log area on disk. For more information, see Data and Log Volume Encryption.
- SAP HANA internal application encryption service
The internal encryption service is used internally by applications requiring data encryption, specifically the secure internal credential store and the SAP HANA secure store. For more information on these secure stores, see Internal Application Encryption Service.
- SAP HANA backup encryption
SAP HANA database instances are automatically backed up. To safeguard the privacy of the SAP HANA backup data, data and log backups are encrypted using native SAP HANA capabilities.
SAP HANA backups are encrypted using AES 256-bit encryption.

Note
Encryption Keys
SAP HANA encryption keys are managed by SAP. You do not need to take any additional steps to encrypt the secure stores used in SAP HANA to store and manage encryption keys.

If required, you can secure SAP HANA encryption root keys additionally using the external SAP Data Custodian Key Management Service (KMS). The KMS allows you to create/import and manage your own keys with support for customer-controlled encryption keys (CCEK), bring your own key (BYOK), and hold your own key (HYOK) functionality. You can use your keys to protect encryption root keys in SAP HANA.

References:

  • Data Storage Security

standard.ref: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

customField.value: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

countermeasure.name: Implement role-based access control (RBAC) for SAP HANA Cloud Databases
countermeasure.desc:
When users access the SAP HANA database using a client interface, their ability to perform operations on database objects is determined by the privileges that they have.
All the privileges granted to a user, either directly or indirectly through roles, are combined. This means that whenever a user tries to access an object, the system performs an authorization check on the user, the user's roles, and directly granted privileges.
Roles are the preferred way to assign privileges to SAP HANA database users. It is recommended that you assign roles to users instead of granting privileges individually. You can assign (or remove) roles using the Role Assignment app.

Remediation:
Roles are the standard and recommended way of granting privileges to users. In the Role Assignment app of the SAP HANA cockpit, you can assign roles by either:

- Selecting the user you want to assign roles - this allows you to assign multiple roles to one user
- Selecting the role you want to assign to users - this allows you to assign one role to multiple users

Procedure
1. On the Database Overview page, with the Security and User Management or All view selected, navigate to the User & Role Management card, and choose Role Assignment.
2. In the Role Assignment app, choose how you want to assign roles, by user or by role, and proceed accordingly:
- User
a. Find the user.
A list of all the roles the selected user has is displayed, not only those assigned directly to the user but also those assigned indirectly through inheritance.
b. Choose Edit and then Add.
c. Find the role(s) you want to assign to the user and choose Select.
d. If the role is in a role group and you are a role group administrator, specify who grants the role: your user or the role group itself (default), depending on your privileges. For more information about the authorization behavior of role groups, see the SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database Security Guide.
e. If you want the user to be able to grant the role to other users, choose Grantable to Others.
f. Choose Save.
- Role
a. Find the role you want to assign.
A list of all users that have the selected role is displayed.
b. Choose Edit and then Assign User.
c. Find the user(s) you want to assign the role to and choose Select.
d. If the role is in a role group and you are a role group administrator, specify who grants the role: your user or the role group itself (default), depending on your privileges. For more information about the authorization behavior of role groups, see the SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database Security Guide.
e. If you want the user to be able to grant the role to other users, choose Grantable to Others.
f. Choose Save.

References:

  • Assign Roles to Database Users
  • User Administration

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1026 - Privileged Account Management

countermeasure.name: Use data lake's HDLADMIN User securely
countermeasure.desc:
HDLADMIN is the default user created when a new data lake Relational Engine database is created. It is a special user account in SAP HANA Cloud that has administrative privileges and unrestricted access to the system. Therefore, it is important to use HDLADMIN user securely to prevent unauthorized access and ensure the integrity and confidentiality of the data. This account should only be used in emergencies and not as a routine user account. Allowing HDLADMIN to be used for routine tasks can increase the risk of accidental or malicious data loss or unauthorized access.

Remediation:
To use HDLADMIN user securely, follow these best practices:

1. The user name and password are specified during database creation. HDLADMIN is a highly privileged user and its password should be changed regularly. By default, passwords expire in 180 days.

2. To ensure database security and accountability, avoid using generic named user IDs. Use a real user's login name with a strong password instead. New administration users should be created with a restricted scope for each administrator's role. HDLADMIN should be reserved for emergencies only. It should not be used on a daily basis to administer the database.

3. To guard against password loss by the active administrative users (including HDLADMIN), you should either create an emergency access administrative account or grant the ability to change administrator account passwords to a maximum of two other administrators.

4. To guard against password loss by the active HDLADMIN user, create one or more extra administrator accounts. Make sure the administrator accounts are granted all of the underlying roles and system privileges of the HDLADMIN user. Use a randomly generated user name and password and lock up those credentials. If the active HDLADMIN password is lost, use one of the extra credentials to log in to that administration account and reset the original account password.

References:

  • HDLADMIN (Default) User

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Privilege abuse
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat involves the misuse of granted privileges within SAP HANA Cloud, where users or attackers exploit excessive or improperly managed permissions to perform unauthorized actions. Such abuse may lead to unauthorized data access, system modifications, or disruption of services.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Malicious insiders, disgruntled employees, or external attackers who compromise privileged credentials.
  • Vectors: Exploiting misconfigured roles, default or excessive permissions, weak access controls, and social engineering tactics to gain or escalate privileges.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to and manipulation of sensitive data.
  • Disruption of system integrity and potential operational downtime.
  • Increased risk of regulatory non-compliance, legal liabilities, and reputational damage.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An insider with unnecessarily broad privileges accesses confidential data, leading to data leakage or misuse.
  2. An attacker gains access to an account with elevated privileges by exploiting weak controls, then escalates their access to alter critical system configurations.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Sensitive data is compromised through unauthorized access to data
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat involves unauthorized parties gaining access to sensitive data within SAP HANA Cloud by bypassing or exploiting weaknesses in authentication, access controls, or system vulnerabilities. Once inside, attackers can extract, manipulate, or leak confidential information.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: External hackers, cybercriminals, and malicious insiders.
  • Vectors: Exploiting weak or misconfigured access controls, leveraging stolen or weak credentials, and using phishing or social engineering to gain initial access.

Impacts:

  • Exposure of confidential customer, financial, or operational data.
  • Potential data manipulation or exfiltration, leading to significant business disruption.
  • Legal, regulatory, and reputational damage.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An external attacker gains entry by exploiting a misconfigured access control, then accesses sensitive data without detection.
  2. A malicious insider uses their elevated privileges to extract confidential data, bypassing established security protocols.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1071 - Application Layer Protocol

weakness.name: CWE-1021
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1021: Improper Restriction of Rendered UI Layers or Frames The web application does not restrict or incorrectly restricts frame objects or UI layers that belong to another application or domain, which can lead to user confusion about which interface the user is interacting with. A web application is expected to place restrictions on whether it is allowed to be rendered within frames, iframes, objects, embed or applet elements. Without the restrictions, users can be tricked into interacting with the application when they were not intending to.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-494
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-494: Download of Code Without Integrity Check The product downloads source code or an executable from a remote location and executes the code without sufficiently verifying the origin and integrity of the code. An attacker can execute malicious code by compromising the host server, performing DNS spoofing, or modifying the code in transit.

weakness.name: CWE-532
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-532: Insertion of Sensitive Information into Log File Information written to log files can be of a sensitive nature and give valuable guidance to an attacker or expose sensitive user information.

countermeasure.name: Enforce TLS 1.2+ with App Transport Security (ATS)
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of the iOS Device Client, it is imperative to encrypt all network traffic using TLS version 1.2 or higher. Additionally, Apple's App Transport Security (ATS) should be enforced to block any non-secure HTTP connections. Here is a step-by-step guide to implementing this security measure:

  1. Enable ATS in the App:
    • Open your Xcode project and navigate to the Info.plist file of your app.
    • Add a new dictionary key named NSAppTransportSecurity.
    • Within this dictionary, add a boolean key NSAllowsArbitraryLoads and set it to NO to block non-secure loads.
  2. Use NSURLSession:
    • Replace any instances of NSURLConnection with NSURLSession as it offers better support for tasks such as data, download, and upload tasks with URL requests.
    • Ensure that you are handling sessions using NSURLSessionConfiguration with default or ephemeral configurations for greater control over the session behavior.
  3. Set Up TLS 1.2+ Connections:
    • By default, ATS will enforce secure connections over TLS 1.2. Ensure servers are configured to support TLS 1.2 or higher.
    • Test your server's security using tools such as SSL Labs to verify the supported protocols match your security requirements.
  4. Configure Certificate Pinning:
    • Obtain your server’s or service’s SSL certificate.
    • Incorporate the certificate data into your app. You can include the certificate as a file in your app bundle or configure it programmatically.
    • When setting up the NSURLSessionDelegate, implement the URLSession:didReceiveChallenge:completionHandler: delegate method to compare server-provided certificates with the pinned certificates.
  5. Testing and Verification:
    • Utilize debugging and logging to ensure all network requests are performed over secure connections and verify during testing phases that no NSAllowsArbitraryLoads exceptions are unintentionally added.
    • Employ automated security testing tools to check for vulnerabilities possibly overlooked during the manual verification process.

References

  • App Transport Security (ATS)
  • NSURLSession - Apple Developer Documentation
  • SSL Labs - SSL Server Test

countermeasure.name: Follow Apple's privacy guidelines and AppTrackingTransparency
countermeasure.desc:
1. Begin by integrating the AppTrackingTransparency (ATT) framework into your iOS Device Client project. This framework is crucial for obtaining explicit user consent before tracking their data. Ensure your development environment is set up to use Xcode 12 or later, as earlier versions do not support ATT.
  2. Create a new key called NSUserTrackingUsageDescription in your Info.plist file. This key holds a string that explains why your application plans to use tracking capabilities. Make sure the description is clear and concise, providing transparency to the user about the purpose of data tracking.
  3. Incorporate ATT API calls in the appropriate locations within your app’s lifecycle. This is commonly done during the app’s initialization process. Use the ATTrackingManager's requestTrackingAuthorization(completionHandler:) method to prompt the user to allow or deny tracking access.
  4. After integrating ATT, conduct thorough testing to ensure the tracking authorization prompt appears correctly and track users’ responses. Ensure that any attempt to access the device's advertising identifier is conditioned upon user consent.
  5. Reduce data collection to only what is necessary for the app to function correctly. Audit your data collection processes to ensure compliance with user preferences regarding tracking, and avoid collecting any sensitive information unless essential.
  6. Demonstrate transparent data practices by updating your app’s privacy policy to reflect the use of tracking and the types of data collected. Ensure that users can easily access and understand this policy.
  7. For privacy-aware deep linking within your application, use the NSUserActivity class. It provides an Apple-approved method to define activities that can be continued on compatible devices. Ensure user activity information does not expose sensitive data unintentionally.
  8. In the implementation of NSUserActivity, configure each activity to only include data directly related to the user’s immediate task. Avoid sending additional data that may not be necessary for the intended user experience.
  9. Regularly review Apple's documentation and developer guidelines to stay updated on best practices and compliance requirements as they evolve over time.

References

  • AppTrackingTransparency
  • NSUserActivity

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1052 - User Account Control

countermeasure.name: Implement anti-tampering and runtime integrity checks
countermeasure.desc:
• Start by leveraging iOS's built-in FairPlay DRM to protect your digital content. Embed FairPlay streaming technology during the media streaming process to ensure only authorized devices can decrypt and access the content, thus preventing unauthorized use.
  • Incorporate runtime integrity checks to detect any unauthorized modifications or debugging attempts on your app. Use iOS's SecTrust API to validate the presence of expected application signatures and verify the integrity at runtime.
  • Enhance security further by implementing a monitoring mechanism for detecting if the app is running in a jailbroken environment. This can be achieved by checking the presence of files typical in jailbroken systems such as /Applications/Cydia.app and /bin/bash, among others.
  • Implement checks against common hooking frameworks such as Frida or Cycript by periodically scanning suspicious libraries and ensuring SSL pinning is used to protect sensitive network data.
  • Use Swift obfuscation tools to obfuscate sensitive logic and critical code paths. Tools like Swift Obfuscator can help in making reverse engineering efforts more difficult by obfuscating method names, classes, and properties.
  • Ensure all sensitive data stored on the device is encrypted using iOS’s built-in Data Protection API, which uses file system-based encryption tied to the user’s passcode or biometrics for further data protection.
  • Regularly update your app to incorporate the latest security patches and enhancements from both Apple and other third-party libraries you might be using. Enable automatic updates to minimize the running of outdated software versions on user devices.
  • Perform thorough security audits and penetration testing to identify and mitigate potential vulnerabilities prior to app deployment. Utilize tools like OWASP Mobile Security Testing Guide as a part of this process to ensure a comprehensive evaluation.

References

  • SecTrust API Documentation
  • OWASP Mobile Security Testing Guide

standard.ref: PR.DS-6: Integrity checking mechanisms are used to verify software, firmware, and information integrity
SI-6 Security and Privacy Function Verification
SI-7 Software, Firmware, and Information Integrity

customField.value: ATT&CK Mobile - M1010 - Deploy Compromised Device Detection Method
