countermeasure.name: Prevent unintended data exposure in logs and backups
countermeasure.desc:
1. Prevent Logging Sensitive Data:

    Replace usage of NSLog with os_log to ensure sensitive data is not inadvertently logged. The os_log API allows developers to classify log message levels and ensures that sensitive information is appropriately protected.

    • Import the os module with #import <os/log.h>.
    • Replace NSLog(@"Sensitive data: %@", sensitiveData); with an appropriate os_log command, such as: os_log(OS_LOG_DEFAULT, "Sensitive data: %{PRIVATE}@", sensitiveData);.

  2. Protect Files with NSFileProtectionComplete:

    Ensure that sensitive files are protected by utilizing NSFileProtectionComplete to make files inaccessible while the device is locked.

    • When creating a file, specify the file protection attribute:
    • Example for setting protection attribute:
      • NSDictionary *attributes = @{NSFileProtectionKey: NSFileProtectionComplete};
[NSFileManager.defaultManager createFileAtPath:myFilePath contents:nil attributes:attributes];
    • For existing files, apply the protection using:
      • [[NSFileManager defaultManager] setAttributes:attributes ofItemAtPath:myFilePath error:&error];

  3. Disable Screenshots for Sensitive Views:

    To prevent sensitive information from being captured in screenshots, modify views using UIWindow and isSecureTextEntry.

    • For text fields displaying sensitive information, enable isSecureTextEntry:
      • myTextField.isSecureTextEntry = YES;
    • For preventing screenshots of an entire window, set the secure property:
      • myWindow.secure = YES;

References

  • Logging with os_log

customField.value: ATT&CK Mobile - M1013 - Application Developer Guidance

countermeasure.name: Secure WebView configurations
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of an iOS Device Client, it is recommended to transition from using UIWebView to WKWebView. The WKWebView class offers a more secure and modern approach to rendering web content. Follow these steps for a secure implementation:

  1. Integrate WKWebView: Begin by incorporating WKWebView into your project. Replace instances of UIWebView with WKWebView in the codebase. This can be done by updating the storyboard or programmatically initializing WKWebView.
  2. Disable JavaScript Execution: By default, JavaScript execution is enabled in WKWebView. To enhance security, disable JavaScript unless it is absolutely necessary for application functionality. Configure the WKPreferences object associated with the WKWebViewConfiguration as follows: 
    
            let webConfiguration = WKWebViewConfiguration()
            webConfiguration.preferences.javaScriptEnabled = false
            let webView = WKWebView(frame: .zero, configuration: webConfiguration)
    Only enable JavaScript when required and carefully audit the JavaScript content to avoid vulnerabilities such as Cross-Site Scripting (XSS).
  3. Restrict Navigation to Trusted Domains: Utilize WKContentMode.restrictToSafeArea or alternatively implement a custom URL navigation policy. This will ensure that your WKWebView only navigates to pre-approved domains. Implement a navigation delegate and handle the decision policy like so: 
    
            func webView(_ webView: WKWebView, decidePolicyFor navigationAction: WKNavigationAction, decisionHandler: @escaping (WKNavigationActionPolicy) -> Void) {
                if let url = navigationAction.request.url, isDomainTrusted(url: url) {
                    decisionHandler(.allow)
                } else {
                    decisionHandler(.cancel)
                }
            }

            func isDomainTrusted(url: URL) -> Bool {
                let trustedDomains = ["trusted.com", "secure.org"]
                return trustedDomains.contains(where: url.host?.contains ?? { _ in false })
            }
    Adjust the implementation to properly define what constitutes a "trusted" domain based on your specific security policies.
  4. Continuous Monitoring and Updates: Regularly update the app and library dependencies to benefit from the latest security enhancements. Stay informed about new iOS security best practices by engaging with Apple’s developer resources and community forums.

References

  • Apple Developer WKWebView Documentation
  • Apple Developer WKPreferences
  • Apple Developer WKNavigationDelegate

countermeasure.name: Use Secure Authentication with Face ID and Touch ID
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance security for the iOS Device Client, implement biometric authentication by leveraging Apple's LocalAuthentication framework and combine it with the Secure Enclave for secure cryptographic operations. Additionally, utilize OAuth 2.0 or OpenID Connect for robust network authentication. Follow these steps to effectively integrate these security measures:

  1. Integrate LocalAuthentication Framework

    • Open your iOS project in Xcode.
    • Add the LocalAuthentication framework to your project by selecting your project target, then navigating to the "General" tab, and under "Frameworks, Libraries, and Embedded Content," click the "+" button and search for "LocalAuthentication".
    • Import the framework in your code using #import <LocalAuthentication/LocalAuthentication.h>.

  2. Configure Biometric Authentication

    • Create an instance of LAContext which represents the context for performing authentication checks.
    • Check if biometric authentication is available using canEvaluatePolicy:error:.
    • Invoke the evaluatePolicy:localizedReason:reply: method with the appropriate policy (e.g., LAPolicyDeviceOwnerAuthenticationWithBiometrics) to perform the authentication.
    • Implement error handling to manage cases where biometric authentication fails or is unavailable.

  3. Utilize Secure Enclave for Cryptographic Operations

    • Use the Secure Enclave to store sensitive information such as cryptographic keys. This can be done through the Keychain Services API by specifying the kSecAttrTokenIDSecureEnclave attribute when creating key attributes.
    • Ensure that your cryptographic operations that need to remain secure are directed to operate via Secure Enclave when possible, such as performing cryptography in the Secure Enclave.

  4. Implement OAuth 2.0 or OpenID Connect for Network Authentication

    • Determine your authentication provider and set up the appropriate endpoints for authorization and token exchange.
    • Use a third-party library such as AppAuth for iOS, which simplifies the integration process of OAuth 2.0 and OpenID Connect.
    • Configure your application’s info.plist to handle URL schemes necessary for OAuth/OpenID Connect redirection.
    • Implement the authorization code flow with the PKCE extension for enhanced security in your network communications.

Through the above steps, biometric authentication paired with Secure Enclave operations and secure network communication will significantly bolster the security posture of the iOS Device Client.

References

  • LocalAuthentication Framework Documentation
  • Keychain Services Documentation
  • AppAuth for iOS GitHub Repository

standard.ref: Consumers Less Than Under 13 Years of Age (c)

PR.AC-6: Identities are proofed and bound to credentials and asserted in interactions

PR.AC-7: Users, devices, and other assets are authenticated (e.g., single-factor, multi-factor) commensurate with the risk of the transaction (e.g., individuals' security and privacy risks and other organizational risks)

countermeasure.name: Use the iOS Keychain for secure storage
countermeasure.desc:
1. Access the Keychain Services Documentation: Begin by familiarizing yourself with Apple's Keychain Services to understand how the Keychain API works. This will provide knowledge about the methods and constants used for storing sensitive information securely.

  2. Include the Security Framework: Ensure the Security framework is included in your project. This is necessary to access the Keychain Services functions. In your Xcode project, go to your target’s settings, select the "General" tab, and add the Security.framework under "Linked Frameworks and Libraries".

  3. Define Keychain Access Attributes: To secure sensitive data, set up the appropriate attributes dictionary for the item you want to store. Use the attribute constant kSecAttrAccessibleWhenUnlocked to specify the item's accessibility attribute, which controls when the item can be accessed (only when the device is unlocked).

    let keychainItemAttributes: [String: Any] = [
    kSecClass as String: kSecClassGenericPassword,
    kSecAttrAccount as String: "UserAccountIdentifier",
    kSecValueData as String: sensitiveData,
    kSecAttrAccessible as String: kSecAttrAccessibleWhenUnlocked
]

  4. Add Sensitive Data to the Keychain: Use the SecItemAdd function to store the sensitive information in the Keychain. Check for errors to ensure the item was added successfully.

    let status = SecItemAdd(keychainItemAttributes as CFDictionary, nil)
if status == errSecSuccess {
    print("Data successfully added to the Keychain.")
} else {
    print("Error adding data to the Keychain: \(status)")
}

  5. Access Sensitive Data from the Keychain: To retrieve information, use the SecItemCopyMatching function with a query dictionary specifying the kSecReturnData attribute to access the data.

    let query: [String: Any] = [
    kSecClass as String: kSecClassGenericPassword,
    kSecAttrAccount as String: "UserAccountIdentifier",
    kSecReturnData as String: kCFBooleanTrue!,
    kSecMatchLimit as String: kSecMatchLimitOne
]
var retrievedData: AnyObject?
let status = SecItemCopyMatching(query as CFDictionary, &retrievedData)
if status == errSecSuccess, let data = retrievedData as? Data {
    print("Data retrieved: \(data)")
} else {
    print("Error retrieving data: \(status)")
}

  6. Regularly Review and Manage Keychain Entries: Periodically review the entries stored in Keychain to ensure they are still necessary. Use SecItemDelete to remove outdated entries to maintain a minimal footprint.

    let deleteQuery: [String: Any] = [
    kSecClass as String: kSecClassGenericPassword,
    kSecAttrAccount as String: "UserAccountIdentifier"
]
let status = SecItemDelete(deleteQuery as CFDictionary)
if status == errSecSuccess {
    print("Data successfully deleted from Keychain.")
} else {
    print("Error deleting data: \(status)")
}

References

  • Apple Keychain Services
  • Storing Keys in the Keychain - Apple Developer

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1057 - Data Loss Prevention

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Weak authentication and authorization
threat.desc:
General threat description
Inadequate implementation of authentication protocols allows unauthorized users to gain access to confidential user information and perform sensitive operations without permission.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors can exploit weak or absent authentication measures using stolen credentials, brute force attacks, or by leveraging known vulnerabilities in the authentication process to gain unauthorized access.
Impacts
Unauthorized access can result in compromised user privacy, data breaches, and the potential for attackers to perform actions on behalf of legitimate users, leading to loss of trust and reputational damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker performs a brute force attack on user passwords, gaining access to the application and sensitive user data. 2. A phishing attack results in the compromise of user credentials, due to lack of multi-factor authentication, allowing unauthorized access to the application. 3. A vulnerability in the authentication system is exploited by attackers to bypass login mechanisms and gain access to sensitive areas of the application.

customField.value: ATT&CK Mobile - T1468 - Remotely Track Device Without Authorization

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Insecure data storage
threat.desc:
General threat description
Inadequate protection mechanisms may lead to the improper storage of sensitive data such as user credentials, API keys, and personal information, thereby exposing them to potential security breaches by unauthorized entities.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious applications installed on the device or intruders who have physical access to the device are common vectors that can exploit the insecure storage of sensitive data to extract it.
Impacts
Unauthorized exposure of sensitive data can lead to privacy violations, identity theft, unauthorized transactions, or malicious control over user accounts and services.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker installs a malicious app on the victim's device, which silently reads and transmits stored API keys or credentials to a remote server. Alternatively, an attacker gains physical access to a misplaced or stolen device and retrieves sensitive data from improperly secured storage.

customField.value: ATT&CK Mobile - T1409 - Stored Application Data

threat.name: Unintended data leakage
threat.desc:
General threat description
Sensitive information could be inadvertently revealed through various channels including application logs, device snapshots, system backups, or inter-process communications, leading to potential data breaches.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors may exploit backdoors in logging mechanisms, snapshot storage, backup files, or vulnerabilities in inter-process communication systems to access confidential data.
Impacts
Unintended exposure of sensitive data can lead to unauthorized access, resulting in privacy violations, identity theft or financial loss.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to sensitive user information by retrieving unsecured application logs that contain authentication tokens, or by accessing backup files that have been stored without encryption.

customField.value: ATT&CK Mobile - T1413 - Access Sensitive Data in Device Logs

threat.name: Insecure network communication
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unencrypted or improperly configured network communications can expose sensitive user data to interception by attackers (e.g., via man-in-the-middle attacks).
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers who gain access to the network can intercept unencrypted communications, potentially manipulating or recording the data being transmitted between an iOS device and external servers.
Impacts
Loss of sensitive user data, including personally identifiable information, login credentials, and financial details, leading to compromises of user accounts and privacy breaches.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker positions themselves on a public Wi-Fi network used by the iOS device, then intercepts data packets sent from an app that does not use HTTPS. The attacker can then access sensitive information such as user credentials or personal messages.

customField.value: ATT&CK Mobile - T1410 - Network Traffic Capture or Redirection

threat.name: Privacy violations
threat.desc:
General threat description
The iOS Device Client software component may collect, track, or share user data excessively without obtaining proper user consent, potentially leading to non-compliance with data protection regulations and erosion of user trust.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Developers or entities responsible for the iOS Device Client software may incorporate features or code that facilitate unauthorized data collection or sharing practices. Attackers may exploit these features to access user data without consent.
Impacts
Non-compliance with regulations such as GDPR or CCPA can result in legal penalties and fines. Additionally, compromised user trust can lead to a diminished user base and damage to the brand's reputation.
Example Attack Scenarios
A mobile application may silently track user location data and share it with third-party advertisers without user consent, leading to a regulatory crackdown and public backlash. Another scenario could involve an undisclosed sharing of user contact information with affiliate companies, causing users to receive unsolicited communications, thereby damaging trust and resulting in user attrition.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Code tampering and reverse engineering
threat.desc:
General threat description
During reverse-engineering attempts, unauthorized individuals might analyze the application to identify underlying proprietary algorithms, extract confidential data, or introduce harmful modifications.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include cybercriminals, competitors, or malicious insiders who utilize software debugging tools and decompilers to gain insight into the application’s code.
Impacts
Successful reverse-engineering could lead to the exposure of intellectual property, compromise of sensitive information, or alteration of the application's functionality to disrupt its operations.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker could use decompiling tools on the iOS application to find and exploit hardcoded cryptographic keys, or inject malware to alter the user experience, potentially leading to data theft or unauthorized access.

customField.value: ATT&CK Mobile - T1533 - Data from Local System

threat.name: Insecure WebView implementation
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improper configuration of WebView components can present a risk by enabling the injection of JavaScript, which in turn may expose sensitive functions within the application.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors can exploit this vulnerability by injecting malicious JavaScript code into WebView components due to insufficient configuration settings, gaining access to privileged areas of the app.
Impacts
Compromise of WebView components can lead to unauthorized access to sensitive application functionality, potentially resulting in data breaches or unauthorized actions within the app.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker injects a script into a WebView, enabling them to manipulate data and actions within the app that should be restricted or confidential, such as accessing user credentials or performing unwanted transactions.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

countermeasure.name: Configure network security for SAP Enterprise Portal
countermeasure.desc:
Proper network and communication security configurations are essential for safeguarding the SAP Enterprise Portal and its associated resources. The security concept for SAP NetWeaver Application Server (AS) Java covers the network and communication security for the portal.

Remediation:
1. Refer to the SAP NetWeaver Application Server for Java Security Guide to understand the recommended network and communication security configurations for the SAP Enterprise Portal.
2. Implement a network architecture with multiple network zones, where the portal server and AS Java reside in the inner demilitarized zone (DMZ), while back-end systems such as SAP systems are located in the high-security area.
3. Configure the document domain and Same Origin Policy (SOP) settings appropriately to enable secure interaction between applications within the SAP Enterprise Portal frames.
4. Enable secure network communication, such as Transport Layer Security (TLS) or Secure Sockets Layer (SSL), between the portal server and back-end systems by configuring the AS Java to use these protocols.
5. Separate the Search and Classification (TREX) server from the portal server and establish a packet-filtering firewall to restrict access to the TREX server only to the portal, preventing normal users from accessing it.
6. If utilizing a Federated Portal Network (FPN), configure the AS Java to use SSL for secure communication of remote role assignment information, and consider the limitations of SSL support for remote delta links.
7. For iViews that involve back-end communication, protect the communication by enabling Secure Network Communication (SNC) or SSL, depending on the iView type.
8. Set up appropriate firewall rules and configure the application gateway's translation table (publishing rules) to allow client-back-end communication and ensure secure access for clients through firewalls.

References:

  • Network and Communication Security

countermeasure.name: Implement RBAC for SAP Enterprise Portal
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing Role-based Access Control (RBAC) in SAP Enterprise Portal enhances security and ensures that users have appropriate access privileges based on their roles and responsibilities within the organization. RBAC provides a structured approach to managing portal content, defining navigation structures, and assigning permissions to users and groups.

Remediation:
After installation, the following preconfigured roles are assigned to the following standard groups:

Role | Assigned to Groups

Super Admin | Administrators
Standard User | Administrators

Note
The Super Admin role has access to all content and objects in the portal and these permissions cannot be deleted or modified. Because this role has such extensive permissions, SAP recommends not to assign users to this role for normal daily administration. SAP recommends that only one user account should be assigned to this role. All other administrator users should be assigned a subset of administrative tasks and these users should be used for daily administration.
For more information about delegating administrative tasks to a number of users, see Administration Roles and Delegating Administration Tasks.

SAP recommends that after installation you assign the Standard User role to the default group Everyone. If this group does not have a role assigned to it, some users may not have a role assigned to them and, as a result, see a blank page when they log on to the portal.

To implement RBAC for SAP Enterprise Portal:

1. Analyze the existing portal roles and their association with user access requirements.
2. Identify the permissions and privileges associated with each role and ensure they align with job functions and responsibilities.
3. Define additional roles if needed, considering the principle of least privilege.
4. Review the preconfigured roles provided by SAP and customize them as required, keeping in mind the specific needs of the organization.
5. Assign appropriate roles to user groups based on their job functions and responsibilities.
6. Configure the portal to inherit permissions from the assigned roles for users and groups.
7. Conduct thorough testing to verify that users are granted the correct permissions and access rights according to their assigned roles.

References:

  • Portal Roles

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Privilege abuse
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Privilege abuse in SAP Enterprise Portal occurs when users or compromised accounts misuse their granted permissions to perform actions beyond their authorized limits. This is often due to misconfigured access controls or excessive privileges.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Malicious Insiders: Employees or contractors misusing their access.
  • Compromised Accounts: External attackers leveraging stolen credentials.
  • Attack Vectors: Exploiting weak role-based access controls, privilege escalation techniques, or legacy/shared accounts.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive data.
  • Alteration of system configurations and data integrity issues.
  • Compliance violations and reputational damage.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An insider intentionally exports confidential documents for personal gain.
  2. An attacker uses a phishing attack to compromise a high-privilege account and access restricted data.
  3. Misconfigured access settings allow a user to elevate privileges and perform administrative tasks.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Attackers could gain access to sensitive data through a man in the middle attack
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
This threat involves attackers positioning themselves between users and the SAP Enterprise Portal to intercept, decrypt, and potentially modify data in transit. Exploiting weaknesses in encryption or misconfigurations in secure communication channels enables attackers to access sensitive information without detection.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • External Cybercriminals: Employ techniques like ARP poisoning, DNS spoofing, or setting up rogue access points.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploiting unencrypted or weakly encrypted communications.
    • Leveraging misconfigured or outdated TLS/SSL settings.
    • Intercepting data on unsecured public or internal networks.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized disclosure of sensitive information, including personal or confidential business data.
  • Data Integrity Issues: Attackers can alter data in transit, leading to corrupted or manipulated information.
  • Reputational and Financial Damage: Breaches may result in loss of customer trust and potential regulatory penalties.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker sets up a rogue Wi-Fi hotspot, capturing data from users accessing the SAP Enterprise Portal over an unsecured network.
  2. Exploiting a misconfigured TLS setup, an attacker intercepts and decrypts data exchanged between a user’s browser and the portal.
  3. Using ARP poisoning, an attacker reroutes internal network traffic through a controlled device, enabling interception and alteration of sensitive communications.

weakness.name: CWE-1122
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1122: Excessive Halstead Complexity The code is structured in a way that a Halstead complexity measure exceeds a desirable maximum.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

weakness.name: CWE-926
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-926: Improper Export of Android Application Components The Android application exports a component for use by other applications, but does not properly restrict which applications can launch the component or access the data it contains.

countermeasure.name: Configure automatic mobile OS updates
countermeasure.desc:
Implement and regularly update automatic mobile OS updates on all mobile devices to ensure they are running the latest secure versions of their operating systems. This control minimizes exposure to vulnerabilities by promptly applying critical patches and security improvements as they are released. Developers and DevOps engineers should configure mobile device management (MDM) solutions or native OS settings to enforce automatic updates and continuously monitor update compliance across the device fleet.

Implementation Steps:

Enable Auto-Updates:
Configure mobile devices to automatically download and install OS updates as soon as they are available.

Deploy Centralized Update Policies:
Use MDM solutions to enforce and manage update policies across all mobile devices, ensuring uniform compliance.

Monitor Update Compliance:
Regularly audit update logs and compliance reports to verify that all devices are running the latest OS versions and apply remediation if discrepancies are found.

References:

  • Android Enterprise Updates

standard.ref: Contract Requirements for Service Providers and Contractors (a)
ID.RA-1: Asset vulnerabilities are identified and documented
PR.IP-12: A vulnerability management plan is developed and implemented

countermeasure.name: Deploy mobile anti-malware solutions
countermeasure.desc:
Implement and regularly update mobile anti-malware solutions on all mobile devices to detect, prevent, and remediate malware infections that could compromise the device's security. This control ensures that reputable anti-malware software with real-time scanning and periodic full-device scans is installed and maintained. Developers and DevOps engineers should use mobile device management (MDM) tools to enforce consistent deployment, configuration, and automatic updates of malware definitions across the entire mobile device fleet.

Implementation Steps:

Install Reputable Anti-Malware Software:
Deploy trusted anti-malware applications on all mobile devices via MDM solutions or approved installation packages.

Enable Real-Time Scanning:
Configure the anti-malware solution to continuously monitor device activity and block potential threats in real time.

Schedule Regular Full-Device Scans:
Set up periodic scans to identify and remediate any dormant or emerging malware infections.

Automate Malware Definition Updates:
Ensure the anti-malware software is configured to automatically update its threat definitions to keep pace with emerging threats.

Monitor and Audit Compliance:
Use centralized management tools to verify that all devices maintain up-to-date anti-malware protection and address any compliance issues promptly.

References:

  • NIST SP 800-83: Guide to Malware Incident Prevention and Handling

standard.ref: Contract Requirements for Service Providers and Contractors (a)
ID.RA-1: Asset vulnerabilities are identified and documented
PR.IP-12: A vulnerability management plan is developed and implemented

countermeasure.name: Deploy mobile anti-phishing protection
countermeasure.desc:
Implement and regularly update anti-phishing protection on all mobile devices to detect and block phishing attempts targeting mobile users. This control leverages built-in email and browser security features, integrates threat intelligence feeds, and enforces centralized policies to ensure that phishing attacks are promptly identified and mitigated. Developers and DevOps engineers should use mobile device management (MDM) solutions to deploy and monitor anti-phishing configurations consistently across the entire mobile device fleet.

Implementation Steps:

Enable Built-In Anti-Phishing Features:
Activate anti-phishing functionalities available in mobile email and browser applications, ensuring they are properly configured to warn users of suspicious links and communications.

Integrate Threat Intelligence Feeds:
Connect to reputable threat intelligence services (e.g., Google Safe Browsing) to keep phishing detection databases current with emerging phishing trends.

Deploy Centralized Policies:
Use MDM tools to enforce uniform anti-phishing configurations and update policies across all mobile devices, ensuring consistent protection.

Conduct Regular Testing:
Periodically simulate phishing attacks and audit mobile device logs to verify the effectiveness of anti-phishing measures and adjust configurations as needed.

References:

  • Google Safe Browsing API

standard.ref: Contract Requirements for Service Providers and Contractors (a)
ID.RA-1: Asset vulnerabilities are identified and documented
PR.IP-12: A vulnerability management plan is developed and implemented

countermeasure.name: Enable remote wipe and tracking features
countermeasure.desc:
Implement and regularly update remote wipe and tracking features on all mobile devices to protect sensitive data in the event of device loss or theft. This control utilizes mobile device management (MDM) solutions to enable real-time tracking, location monitoring, and the ability to remotely erase data. By ensuring that these features are active and properly configured, organizations can quickly respond to incidents of loss or theft, mitigating the risk of unauthorized data access and reducing overall impact.

Implementation Steps:

Configure Remote Wipe:
Enable and enforce remote wipe capabilities via MDM settings to allow for immediate data erasure when a device is lost or compromised.

Set Up Device Tracking:
Activate tracking and location reporting features on mobile devices to facilitate quick identification and recovery in case of theft.

Establish Incident Response Procedures:
Define and document processes for initiating remote wipe and tracking actions, including regular testing and drills to ensure readiness.

Monitor and Audit Compliance:
Use centralized management tools to verify that remote wipe and tracking features are enabled across all devices and perform periodic audits to ensure their effectiveness.

References:

  • NIST SP 800-124 Revision 1: Guidelines for Managing the Security of Mobile Devices

standard.ref: PR.DS-3: Assets are formally managed throughout removal, transfers, and disposition
PR.IP-6: Data is destroyed according to policy
PR.PT-2: Removable media is protected and its use restricted according to policy

countermeasure.name: Enforce app store whitelisting and robust app vetting
countermeasure.desc:
Implement and regularly update app store whitelisting and robust app vetting policies on all mobile devices to ensure that only approved and trusted applications are installed. This control helps mitigate the risk of malicious apps by restricting installations to vetted sources and enforcing strict approval processes. Developers and DevOps engineers should leverage mobile device management (MDM) solutions to enforce these policies and continuously monitor app installations.

Implementation Steps:

Establish an App Whitelist:
Identify and maintain a list of approved app stores or specific applications that have been thoroughly vetted for security and compliance.

Deploy Centralized App Management:
Utilize MDM solutions to enforce the whitelist across all mobile devices, ensuring that only approved apps can be installed.

Conduct Robust App Vetting:
Evaluate applications for security vulnerabilities, permissions, and overall risk before adding them to the whitelist, and periodically review the approved apps for compliance.

Monitor and Audit App Installations:
Regularly audit mobile devices for unauthorized apps and update the whitelist based on emerging threats and updated security policies.

References:

  • Apple App Store Review Guidelines

standard.ref: PR.DS-6: Integrity checking mechanisms are used to verify software, firmware, and information integrity

countermeasure.name: Enforce regular app updates and conduct vulnerability scanning
countermeasure.desc:
Implement and regularly update mobile applications along with conducting periodic vulnerability scanning on all mobile devices to ensure that installed apps remain secure and free of known vulnerabilities. This control minimizes the risk of exploitation through outdated or misconfigured applications by automating app updates and integrating vulnerability assessments into the mobile device management process. Developers and DevOps engineers should leverage centralized management tools to enforce update policies and deploy vulnerability scanning solutions to identify and remediate security issues in installed apps.

Implementation Steps:

Enable Auto-Updates for Mobile Apps:
Configure mobile devices and app stores to automatically update applications as new, secure versions are released.

Deploy Vulnerability Scanning Tools:
Utilize mobile security tools to conduct regular vulnerability scans on installed applications, identifying potential weaknesses or misconfigurations.

Integrate with Mobile Device Management (MDM):
Use MDM solutions to enforce app update policies and schedule regular vulnerability assessments across all devices.

Monitor, Report, and Remediate:
Establish processes to monitor scan results, report identified vulnerabilities, and quickly remediate issues through updates or configuration changes.

References:

  • OWASP Mobile Security Testing Guide

countermeasure.name: Implement secure backup and data synchronization protocols
countermeasure.desc:
Implement and regularly update secure backup and data synchronization protocols on all mobile devices to protect sensitive data during storage and transit. This control ensures that backup and synchronization processes use strong encryption, secure communication channels, and trusted storage solutions. Developers and DevOps engineers should configure mobile device management (MDM) tools to enforce secure backup settings and continuously monitor synchronization processes for compliance with organizational security policies.

Implementation Steps:

Enable Encrypted Backups:
Configure mobile devices to encrypt data before backup and ensure that backups are stored using strong encryption standards.

Use Secure Synchronization Channels:
Ensure data synchronization occurs over secure channels (e.g., HTTPS/TLS) to prevent interception during transit.

Enforce Backup Policies via MDM:
Leverage MDM solutions to deploy and enforce secure backup and synchronization settings across all mobile devices.

Monitor and Audit Backup Processes:
Regularly review backup logs and synchronization records to verify that data is securely handled and to identify any anomalies.

References:

  • NIST SP 800-111: Guide to Storage Encryption Technologies

customField.value: ATT&CK Mobile - M1010 - Deploy Compromised Device Detection Method

countermeasure.name: Implement secure data storage and device encryption
countermeasure.desc:
Implement and regularly update secure data storage and device encryption on all mobile devices to safeguard sensitive information from unauthorized access. This control ensures that all locally stored data is encrypted using robust encryption standards, protecting it even if the device is lost or stolen. Developers and DevOps engineers should enforce encryption policies via mobile device management (MDM) solutions, configure devices for full-disk encryption, and use secure storage APIs provided by the operating system. Regular audits and updates are essential to ensure compliance and address emerging security threats.

Implementation Steps:

Configure Full-Disk Encryption:
Enable full-disk encryption on all mobile devices to ensure that all data at rest is secured.

Enforce MDM Policies:
Use MDM solutions to deploy and enforce secure encryption settings across the device fleet.

Leverage Secure Storage APIs:
Utilize OS-provided secure storage mechanisms for sensitive data and application credentials.

Manage Encryption Keys Securely:
Implement robust key management practices to protect encryption keys from unauthorized access.

Audit and Monitor Compliance:
Regularly review encryption settings and conduct audits to verify that encryption policies are consistently applied.

References:

  • NIST SP 800-111: Guide to Storage Encryption Technologies

standard.ref: SC-12 CRYPTOGRAPHIC KEY ESTABLISHMENT AND MANAGEMENT

customField.value: ATT&CK Mobile - M1009 - Encrypt Network Traffic

countermeasure.name: Implement strong device authentication
countermeasure.desc:
Implement and regularly update strong device authentication on all mobile devices to ensure that only authorized users can access the device and its sensitive data. This control involves enforcing robust authentication mechanisms—such as multi-factor authentication (MFA), complex passcodes, and biometric verification—to mitigate the risk of unauthorized access. Developers and DevOps engineers should leverage mobile device management (MDM) solutions and enterprise identity providers to enforce and monitor these authentication policies across all devices.

Implementation Steps:

Enforce Robust Passcode Policies:
Configure devices to require complex passcodes with a minimum length and periodic changes.

Enable Biometric Authentication:
Utilize built-in biometric features (e.g., fingerprint or facial recognition) to add an additional layer of security.

Deploy Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA):
Integrate MFA for accessing sensitive applications and data on mobile devices.

Integrate with Enterprise Identity Providers:
Use centralized authentication systems via MDM to enforce consistent policies and monitor compliance across the device fleet.

Regularly Audit Authentication Settings:
Conduct periodic reviews and audits to ensure that authentication configurations remain effective and aligned with evolving security requirements.

References:

  • NIST SP 800-63B: Digital Identity Guidelines

standard.ref: DE.AE-1: A baseline of network operations and expected data flows for users and systems is established and managed
ID.AM-3: Organizational communication and data flows are mapped
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected
SC-16 Transmission of Security and Privacy Attributes

customField.value: ATT&CK Mobile - M1007 - Caution with Device Administrator Access

countermeasure.name: Use VPN and enforce encrypted communication channels
countermeasure.desc:
Implement and regularly update Virtual Private Network (VPN) configurations and enforce encrypted communication channels on all mobile devices to secure data in transit. This control ensures that all network communications are routed through secure tunnels and that robust encryption protocols (e.g., TLS) are applied, protecting against eavesdropping and man-in-the-middle attacks. Developers and DevOps engineers should leverage mobile device management (MDM) solutions to deploy VPN configurations and enforce encryption standards consistently across the device fleet.

Implementation Steps:

Deploy VPN Solutions:
Configure and enforce the use of reputable VPN solutions on all mobile devices to create secure tunnels for network traffic.

Enable Strong Encryption Protocols:
Ensure that both VPN connections and general network communications use the latest approved encryption protocols (e.g., TLS 1.2/1.3).

Centralized Management:
Use MDM solutions to enforce VPN usage and encrypted communication policies across all mobile devices, and monitor compliance regularly.

Test and Audit:
Conduct periodic security audits and penetration testing to validate that VPN and encrypted channels are correctly implemented and functioning as intended.

References:

  • NIST Special Publication 800-52 Revision 2
