usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Exploitation of vulnerabilities in installed apps
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat involves adversaries identifying and exploiting weaknesses in the mobile applications installed on a device. Vulnerabilities may arise from insecure coding practices, outdated libraries, or improper permission configurations, allowing attackers to compromise app functionality and gain unauthorized access to sensitive data stored on the mobile device.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Malicious developers or adversaries who modify legitimate applications to include harmful code.
  • Attackers leveraging known vulnerabilities in third-party libraries integrated into mobile apps.
  • Distribution of compromised or counterfeit apps through both official and unofficial app stores.
  • Exploitation of insecure app permissions and data storage practices within vulnerable applications.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to personal or sensitive data stored by the apps or on the device.
  • Data exfiltration, leading to privacy breaches and potential financial loss.
  • Compromise of device integrity, allowing for further exploitation and lateral movement within networks.
  • Erosion of user trust, resulting in reputational damage for app developers and service providers.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker discovers a buffer overflow vulnerability in a widely used social media app. By exploiting this flaw, the attacker executes malicious code that accesses and exfiltrates the user's contacts and messages.
  • A modified version of a popular banking app is distributed through a third-party app store. Once installed, the malicious app exploits insecure data storage practices to harvest sensitive financial information, which is then sent to the attacker’s server.

customField.value: ATT&CK Mobile - T1455 - Exploit Baseband Vulnerability

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Device theft or loss leading to data compromise
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat involves the potential exposure and unauthorized access of sensitive data when a mobile device is lost or stolen. If the device is not secured with proper encryption and access controls, attackers gaining physical access can extract confidential information, leading to significant data breaches.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Opportunistic criminals targeting lost or stolen devices
  • Unauthorized individuals exploiting weak or absent access controls on the device
  • Attackers leveraging physical access to bypass security measures such as screen locks or encryption

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to personal, financial, or corporate data
  • Increased risk of identity theft, financial fraud, and further unauthorized activities
  • Potential reputational and financial damage for individuals and organizations

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • A mobile device is left unattended in a public place; an opportunistic thief retrieves the device, bypasses its weak screen lock, and accesses stored sensitive data.
  • A stolen mobile device without full-disk encryption allows an attacker to extract confidential business information and personal data, which is then used for further malicious activities.

threat.name: Malware infections on the mobile device
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat involves the introduction and execution of malicious software on mobile devices, which can compromise device functionality, steal sensitive data, or provide a foothold for further attacks. Malware can be delivered through various channels, and once installed, it may operate covertly to disrupt services, exfiltrate information, or control the device remotely.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Cybercriminals distributing malicious apps through unofficial app stores or compromised legitimate apps.
  • Phishing campaigns that trick users into downloading malware-laden attachments or links.
  • Drive-by downloads from compromised or malicious websites accessed via the mobile device.
  • Exploitation of vulnerabilities in mobile operating systems and applications to install malware without user consent.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive data including personal, financial, or corporate information.
  • Degradation of device performance, data loss, and system instability.
  • Potential for the malware to spread laterally within networks or facilitate further cyberattacks.
  • Loss of user privacy and increased risk of identity theft or financial fraud.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • A user installs an app from an unofficial app store that appears legitimate but contains hidden malware, which then records keystrokes and sends sensitive information to a remote attacker.
  • An attacker sends a phishing message with a link to a compromised website; when the user visits the site, a drive-by download installs malware on the device, enabling the attacker to take control of the device remotely.

customField.value: ATT&CK Mobile - T1473 - Malicious or Vulnerable Built-in Device Functionality

threat.name: Interception of network communications
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat involves adversaries intercepting and potentially altering data transmitted between a mobile device and external networks. Attackers exploit insecure or misconfigured network channels to capture sensitive information and may manipulate the data to facilitate further attacks.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Cybercriminals deploying rogue Wi-Fi access points or hotspots
  • Man-in-the-middle attackers exploiting unencrypted network protocols
  • Hackers leveraging vulnerabilities in mobile operating systems or network stacks
  • Adversaries compromising network devices such as routers

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive data such as login credentials, financial information, or personal details
  • Data manipulation leading to fraudulent transactions or misinformation
  • Compromised privacy and erosion of user trust in mobile connectivity
  • Increased risk of subsequent targeted attacks due to exposed session data

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • A mobile device connects to a public Wi-Fi network, where an attacker uses a rogue access point to intercept and log sensitive communications, capturing login credentials and personal data.
  • An attacker exploits a vulnerability in the mobile OS network stack to perform a man-in-the-middle attack, altering data exchanged between the device and a secure server, resulting in unauthorized transactions.

customField.value: ATT&CK Mobile - T1438 - Exfiltration Over Other Network Medium

threat.name: Exposure of sensitive data due to insecure local storage
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat involves the risk that sensitive data stored locally on mobile devices may be accessible to unauthorized users due to insecure storage practices. Weak local storage mechanisms, such as unencrypted files or poorly secured databases, can expose personal, financial, or corporate data if the device is compromised or accessed by malicious actors.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Cybercriminals targeting unencrypted or misconfigured storage systems on mobile devices
  • Malicious applications that gain access to local storage areas containing sensitive information
  • Attackers leveraging physical access to the device or exploiting vulnerabilities in the operating system to retrieve data
  • Insider threats with legitimate access to the device who misuse stored data

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to and exfiltration of sensitive information
  • Increased risk of identity theft, financial fraud, or corporate espionage
  • Compromise of user privacy and potential regulatory or legal consequences for organizations
  • Erosion of user trust in the security of mobile applications and services

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker exploits a vulnerability in a mobile app that stores user credentials in plain text, allowing them to extract this sensitive information directly from the device’s local storage.
  • A lost or stolen device without proper encryption on its local storage is accessed by unauthorized users, leading to the extraction of confidential personal and corporate data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Mobile - T1533 - Data from Local System

threat.name: Data leakage via insecure backup or synchronization services
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat involves the risk that sensitive data stored on mobile devices is exposed through insecure backup or synchronization services. Weaknesses in the configuration or implementation of these services may allow unauthorized access or interception of data during backup or synchronization processes.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Cybercriminals exploiting misconfigured or unsecured cloud backup services.
  • Attackers intercepting data during transmission between the mobile device and backup servers.
  • Malicious insiders with access to backup systems.
  • Exploitation of vulnerabilities in synchronization protocols or software.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to personal, corporate, or sensitive data.
  • Data theft, leading to privacy breaches and potential financial or reputational damage.
  • Increased risk of subsequent attacks if leaked data includes authentication credentials or sensitive operational information.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker identifies a misconfigured cloud backup service used by a mobile device client, gaining access to unencrypted backup files containing sensitive user data.
  • A mobile device synchronizes data with a cloud service over an unencrypted connection, allowing a man-in-the-middle attacker to intercept and exfiltrate confidential information.

customField.value: ATT&CK Mobile - T1470 - Obtain Device Cloud Backups

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Unauthorized access due to weak device authentication
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat involves adversaries exploiting insufficient authentication measures on mobile devices, such as weak PINs, passwords, or absence of biometric verification, to gain unauthorized access. Without robust authentication, attackers can easily bypass device security, potentially accessing sensitive data and applications stored on the device.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Cybercriminals using brute force or credential stuffing attacks against weak passwords or PINs.
  • Insider threats or unauthorized individuals exploiting minimal authentication controls on lost or shared devices.
  • Attackers leveraging social engineering tactics to trick users into revealing their authentication credentials.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive personal or corporate data stored on the mobile device.
  • Potential for further lateral movement within an organization if the device is connected to corporate networks.
  • Increased risk of identity theft, financial fraud, and privacy breaches.
  • Compromise of device integrity, leading to installation of malware or unauthorized configuration changes.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker uses a brute force tool to systematically guess a weak 4-digit PIN on a mobile device, eventually gaining access and extracting sensitive information.
  • A lost or unattended mobile device with weak authentication is retrieved by an unauthorized individual who accesses stored emails, contacts, and financial applications, resulting in data theft or misuse.

customField.value: ATT&CK Mobile - T1626.001 - Device Administrator Permissions

threat.name: Phishing attacks targeting mobile users
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat involves adversaries using deceptive techniques to lure mobile device users into providing sensitive information or downloading malicious content. Phishing attacks on mobile devices often exploit the smaller screen size and limited context to trick users into trusting fraudulent messages, emails, or websites that mimic legitimate services.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Cybercriminals employing social engineering tactics via SMS, email, or instant messaging.
  • Malicious websites or in-app advertisements that redirect users to counterfeit login pages.
  • Adversaries using cloned or lookalike mobile apps designed to capture user credentials.
  • Attackers leveraging push notifications or pop-up messages within compromised apps.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to user accounts and sensitive data such as passwords, financial details, or personal information.
  • Installation of additional malware through fraudulent links or app downloads.
  • Erosion of user trust in mobile communications and associated services.
  • Potential financial loss and privacy breaches resulting from compromised credentials.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • A mobile user receives a text message that appears to be from their bank, prompting them to click a link that directs them to a fraudulent website mimicking the bank’s login page, where their credentials are harvested.
  • An attacker sends a phishing email to a mobile device user containing a link to a cloned version of a popular social media app; once the user logs in, their account details are captured and misused.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Infiltration of malicious applications
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat involves adversaries distributing malicious applications that appear legitimate to mobile device users. These apps may be designed to steal sensitive data, deliver malware, or gain unauthorized access to device functions. The infiltration often occurs through unofficial app stores or by disguising malware as a benign application, bypassing traditional security checks.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Cybercriminals creating and distributing malicious apps through third-party or compromised official app stores.
  • Attackers leveraging social engineering tactics to convince users to download and install fraudulent applications.
  • Malicious developers embedding harmful code into apps that mimic legitimate functionalities.
  • Exploitation of vulnerabilities in app vetting processes to bypass security filters.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive personal or corporate data stored on the mobile device.
  • Installation of additional malware that can further compromise device security.
  • Financial loss due to fraudulent transactions or identity theft.
  • Erosion of user trust in mobile applications and potential reputational damage for affected organizations.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • A user downloads an application from an unofficial app store that appears to offer useful features but secretly collects personal data and transmits it to a remote server controlled by an attacker.
  • An attacker disguises a malicious app as a popular game, tricking users into installing it; once installed, the app gains access to contacts, messages, and location data, which are then exploited for targeted phishing or identity theft.

customField.value: ATT&CK Mobile - T1630.001 - Uninstall Malicious Application

threat.name: Exploitation of unpatched mobile OS vulnerabilities
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat involves adversaries taking advantage of unpatched or outdated mobile operating system vulnerabilities. Without timely updates, known security flaws remain open to exploitation, allowing attackers to bypass security controls, gain unauthorized access, or execute arbitrary code on the device.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Cybercriminals targeting devices running outdated mobile OS versions
  • State-sponsored attackers leveraging known or zero-day vulnerabilities
  • Automated attack tools scanning for vulnerable devices
  • Malicious applications exploiting OS flaws to escalate privileges

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive personal or corporate data
  • Complete device compromise, including installation of persistent malware
  • Potential for lateral movement within connected enterprise networks
  • Erosion of user trust and possible regulatory or financial repercussions

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker exploits a known vulnerability in an outdated mobile OS to bypass authentication, gaining root access and installing spyware to monitor user activity.
  • Automated malware targets devices with unpatched operating systems, exploiting the vulnerability to install ransomware that encrypts sensitive data and demands payment for decryption.

customField.value: ATT&CK Mobile - T1455 - Exploit Baseband Vulnerability

weakness.name: CWE-119
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-119: Improper Restriction of Operations within the Bounds of a Memory Buffer The product performs operations on a memory buffer, but it can read from or write to a memory location that is outside of the intended boundary of the buffer.

weakness.name: CWE-308
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-308: Use of Single-factor Authentication The use of single-factor authentication can lead to unnecessary risk of compromise when compared with the benefits of a dual-factor authentication scheme. While the use of multiple authentication schemes is simply piling on more complexity on top of authentication, it is inestimably valuable to have such measures of redundancy. The use of weak, reused, and common passwords is rampant on the internet. Without the added protection of multiple authentication schemes, a single mistake can result in the compromise of an account. For this reason, if multiple schemes are possible and also easy to use, they should be implemented and required.

weakness.name: CWE-451
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-451: User Interface (UI) Misrepresentation of Critical Information The user interface (UI) does not properly represent critical information to the user, allowing the information - or its source - to be obscured or spoofed. This is often a component in phishing attacks.

weakness.name: CWE-668
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-668: Exposure of Resource to Wrong Sphere The product exposes a resource to the wrong control sphere, providing unintended actors with inappropriate access to the resource.

countermeasure.name: Implement encryption of communications
countermeasure.desc:
To secure a mobile application's user interface and protect against unauthorized access or data interception, implementing encryption of communications is essential. This countermeasure ensures that data transmitted between the mobile app and backend services is not readable by unauthorized parties. Here’s how to put this into action:

Use HTTPS for All Communications:

  • Ensure that your mobile app communicates with its servers using HTTPS rather than HTTP. This encrypts data in transit, protecting it from interception and eavesdropping.
  • Obtain a TLS (Transport Layer Security) certificate from a trusted Certificate Authority (CA) for your server to facilitate HTTPS.

Implement Certificate Pinning:

  • Go beyond standard HTTPS validation by implementing certificate pinning in your app. This involves hardcoding the server’s certificate within the app to prevent man-in-the-middle (MITM) attacks caused by trust in arbitrary certificates presented by the server.
  • Regularly update the app to reflect any changes in the server's certificate.

Secure API Communications:

  • Use OAuth2 or similar secure authentication mechanisms for API calls, ensuring that tokens or credentials are encrypted during transmission.
  • Consider encrypting sensitive data payloads in API requests and responses, in addition to using HTTPS, for an extra layer of security.

Encrypt Data on WebSocket Connections:

  • If your app uses WebSockets for real-time communication, ensure they are encrypted by using WSS (WebSocket Secure) instead of WS.

Validate Input to Prevent Injection Attacks:

  • Securely validate all input on the client and server sides to prevent injection attacks, which could compromise encrypted communications indirectly.

Implement Secure Coding Practices:

  • Follow secure coding guidelines to avoid vulnerabilities in your app that could undermine the encryption of communications, such as insecure storage of certificates or keys.

Test Encryption Implementation:

  • Regularly test your encryption implementation with tools like Wireshark to ensure that data cannot be read in transit. Perform penetration testing to identify and mitigate any vulnerabilities.

Update and Patch Libraries:

  • Regularly update any third-party libraries used for encryption and secure communications to patch known vulnerabilities.

Educate and Inform Users:

  • Educate your users on the importance of maintaining the security of their devices, as device compromise can undermine communication encryption.

Monitor and Respond to Security Threats:

  • Continuously monitor for emerging security threats related to encrypted communications and respond by updating your encryption methods and practices as necessary.

By implementing these steps, developers can ensure that their mobile app's communications are encrypted, significantly enhancing the security of data in transit and protecting against unauthorized access and data breaches.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information

countermeasure.name: Implement Two-Factor Authentication to provide an extra layer of security
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing Two-Factor Authentication (2FA) adds a crucial layer of security to mobile applications by requiring users to provide two distinct forms of identification before gaining access. This countermeasure significantly reduces the risk of unauthorized access, even if one factor (like a password) is compromised. Follow these steps to implement 2FA in your mobile app effectively:

Choose a 2FA Method:

  • Select the appropriate 2FA methods for your application, such as SMS-based codes, email verification, authenticator apps (e.g., Google Authenticator, Authy), or hardware tokens. Consider the security implications and user convenience of each method.

Update Your Authentication Flow:

  • Revise your app's authentication flow to incorporate a second verification step after the initial login. Ensure the process is user-friendly and clearly communicates the need for additional verification.

Integrate 2FA into Your Backend:

  • Modify your backend authentication system to support 2FA. This includes generating and verifying the second factor and managing fallbacks for situations where the primary 2FA method is unavailable.

Secure 2FA Token Generation:

  • Use secure, random generators for 2FA codes. Ensure that codes are valid for a limited time (e.g., 5-10 minutes) to minimize the window for potential misuse.

Implement Rate Limiting:

  • Prevent brute force attacks by implementing rate limiting on 2FA verification attempts. After a certain number of failed attempts, lock the account temporarily and notify the user.

Educate Users:

  • Provide clear instructions and support for users on setting up and using 2FA. Educate them about the importance of 2FA in protecting their accounts.

Support for Backup Codes:

  • Offer backup codes that users can generate and use in case they lose access to their primary 2FA method. Instruct users to store these codes securely.

Test Your Implementation:

  • Thoroughly test your 2FA implementation under various scenarios, including loss of the second factor, to ensure the system is resilient and user-friendly.

Monitor and Review:

  • Continuously monitor the performance and security of your 2FA system. Be prepared to make adjustments based on user feedback and evolving security threats.

Update Your Privacy Policy and Terms of Service:

  • Update your privacy policy and terms of service to reflect the implementation of 2FA, detailing how user data related to 2FA is handled and protected.

By following these steps, developers can effectively implement 2FA, enhancing the security of mobile applications against unauthorized access and providing users with a higher level of protection for their data and accounts.

standard.ref: Choosing and Using Security Questions Cheat Sheet

countermeasure.name: Use secure storage mechanisms
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing secure storage mechanisms in a mobile application is essential to protect sensitive information from unauthorized access, both from external threats and malicious apps. Here's how to do it effectively:

Understand What Needs Protection:

  • Identify sensitive data that requires secure storage, such as authentication tokens, user personal information, encryption keys, and financial records.

Use Platform-Specific Secure Storage Solutions:

  • Utilize the secure storage APIs provided by the mobile operating system:
    • iOS: Use the Keychain service to store small pieces of sensitive data securely. Keychain provides encryption and access control policies based on the device's security features.
    • Android: Use the Android Keystore system to encrypt keys and credentials in a way that makes them accessible only to your app. For storing encrypted data, leverage SharedPreferences in EncryptedSharedPreferences mode or the Room database with encryption.

Encrypt Data Before Storing:

  • Encrypt sensitive data before storing it locally, even if you're using secure storage solutions. Use strong encryption algorithms like AES with a secure key management strategy.
  • Never hard-code encryption keys in the app's source code. Consider using key derivation functions (KDF) to generate keys from user input or securely generate and store keys using the platform's keystore.

Implement Secure Key Management:

  • Store encryption keys securely using the platform's key management system (e.g., Android Keystore, iOS Keychain).
  • Avoid storing keys locally on the device whenever possible. If necessary, use secure server-side services for key management and retrieval.

Minimize Data Persistence:

  • Only store data locally when absolutely necessary. Evaluate if sensitive data can be kept in memory and securely wiped after use instead of being persistently stored.

Apply Access Controls:

  • Set strong access controls for any stored data. Ensure that only authenticated and authorized users or processes can access or modify the stored data.

Secure Backups:

  • Ensure that backups of the application data are encrypted and secure. On iOS, use the NSFileProtectionComplete attribute for files that should be encrypted under lock and key. On Android, opt-out sensitive files from automatic cloud backup or use encrypted backups.

Regularly Update Security Practices:

  • Stay updated with the latest security best practices and updates from the mobile operating systems. Regularly review and update your data storage practices to comply with new security standards and mitigate emerging threats.

Perform Security Testing:

  • Regularly test your application for security vulnerabilities related to data storage. Use static analysis tools to identify potential security flaws and conduct thorough penetration testing to ensure secure storage mechanisms are effectively protecting sensitive data.

Educate Developers and Users:

  • Ensure that developers are aware of the best practices for secure data storage and that users are informed about how to securely manage their data within the app, including the use of strong passwords and secure network connections.

Implementing these steps will significantly enhance the security of sensitive data stored by mobile applications, protecting against unauthorized access and ensuring compliance with data protection regulations.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1029 - Remote Data Storage

countermeasure.name: Use the app sandbox feature provided by the Operating System to contain the app and limit its access
countermeasure.desc:
To leverage the app sandbox feature provided by mobile operating systems for security, follow these steps to contain your app and limit its access to only necessary system resources and data. This is a critical measure to protect both the app and the device from malicious exploits and data breaches.

Understand the Sandbox Environment:

  • Familiarize yourself with how the sandbox environment works on your target OS (iOS, Android, etc.). The sandbox restricts your app's access to the file system, network, and other apps' data, allowing access only to what is explicitly permitted by the OS and the user.

Follow Platform Guidelines for Data Storage:

  • Use the designated directories for storing app data, cache, and user files as recommended by the OS guidelines. These directories are isolated for each app by the sandbox.

Limit Permissions to the Minimum Necessary:

  • Request only the permissions your app absolutely needs to function. Excessive permissions can expose unnecessary risk. Carefully review the permissions during development and before app updates.

Handle User Data Carefully:

  • When dealing with user data, especially sensitive information, follow best practices for security, such as encryption and secure data deletion. Remember, the sandbox isolates your app, but you must still protect the data within it.

Secure Inter-App Communication:

  • Use secure methods for inter-app communication (IAC), such as URL schemes on iOS with proper validation or Android Intents with explicit declaration and permission checks. Ensure that any data shared between apps cannot be intercepted or manipulated.

Implement Network Security Measures:

  • Ensure all network communications from within the sandbox are secure. Utilize TLS for transmitting sensitive information and consider certificate pinning to prevent man-in-the-middle attacks.

Update and Patch Regularly:

  • Regularly update your app and its dependencies to incorporate the latest security patches and features from the OS and third-party libraries.

Use OS Features for Background Execution:

  • For background tasks, use the APIs and services provided by the OS. These are designed to be power-efficient and secure within the sandbox environment.

Test Sandbox Restrictions:

  • Conduct thorough testing to ensure your app functions correctly within the sandbox without unnecessary access to system resources. Use both automated testing tools and manual testing to check for compliance and security issues.

Monitor OS Updates and Changes:

  • Stay informed about updates to the operating system, especially changes to security features and sandbox behavior. Update your app to adapt to these changes, maintaining compatibility and security.

Educate Your Development Team:

  • Ensure your development team is aware of the importance of the sandbox and how to develop apps that function effectively and securely within its constraints.

By utilizing the app sandbox feature effectively, you can significantly enhance the security of your mobile application, protecting both your users and their data from potential threats.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1048 - Application Isolation and Sandboxing

countermeasure.name: Validate all user inputs to protect against injection attacks
countermeasure.desc:
To protect your mobile application against injection attacks through effective user input validation, follow these actionable steps. This approach ensures that inputs cannot be exploited to execute unintended commands or access unauthorized data.

Understand the Risks:

  • Recognize that user inputs can come from various sources including text fields, query parameters, cookies, and any external systems interfacing with your app. Injection attacks like SQL, NoSQL, LDAP, and OS command injections exploit these inputs to manipulate backend systems.

Sanitize Inputs:

  • Use built-in libraries or frameworks for input validation. Sanitize all user inputs by removing harmful data or characters that could be interpreted as commands or queries by the server or database.
  • For web-based mobile apps, encode HTML outputs to prevent cross-site scripting (XSS), ensuring characters like <, >, &, and ' are properly escaped.

Validate Input Formats:

  • Implement strict type, format, and length validation for all user inputs. For example, if a field expects an email address, ensure the input matches the standard email format before processing it.
  • Use regular expressions for format validation but be cautious to avoid creating security flaws with overly complex expressions.

Leverage Parameterized Queries:

  • For database access, use parameterized queries or prepared statements instead of dynamically constructing queries with user inputs. This ensures that the database interprets inputs only as data, not executable code.

Employ ORM Frameworks:

  • Utilize Object-Relational Mapping (ORM) frameworks that inherently use parameterized queries and significantly reduce the risk of SQL injection.

Use Whitelisting:

  • Where possible, employ whitelisting to allow only predetermined, safe inputs. This is more secure than blacklisting, which tries to block known dangerous inputs but can be bypassed.

Implement Client-Side Validation:

  • Use client-side validation for user convenience and to reduce server load, but do not rely on it for security. Always validate inputs on the server side as client-side checks can be bypassed.

Secure External Interfaces:

  • If your app interacts with external systems or APIs, validate inputs on these interfaces too. Ensure that data received from other systems is treated with the same level of scrutiny as direct user inputs.

Regular Security Training:

  • Educate your development team about the importance of input validation and keeping up with security best practices. Understanding the latest attack vectors and validation techniques is crucial.

Automate Security Testing:

  • Incorporate automated security testing tools into your development process. Static Application Security Testing (SAST) and Dynamic Application Security Testing (DAST) can help identify potential injection vulnerabilities.

Stay Informed and Update:

  • Keep abreast of the latest security advisories and updates related to the frameworks and languages you use. Apply patches and updates to mitigate known vulnerabilities.

By rigorously validating all user inputs, you significantly reduce the risk of injection attacks, protecting both your application and its users from potential security breaches.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1040 - Behavior Prevention on Endpoint

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Attackers gain unauthorized access to the App's functions or data
threat.desc:
This threat involves attackers exploiting vulnerabilities in a mobile application's user interface (UI) or its underlying logic to gain unauthorized access to restricted functions or sensitive data. Mobile apps, with their complex ecosystems involving client-side storage, APIs, and server-side components, present numerous attack surfaces. Unauthorized access can lead to data breaches, function abuse, and compromised user accounts.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Can range from individual hackers and malicious insiders to organized cybercrime groups seeking financial gain, espionage, or sabotage.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Insecure Direct Object References (IDOR): Accessing unauthorized data by manipulating input values in requests.
    • Broken Access Control: Exploiting insufficient access controls to perform actions or access data without proper authorization.
    • Client-Side Injection: Injecting malicious scripts or code into the app, leading to data leakage or manipulation.
    • Misconfigured Security Settings: Leveraging default or weak security settings to bypass authentication or access controls.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Loss or theft of personal data, sensitive corporate information, or intellectual property.
  • Privilege Escalation: Gaining elevated privileges within the app, allowing attackers to access additional features or data.
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of trust from users and stakeholders, potentially leading to a decrease in user base and revenue.
  • Regulatory Penalties: Non-compliance with data protection laws can result in legal actions and significant fines.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Scenario 1: An attacker discovers an IDOR vulnerability in a mobile banking app that allows them to manipulate account ID values in the URL of a request. By changing the ID, the attacker accesses other users' account details and transactions.
  • Scenario 2: A social media app fails to properly implement access controls for its photo storage. An attacker enumerates user IDs in API calls and retrieves private photos belonging to other users.
  • Scenario 3: A mobile shopping app's developer left debug mode enabled in the production version, which includes verbose error messages and a hidden admin panel. An attacker discovers this oversight, accesses the admin panel, and extracts the user database.
  • Scenario 4: A fitness app stores user session tokens insecurely on the client side. An attacker develops a malicious third-party app that, once installed on the same device, reads these tokens and uses them to hijack user sessions.

To mitigate this threat, developers should adopt secure coding practices, ensure robust authentication and authorization controls, regularly update and patch all components, and conduct thorough security testing, including static and dynamic analysis, as well as penetration testing of the mobile app.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1056 - Input Capture

threat.name: Attackers exploit vulnerable dependencies to execute malicious activities
threat.desc:
Mobile applications often depend on third-party libraries and frameworks to function properly. These dependencies can include UI components, network communication libraries, or encryption libraries. When these dependencies are not kept up-to-date or are poorly maintained, they can contain vulnerabilities that attackers exploit to perform malicious activities. Such activities can range from unauthorized access and data leakage to complete app compromise.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Cybercriminals looking for financial gain, hackers aiming to access or steal sensitive information, competitors seeking business intelligence, or even hacktivists with a specific agenda.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Compromised Libraries: Using libraries or dependencies that have known vulnerabilities or have been maliciously modified.
    • Outdated Components: Failing to update dependencies to their latest versions, which may have patched known security issues.
    • Indirect Dependencies: Dependencies of your direct dependencies, which might not be as closely monitored or updated, providing a backdoor for attackers.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to sensitive data stored within the app or on the mobile device.
  • User Privacy Violation: Compromise of user personal information, leading to privacy violations.
  • System Compromise: Attackers gaining control over the mobile device or app, potentially leading to further attacks on the network the device connects to.
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of trust from users and partners, affecting the app's popularity and the company's reputation.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Scenario 1: An attacker discovers that a popular mobile UI framework used in numerous mobile apps has a vulnerability allowing for remote code execution. They craft a malicious payload that, when executed, allows them to steal user data from devices running apps built with the vulnerable version of the framework.
  • Scenario 2: A mobile app uses an outdated encryption library, known to contain a flaw that weakens data encryption. An attacker intercepts the app's data transmission, exploiting the vulnerability to decrypt sensitive information, leading to data leakage.
  • Scenario 3: Through a compromised third-party analytics library integrated into a mobile app, attackers inject malicious code that executes when the app starts. This code collects sensitive information from the user's device and sends it to the attacker's server without the user's knowledge.
  • Scenario 4: A developer unknowingly uses a UI component from an untrusted source that contains hidden malicious functionality. This component is designed to capture user inputs, such as passwords and credit card information, and send them to an external server controlled by the attacker.

To mitigate these threats, developers should:

  • Regularly update all dependencies to their latest secure versions.
  • Perform thorough security audits of third-party libraries and frameworks before integration.
  • Use trusted sources for downloading dependencies and verify their integrity.
  • Monitor security advisories for vulnerabilities in used dependencies.
  • Consider using automated tools to track and update dependencies to ensure security patches are applied promptly.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application||ATT&CK Enterprise - TA0005 - Defense Evasion||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation||ATT&CK Enterprise - TA0001 - Initial Access

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Attackers attempt to access sensitive information
threat.desc:
This threat involves attackers targeting mobile applications to access sensitive information, such as personal data, login credentials, financial information, or proprietary business data. Given the wealth of information processed and stored by mobile apps, they are a prime target for attackers looking to steal data for various malicious purposes, including identity theft, financial fraud, or corporate espionage.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Cybercriminals, competitors seeking a competitive edge, hackers with political or social motivations, or insiders with access to the mobile application's resources.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Data Leakage: Exploiting vulnerabilities in the app's data handling processes to intercept or access data stored insecurely on the device or transmitted over the network.
    • Insecure Storage: Taking advantage of insecure data storage practices, such as storing sensitive information in plaintext or using weak encryption.
    • Man-in-the-Middle (MitM) Attacks: Intercepting communications between the mobile app and servers to access sensitive information being transmitted.
    • Phishing and Social Engineering: Tricking users into disclosing sensitive information through fake login screens or malicious links.

Impacts

  • Loss of Sensitive Data: Unauthorized access to personal or corporate data can lead to financial loss, identity theft, and privacy violations.
  • Reputation Damage: Breaches of sensitive information can significantly damage the reputation of the app's developers and associated brands.
  • Legal and Compliance Issues: Violations of data protection regulations, such as GDPR or HIPAA, can result in hefty fines and legal penalties.
  • Operational Disruption: The aftermath of an information breach can disrupt operations and require significant resources to address.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • Scenario 1: An attacker discovers that a fitness tracking app stores user session tokens in an unencrypted preferences file. By gaining access to this file, the attacker retrieves tokens and accesses users' personal health data and messages.
  • Scenario 2: Through a MitM attack, a cybercriminal intercepts unencrypted traffic between a mobile shopping app and its server, capturing credit card information and login credentials of users making purchases.
  • Scenario 3: A malicious actor crafts a phishing email containing a link to a fake login page for a popular mobile game. Users entering their credentials on this page have their accounts compromised, leading to unauthorized access to personal information and in-app purchases.
  • Scenario 4: An insider or a developer with malicious intent embeds functionality within a mobile app that surreptitiously collects and transmits sensitive user data to an external server under their control.

To mitigate these threats, developers must implement strong encryption for data at rest and in transit, adopt secure coding practices, regularly update and patch all app components, and educate users about the importance of data security and the risks of phishing and social engineering. Regular security assessments, including penetration testing and vulnerability scanning, are also crucial to identify and rectify potential security weaknesses.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1566 - Phishing||ATT&CK Enterprise - T1087 - Account Discovery
