countermeasure.name: Implement SAP Ariba procurement mobile app security features
countermeasure.desc:
The SAP Ariba Procurement mobile app handles sensitive data and communication with the SAP Ariba servers. To ensure the confidentiality and integrity of the data and prevent unauthorized access, it is crucial to implement robust security features. By enabling the recommended security features in the mobile app, organizations can enhance data protection, prevent unauthorized access, and reduce the risk of data breaches.

Remediation:
Security features in the SAP Ariba Procurement mobile app help protect your data and the communication between the app and SAP Ariba.

- App lock: Users can unlock the app only by using the same screen lock (PIN, pattern, password, or finger print for android devices) or passcode (code, fingerprint, or facial recognition for apple devices) that they've setup to unlock the device.
- Fingerprint recognition support: allows users to use fingerprint recognition feature to access the mobile app.
- Face ID support for iOS devices : allows users with iPhone X and later devices to use facial recognition to access the mobile app.
- Automatic signout periodically: Users are automatically signed out of the SAP Ariba Procurement mobile app after a period of 30 days from the sign-in. Additionally, customer administrators can specify the number of days after which users are to be automatically signed out of the mobile app by configuring the Force sign out mobile app users after a specified number of days (Application.Mobile.ForceSignOutUsersInDays) self-service parameter.
- Data encryption: All data is encrypted, including data transmitted over the network and data stored on the device (for offline access).
a. All communication between the device and the server is over TLS 1.2.
b. Data stored on mobile devices is encrypted using AES 256.
- Certificate pinning: The mobile app (a client) is hard-wired with the SAP Ariba servers' certificate digest to ensure that the app is communicating only with the correct servers.
- Jailbroken and rooted devices: The mobile app is not supported on jailbroken and rooted devices. If a device is jailbroken or rooted after the app is installed and activated, the app will be deactivated and all data wiped off when the app is reopened.

References:

  • SAP Ariba Procurement Mobile App Security Features

countermeasure.name: Secure access and usage of group descriptions table in SAP Ariba strategic sourcing and supplier management
countermeasure.desc:
The Group Descriptions Table in SAP Ariba Strategic Sourcing and Supplier Management provides critical functionalities for managing group descriptions, actions, and permissions within the system. While these capabilities are essential for efficient administration, they also introduce potential security risks if not appropriately controlled. Unauthorized access to sensitive group descriptions and permissions could lead to unauthorized changes, data exposure, and potential security breaches. To mitigate these risks, it is crucial to implement secure access and usage of the Group Descriptions Table.

Remediation:
To enhance security and control over the Group Descriptions Table in SAP Ariba Strategic Sourcing and Supplier Management, follow the remediation steps below:

1. Role-Based Access Control (RBAC):
- Implement RBAC to restrict access to the Group Descriptions Table based on users' job roles and responsibilities.
- Define roles with granular permissions, ensuring users only have access to the specific functions and data relevant to their job functions.
2. Limited Search and Filtering:
- Restrict search and filtering capabilities within the Group Descriptions Table to authorized users only.
- Ensure that sensitive data, such as group descriptions with critical permissions, cannot be searched or filtered by unauthorized users.
3. Case-Sensitive Search Terms:
-Enforce case-sensitive search terms to prevent unauthorized access through attempts to manipulate search results.
4. Secure Exporting:
- Limit the ability to export the table data to authorized personnel with the appropriate permissions.
- Implement secure export options that prevent unauthorized users from exporting sensitive data to external environments.
5. Audit Trail:
- Establish an audit trail mechanism to track access and changes made to the Group Descriptions Table.
- Monitor user activities and access patterns to identify and investigate any suspicious or unauthorized actions.

References:

  • Project Group Roles
  • Strategic Sourcing and Supplier Management Group Descriptions

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Privilege abuse
threat.desc:
General threat description
This threat involves adversaries misusing elevated privileges within the SAP Ariba environment to gain unauthorized access, manipulate procurement data, or alter system configurations. Overly broad or misconfigured role-based access controls can provide attackers or negligent insiders the opportunity to perform actions beyond their intended permissions, compromising system integrity and data confidentiality.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include internal users such as disgruntled employees or contractors with excessive access rights, as well as external attackers who gain control of privileged accounts through phishing or credential theft. Common attack vectors involve exploiting weak role assignments, bypassing insufficient authentication controls, or leveraging misconfigured access policies to escalate privileges within SAP Ariba.

Impacts
Privilege abuse can lead to unauthorized disclosure or manipulation of sensitive procurement data, disruption of critical business processes, financial losses, and regulatory non-compliance. The abuse of elevated privileges may also damage the organization's reputation and erode trust among business partners and stakeholders.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An internal employee with excessive privileges intentionally exports sensitive procurement data and shares it with unauthorized third parties.
  • An external attacker compromises a privileged account via a phishing attack and uses the access to modify supplier contracts, leading to fraudulent transactions.
  • A contractor retains elevated access after their role changes, exploiting misconfigured role-based controls to alter system settings and disrupt procurement workflows.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Anonymous users could gain access to sensitive data
threat.desc:
General threat description
This threat arises when SAP Ariba fails to enforce proper authentication and access controls, allowing unauthenticated or anonymous users to access sensitive procurement or supplier data. Without proper restrictions, any user—even one without verified credentials—may exploit vulnerabilities or misconfigurations to retrieve confidential information.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include external hackers and opportunistic cybercriminals who target misconfigured public endpoints or APIs. Attack vectors often involve exploiting weak authentication mechanisms, bypassing missing access controls, and using automated tools to scan for open or improperly secured data access points.

Impacts
If exploited, this threat can lead to unauthorized disclosure of confidential business data, compromise of sensitive supplier or procurement information, financial losses, and reputational damage. Additionally, regulatory non-compliance may result from breaches of data protection standards.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An attacker identifies an open API endpoint in SAP Ariba that lacks proper authentication and extracts sensitive procurement data without needing to provide any credentials.
  • A cybercriminal uses automated tools to scan for unsecured interfaces and finds that anonymous access is allowed, leading to the mass exfiltration of confidential supplier information.
  • An external user exploits misconfigured access controls on a public-facing SAP Ariba portal, bypassing authentication and downloading sensitive strategic sourcing documents.

threat.name: Attackers could gain access to sensitive data through a man in the middle attack
threat.desc:
General threat description
This threat involves adversaries positioning themselves between legitimate communication endpoints within the SAP Ariba environment to intercept, alter, or eavesdrop on data in transit. Without robust encryption and secure communication channels, sensitive information such as credentials, financial records, and confidential business data may be exposed to attackers who can capture and manipulate the data without detection.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include external cybercriminals, state-sponsored actors, and opportunistic hackers. Common attack vectors include ARP poisoning, DNS spoofing, exploiting misconfigured or outdated SSL/TLS settings, and compromising network devices to insert themselves into the communication path between SAP Ariba clients and servers.

Impacts
If successful, a man in the middle attack can lead to unauthorized disclosure and manipulation of sensitive data, resulting in financial losses, reputational damage, regulatory non-compliance, and overall disruption of business operations. Additionally, intercepted credentials can enable further exploitation and deeper penetration into the system.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An attacker on an unsecured public network uses ARP poisoning to intercept communication between a supplier’s SAP Ariba client and the server, capturing login credentials and transactional data.
  • A cybercriminal exploits misconfigured TLS settings to perform DNS spoofing, redirecting traffic through a rogue server where sensitive procurement data is intercepted and potentially altered.
  • A state-sponsored actor compromises a network router, inserting themselves into the data flow between SAP Ariba endpoints, decrypting sensitive information transmitted during critical business transactions.

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Attackers gain access to user accounts by exploiting flaws in the authentication function
threat.desc:
General threat description
This threat involves adversaries exploiting vulnerabilities in the authentication mechanisms of SAP Ariba. Weaknesses such as improper input validation, weak password policies, lack of multi-factor authentication, and insecure storage or transmission of credentials allow attackers to bypass login controls and gain unauthorized access to user accounts.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include external hackers, organized cybercriminal groups, and malicious insiders. Attack vectors involve brute force attacks, credential stuffing, injection of malicious code into authentication routines, and interception of credentials through phishing or network eavesdropping.

Impacts
If attackers succeed, they can compromise sensitive procurement and supplier data, manipulate transactional records, and perform unauthorized activities under the guise of legitimate users. This can result in financial losses, reputational damage, regulatory non-compliance, and further exploitation of the system through lateral movement.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An attacker deploys an automated brute force tool to repeatedly attempt logins on the SAP Ariba interface, eventually compromising accounts with weak or default passwords.
  • A cybercriminal exploits an injection flaw in the authentication function, allowing them to bypass login checks and gain administrative access to user accounts.
  • A malicious insider leverages deficiencies in the authentication process to access high-privilege accounts, subsequently altering procurement data and exfiltrating confidential information.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Attackers gain unauthorised access through malicious file upload
threat.desc:
General threat description
This threat involves adversaries uploading malicious files to the SAP Ariba system, exploiting vulnerabilities in the file upload functionality to bypass security controls. By injecting files containing harmful scripts or executables, attackers can trigger unintended actions, gain unauthorised access, or compromise sensitive data within the system.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include external hackers, cybercriminals, and opportunistic attackers. Common attack vectors involve exploiting insufficient file validation mechanisms, uploading files with disguised extensions, or leveraging vulnerabilities in the file handling process to execute malicious code on the server.

Impacts
If successful, this attack can lead to unauthorised access to sensitive data, execution of arbitrary code, and system compromise. The consequences may include data breaches, disruption of business operations, financial loss, and damage to the organization’s reputation.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An attacker uploads a file containing embedded malicious code that is not properly validated by the system, triggering unauthorized access to critical application functions.
  • A cybercriminal disguises a malicious executable as a harmless document, uploads it through a weak file upload control, and gains access to sensitive procurement data after executing the file.
  • An opportunistic hacker exploits a vulnerability in the file upload mechanism to inject a backdoor, which is later used to escalate privileges and extract confidential supplier information.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-434
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-434: Unrestricted Upload of File with Dangerous Type The product allows the attacker to upload or transfer files of dangerous types that can be automatically processed within the product's environment.

weakness.name: CWE-521
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-521: Weak Password Requirements The product does not require that users should have strong passwords, which makes it easier for attackers to compromise user accounts. Authentication mechanisms often rely on a memorized secret (also known as a password) to provide an assertion of identity for a user of a system. It is therefore important that this password be of sufficient complexity and impractical for an adversary to guess. The specific requirements around how complex a password needs to be depends on the type of system being protected. Selecting the correct password requirements and enforcing them through implementation are critical to the overall success of the authentication mechanism.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

countermeasure.name: Configure firewalls for SAP BOBJ
countermeasure.desc:
Configuring the BI platform to work in a firewalled environment is crucial for maintaining secure communication between components and ensuring the platform's availability and integrity. Firewalls act as a barrier to unauthorized network traffic and can help protect against external threats. By properly configuring the BI platform for firewalls, the system can operate smoothly while adhering to security requirements and minimizing the risk of unauthorized access or data breaches.

Remediation:
To configure the BI platform for firewalls, follow these steps:

1. Determine which BI platform components need to communicate across the firewall.
2. Manually configure the request port for each BI platform server that requires communication across the firewall.
3. Configure a port range for job server children that need to communicate across the firewall by adding the "-requestJSChildPorts" - and "-requestPort" parameters to the server's command line.
4. Configure the firewall to allow communication to the request ports and job server port range on the BI platform servers configured in the previous steps.
5. (Optional) If Network Address Translation (NAT) is enabled on the firewall, configure the hosts file on each machine hosting a BI platform server that needs to communicate across the firewall.

References:

  • SAP BusinessObjects Business Intelligence Platform: Configure the hosts file for firewalls that use NAT
  • SAP BusinessObjects Business Intelligence Platform: Configuring the BI platform for firewalls
  • SAP BusinessObjects Business Intelligence Platform: Debugging a firewalled deployment
  • SAP BusinessObjects Business Intelligence Platform: Specifying the firewall rules

countermeasure.name: Configure SSL for SAP BOBJ backend servers
countermeasure.desc:
Enabling SSL (Secure Sockets Layer) for backend servers in a BI platform deployment is crucial to establish secure communication between BI clients and BI servers. By implementing SSL, the confidentiality, integrity, and authenticity of data transmitted between the clients and servers can be ensured, mitigating the risk of unauthorized access, tampering, and data breaches. Configuring SSL provides a strong security foundation and builds trust with users, enhancing the overall security posture of the BI platform.

Remediation:
To configure backend servers for SSL in the BI platform, follow these steps:

1. Deploy the BI platform with SSL enabled to ensure secure communication across the network.
2. Generate or obtain the required key and certificate files for each machine involved in the deployment.
3. Configure the Central Configuration Manager (CCM) and the web application server to specify the location of these key and certificate files.
4. If applicable, configure SSL for thick clients (e.g., Crystal Reports) connecting to the CMS to avoid errors when attempting to connect to an SSL-configured CMS from a non-configured thick client.

References:

  • SAP BusinessObjects Business Intelligence Platform: Configuring backend servers for SSL

countermeasure.name: Enable virus scan for SAP BOBJ
countermeasure.desc:
Enabling virus scan for files committed to the BI platform's input and output file repository servers is crucial to enhance the security of the platform. Virus scanning helps detect and prevent the spread of malicious content or infected files, reducing the risk of malware infections and potential compromise of the BI platform. By implementing virus scan capabilities, the integrity and safety of the files stored and accessed within the platform can be maintained, ensuring a secure environment for data handling and processing.

Remediation:
To enable virus scan for the BI platform's input and output file repository servers, follow these steps:

1. Download the Virus Scan Adapter (VSA) library from an SAP certified vendor.
2. Log on to the Central Management Console (CMC).
3. Navigate to Servers -> Servers List.
4. Right-click on the input file repository server and select "Properties" from the dropdown menu to open the Properties window.
5. In the "Input Filestore Service" section, select the "Enable Virus Scan" checkbox.
6. In the "Virus Scan Adapter File Location" field, enter the absolute path to the virus scan adapter library file.
7. Click "Save & Close" to apply the changes.

Note: By default, virus scan is disabled for all files committed to the BI platform in BI 4.2 SP4. Virus scan can be enabled using either the GUI or CLI. The command line argument required for enabling virus scan on the file repository servers is "vsaFileLoc". It is important to enable virus scan on each input and output file repository server if multiple servers are being used. After enabling virus scan, restart the file repository servers to ensure the changes take effect.

References:

  • SAP BusinessObjects Business Intelligence Platform: Enabling Virus Scan
  • SAP Certified Vendors for Virus Scan

ID.SC-2: Suppliers and third party partners of information systems, components, and services are identified, prioritized, and assessed using a cyber supply chain risk assessment process

countermeasure.name: Implement environment protection for SAP BOBJ
countermeasure.desc:
No matter how secure a system is, there is often at least one location that is vulnerable to attack: the location where users connect to the system. It is nearly impossible to protect this location completely, because the process of simply guessing a valid user name and password remains a viable way to attempt to "crack" the system. The BI platform implements several techniques to reduce the probability of a malicious user achieving access to the system. The various restrictions listed below apply only to Enterprise accounts--that is, the restrictions do not apply to accounts that you have mapped to an external user database (LDAP or Windows AD). Generally, however, your external system will enable you to place similar restrictions on the external accounts.

Remediation:
To Protect against malicious logo attempts, follow these steps:

1. Password restrictions ensure that users authenticating the default Enterprise authentication create passwords that are relatively complex. You can enable the following options:
- Enforce mixed-case passwords
This option ensures that passwords contain at least one upper-case and one lower-case character in the password.
- Enforce numeral(s) passwords
This option ensures that passwords contain at least one numeric character.
- Enforce special character passwords
This option ensures that passwords contain at least one special character.
2. Logon restrictions serve primarily to prevent dictionary attacks (a method whereby a malicious user obtains a valid user name and attempts to learn the corresponding password by trying every word in a dictionary). With the speed of modern hardware, malicious programs can guess millions of passwords per minute. To prevent dictionary attacks, the BI platform has an internal mechanism that enforces a time delay (0.5-1.0 second) between logon attempts. In addition, the platform provides several customizable options that you can use to reduce the risk of a dictionary attack:
- Disable accounts after N failed attempts to log on
- Reset failed logon count after N minute(s)
- Re-enable account after N minute(s)
3. User restrictions ensure that users authenticating the default Enterprise authentication create new passwords on a regular basis. You can enable the following options:
- Must change password every N day(s)
- Cannot reuse the N most recent password(s)
- Must wait N minute(s) to change password
4. Disable the Guest account entirely.

References:

  • Guest account restrictions
  • Logon restrictions
  • Password restrictions
  • Protection against malicious logon attempts

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Attackers try to take advantage of a wide attack surface
threat.desc:
General threat description
This threat involves adversaries exploiting the numerous exposed endpoints, misconfigured services, and unpatched vulnerabilities present within the SAP BOBJ environment. A wide attack surface increases the risk that attackers will find and exploit weaknesses to gain unauthorized access or disrupt business intelligence operations.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include external hackers, cybercriminals, and automated vulnerability scanners. They may use techniques such as port scanning, probing for misconfigurations, exploiting unpatched software, or targeting default configurations to identify weak points in the SAP BOBJ system.

Impacts
If attackers successfully exploit a wide attack surface, the organization could face data breaches, unauthorized system access, and disruption of critical reporting functions. This may result in financial losses, reputational damage, and non-compliance with regulatory requirements.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An attacker uses automated scanning tools to detect open ports and discovers an unpatched service running on SAP BOBJ, which is then exploited to access sensitive data.
  • A cybercriminal identifies a misconfigured administrative interface exposed to the internet and leverages it to gain unauthorized control over the system.
  • Multiple vulnerabilities are exploited in concert, allowing an attacker to bypass security controls and infiltrate various components of SAP BOBJ, ultimately compromising the entire business intelligence platform.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Dictionary-based or brute force password attack
threat.desc:
General threat description
This threat involves adversaries using automated tools to systematically guess user passwords on the SAP BOBJ system. Attackers leverage lists of common words (dictionary attacks) or iterate through numerous character combinations (brute force attacks) to compromise accounts. Weak password policies, default credentials, or predictable password patterns increase the likelihood of a successful attack.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include external hackers, opportunistic cybercriminals, and script kiddies using automated password cracking tools. Common attack vectors involve leveraging dictionary lists of common passwords, brute force algorithms, and credential stuffing techniques to gain unauthorized access.

Impacts
If successful, these attacks can lead to unauthorized access to sensitive business intelligence data, system compromise, and potential lateral movement within the network. The consequences may include data breaches, financial loss, regulatory non-compliance, and reputational damage.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An attacker deploys an automated brute force tool against the SAP BOBJ login interface, eventually guessing weak or default passwords to gain administrative access.
  • A cybercriminal uses a dictionary attack with common password combinations to compromise user accounts, leading to unauthorized access to sensitive reports and data.
  • A script kiddie employs credential stuffing techniques using leaked passwords from other sources, successfully infiltrating the system due to inadequate password complexity.

threat.name: Reverse engineer an executable to expose assumed hidden functionality or content
threat.desc:
General threat description
This threat involves adversaries reverse engineering executables to uncover hidden or undocumented functionalities that are not intended for production use. Such hidden features may include debug interfaces, backdoors, or legacy code that can be exploited to bypass security controls or gain unauthorized access to the system. The process often reveals sensitive implementation details that can facilitate further attacks.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include skilled external attackers, state-sponsored groups, and knowledgeable insiders with reverse engineering expertise. Attack vectors involve using specialized tools such as disassemblers and decompilers (e.g., IDA Pro, Ghidra, OllyDbg) to analyze binary code. Attackers may also leverage static and dynamic analysis techniques to trace hidden code paths and discover undocumented functionalities.

Impacts
Successful exploitation can lead to unauthorized system access, bypassing of authentication or authorization controls, and manipulation of critical business functions. Additionally, exposure of proprietary code can result in intellectual property theft and compromise the overall integrity and confidentiality of the system, potentially leading to data breaches and operational disruptions.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An external attacker decompiles a SAP BusinessObjects executable to reveal a hidden administrative interface that bypasses authentication, allowing unauthorized access to sensitive reports.
  • A state-sponsored group employs dynamic analysis on a legacy component, discovering undocumented debug functions that can be used to manipulate system behavior and exfiltrate confidential data.
  • An insider uses reverse engineering techniques to extract proprietary business logic, subsequently exploiting the knowledge to facilitate fraud or unauthorized modifications to the system.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter

threat.name: Attackers could gain access to sensitive data through a man in the middle attack
threat.desc:
General threat description
This threat involves adversaries intercepting and potentially altering communications between SAP BOBJ endpoints. By positioning themselves between clients and SAP BusinessObjects servers, attackers can capture sensitive data and credentials in transit. Weak or misconfigured encryption, outdated SSL/TLS configurations, or compromised network infrastructure can enable such interception.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include external cybercriminals, state-sponsored hackers, and opportunistic attackers. They may employ techniques such as ARP poisoning, DNS spoofing, session hijacking, or exploitation of weak SSL/TLS configurations to position themselves between communicating parties.

Impacts
If successful, a man in the middle attack can lead to unauthorized disclosure and manipulation of sensitive business intelligence data. This may result in financial losses, reputational damage, regulatory non-compliance, and further system compromise by enabling lateral movement within the network.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An attacker exploits a misconfigured SSL/TLS setting in SAP BOBJ, intercepting data exchanged between a user's workstation and the server, and capturing confidential information such as login credentials and report data.
  • On an unsecured network, a cybercriminal uses ARP poisoning to intercept communications between SAP BOBJ endpoints, subsequently manipulating the data stream to alter critical business insights.
  • A state-sponsored actor uses DNS spoofing to redirect traffic destined for the SAP BusinessObjects server to a rogue server, enabling the interception and potential modification of sensitive data transmitted in clear text.

weakness.name: CWE-226
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-226: Sensitive Information in Resource Not Removed Before Reuse The product releases a resource such as memory or a file so that it can be made available for reuse, but it does not clear or "zeroize" the information contained in the resource before the product performs a critical state transition or makes the resource available for reuse by other entities.

weakness.name: CWE-266
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-266: Incorrect Privilege Assignment A product incorrectly assigns a privilege to a particular actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-521
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-521: Weak Password Requirements The product does not require that users should have strong passwords, which makes it easier for attackers to compromise user accounts. Authentication mechanisms often rely on a memorized secret (also known as a password) to provide an assertion of identity for a user of a system. It is therefore important that this password be of sufficient complexity and impractical for an adversary to guess. The specific requirements around how complex a password needs to be depends on the type of system being protected. Selecting the correct password requirements and enforcing them through implementation are critical to the overall success of the authentication mechanism.

weakness.name: CWE-522
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-522: Insufficiently Protected Credentials The product transmits or stores authentication credentials, but it uses an insecure method that is susceptible to unauthorized interception and/or retrieval.

weakness.name: CWE-613
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-613: Insufficient Session Expiration According to WASC, "Insufficient Session Expiration is when a web site permits an attacker to reuse old session credentials or session IDs for authorization."

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

countermeasure.name: Configure session and token invalidation for stale HTTP sessions and OAuth tokens in SAP Commerce
countermeasure.desc:
SAP Commerce supports user session and token invalidation to ensure that no stale HTTP sessions or OAuth tokens are used after a user password change.
When users change their passwords, all their HTTP sessions and OAuth tokens that were created using old credentials become stale. Stale sessions or tokens are a potential security threat. If a user's credentials were compromised, any stale sessions or tokens created with old credentials could still be valid and attackers could use them to act on behalf of the user.

Remediation:
Use the available configuration properties to invalidate stale HTTP sessions and revoke stale OAuth tokens by default. You can modify the default behaviour by adding the following properties to your local.properties file (Please refer to the link in References to see the table).

References:

  • User Session and Token Invalidation

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1043 - Credential Access Protection

countermeasure.name: Control access to SAP Commerce resources
countermeasure.desc:
Controlling access to SAP Commerce resources is crucial to maintain security and protect sensitive information. Unauthorized access can lead to data breaches and compromise the integrity of the SAP Commerce platform. Implementing access control measures, user types, and securing resources like cockpits and media files helps ensure that only authorized individuals have access to specific functionalities and data.

Remediation:
- System user 

  1. Limit access to the admin account to authorized personnel carrying out administrative roles within the organization. Avoid using the admin account for routine tasks or access by non-administrative users. 
  2. Be cautious when adding users to the "admingroup." Users added to this group inherit the same rights as the admin user. Only assign users to this group who genuinely require administrative privileges. 
  3. Safeguard information related to the admin account and "admingroup." Ensure that access to credentials, configuration details, and sensitive information associated with these accounts is restricted to authorized individuals. 
  4. Implement regular auditing and monitoring of system accounts, especially the admin account and "admingroup," to detect any unauthorized access or suspicious activities promptly.

- User type 

  1. You should use the user type to create more specific types that define accounts for your employees and customers. It is possible to create an item of a user type, but it should be avoided. Items of user type will have another permission hierarchy than items with type employee or customer and there will be no possibility to distinguish the role played by the items. SAP recommends that you use the user type only in order to create more specific types that define accounts for employees, customers, or other more specific roles that need to be mapped in the organization hierarchy. 
  2. Customers are not allowed to manage SAP Commerce. It is technically possible to grant a customer account access to the SAP Commerce management tools. However this is not recommended and should not be allowed. SAP Commerce has one default customer: anonymous. Create other customers as needed. You can either let customers create their own account through the front-end application, or you can do it yourself, manually or by using the ImpEx script to automate the process. 
  3. You can create other employee users later as the need arises, manually or by using ImpEx scripts. By installing new cockpits, you also receive some factory default users that come together with particular cockpit extensions. There are several factory default employee accounts that come with the SAP Commerce system.
    Change the credentials for all default accounts during the implementation phase, or these accounts will be disabled.

- Cockpits
The cockpit spring configuration enforces this through the defaultCorePreAuthenticationChecks bean, defined in cockpit-spring-security.xml:
Admingroup Employeegroup Employee 

- Media 

  • Ensure that all media files containing personal data or sensitive information are placed in secured media folders. 
  • Validate the configuration to confirm that permissions are correctly set up for media access. Permissions can be granted on media objects, media types, and globally. 
  • In scenarios where only specific principals (users or user groups) should have access to specific media, ensure that permissions granted on the type level are overridden. Assign positive read permissions to the specific principal(s) who should access the media. 
  • Conduct regular reviews of media access permissions to ensure that only authorized individuals and groups have access to sensitive media files.

References:

  • Authorization

countermeasure.name: Delete the password from local.properties after you initialize the system in SAP Commerce
countermeasure.desc:
When you initialize the system for the first time, the password is loaded into the database. You can change it later using the Backoffice Administration Cockpit. Delete the password from local.properties after you initialize the system to protect it against unauthorized access.

Remediation:
1. Navigate to hybris/config 
2. Delete the local.properties file.

countermeasure.name: Disable all default passwords for users in SAP Commerce
countermeasure.desc:
If you have been using essential, project, and sample data with users that have default passwords, it is possible you may still have some of those passwords in your system. To improve security, you can use the following procedure to check whether you have any default passwords defined, and then replace them with more secure passwords. All default passwords get replaced with randomized, secure alternatives, and login for any non-administrative users that previously had default passwords is disabled. Carrying out these steps helps strengthen your system against unauthorized access.

Remediation: 

1. Download the Groovy scripts package from SAP Note 2922193, and unzip the file. 

2. Log in to Administration Console. 

3. Go to Console > Scripting Languages Console > Edit Statement. 

4. Change Script Type to groovy. 

5. Copy the password_check.groovy script to the editor area. 

6. Click Execute. The Result tab opens and displays a report. The report lists users with default or common passwords. Note: The report points out that you can't disable administrator users. You can, however, set random passwords for them. For better security, SAP recommends setting administrator passwords manually. 

7. Go to Edit Statement. 

8. Copy the password_randomize.groovy script to the editor area. 

9. Switch the toggle bar to Commit. 

10. Click Execute.

References:

  • Disabling All Default Passwords for Users

standard.ref: PR.AC-1: Identities and credentials are issued, managed, verified, revoked, and audited for authorized devices, users and processes

PR.AC-7: Users, devices, and other assets are authenticated (e.g., single-factor, multi-factor) commensurate with the risk of the transaction (e.g., individuals' security and privacy risks and other organizational risks)

countermeasure.name: Follow authentication best practices for SAP Commerce
countermeasure.desc:
Securing user accounts and passwords is paramount to protecting sensitive information and preventing unauthorized access. Implementing a set of best practices helps safeguard user credentials and maintain the integrity of the system.

Remediation: 

- Implement a CAPTCHA or RECAPTCHA to block automated attacks. Users tend to use the same email address and password combination for multiple locations. Attackers try these combinations using automated password-guessing tools on different websites and CAPTCHAS protect against these automated attempts. 

- Make sure that the password reset function does not reveal whether an account exists as it could expose usernames or emails. Use "Invalid username and/or password" as a failure response rather than indicating which part of the authentication data is incorrect. 

- Use a second factor authentication method. This is one of the most effective measures to block brute force or harvesting attacks. The implementation of two-factor authentication could impact your business process. For administrative accounts available from web components, always use Multi-Factor Authentication. 

- Lock the account after a specified number of failed login attempts. For example, lock the account for 30 minutes after three failed attempts. While a locked-out user cannot log in until the account resets, account lockout protects against automated attacks. 

- Use the password change auditing and password security policies to set a password history policy, which prevents users from reusing a set number of recently used passwords. A password history policy minimizes the risk if an old password is compromised. 

- Implement a password minimum age policy along with the password history policy. A password minimum age policy prevents users from bypassing the password history policy by changing a password multiple times to continue using a preferred password. Set the password minimum age to 24 hours. 

- Set the password maximum age to 3-6 months. When passwords reach the maximum age, users must create a new password. 

- Use only POST requests for log-in forms. A POST request sends user-supplied credentials in the body of the HTTP message. Conversely, a GET request, sends credentials in a URL, which introduces an attack vector. 

- Introduce context-based access control, for example only through the corporate network or a properly configured VPN to prevent and detect denial-of-service attacks. 

- Implement secure failure of authentication controls. 

- Implement redirections from and to the central authentication control, which must be separated from the requested resource. 

- Store only salted hashes. Salted password hashing makes finding user passwords from hashed data more difficult. 

- Do not use autocomplete for passwords. 

- Use HTTPS to implement secure protocols for processing logins and to transfer any personal or sensitive data. Attackers can acquire usernames and passwords from unencrypted data in transit.

References:

  • Useful Resources and Best Practices

countermeasure.name: Implement secure configurations in SAP Commerce
countermeasure.desc:
Configuring SAP Commerce securely is essential to protect your production environment from potential security vulnerabilities and breaches. Secure configuration practices help safeguard sensitive data, maintain system integrity, and reduce the risk of unauthorized access.

Remediation:

  • Prior to deploying SAP Commerce in production, ensure that the configuration on each of the following is secure:
  • Review Installed Extensions
  • Tenant Settings
  • Secure Backoffice Extensions
  • Application Server User
  • Database User Settings
  • Sample SSL Certificates for Developer Environments
  • Solr
  • FlexibleSearch
  • Transparent Attribute Encryption (TAE)
  • Output Encoding
  • Encoding Libraries
  • Input Validation
  • OWASP Java HTML Sanitizer
  • jsoup
  • OWASP JSON Sanitizer
  • CSRF Protection
  • Clickjacking Protection
  • JMX Settings
  • Tomcat
  • Browser Cache
  • Basic Authentication for POP3 Protocol in Microsoft Exchange Online

References:

  • Secure configuration

countermeasure.name: Implement strong password policy in SAP Commerce
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing a strong password policy is essential to enhance the security of SAP Commerce. A robust password policy helps safeguard user accounts against unauthorized access and reduces the risk of password-related security incidents. By enforcing specific requirements for password complexity and ensuring that passwords do not contain easily guessable information, the system becomes more resilient to password-based attacks.

Remediation:
Implement a password policy that includes the following minimal requirements: 

- Passwords must include: 

  • both uppercase and lowercase letters 
  • one or more numerical digits 
  • one or more special characters 
  • at least 8 total characters 

- Passwords must not include: 

  • words found in a dictionary 
  • the user's personal information 
  • text that matches the format of calendar dates, phone numbers, license plate numbers, or other common numbers.

References:

  • Password Policies

countermeasure.name: Regularly run a flex search query to find users with vulnerable passwords and passwords in clear text in SAP Commerce
countermeasure.desc:
Regularly running a flex search query to identify users with vulnerable passwords and clear text passwords is crucial for maintaining strong security in the SAP Commerce system. In cases where a previous encoding strategy was deemed unsafe, it is essential to identify and address all users with potentially compromised passwords. This ensures that no user is using a vulnerable or clear text password, strengthening the system's overall security.

Remediation:
Changing the default strategy this way preserves previously stored passwords (using the default strategy) so that the user can still log in. In cases where the previous strategy was considered to be unsafe, all of the previous passwords remain unsafe. Run a flex search query to find users with vulnerable passwords and passwords in clear text, then change its encoding. Following is an example how to perform that:
$passwordEncoding=sha-256
$defaultPassword=697AkzWKEkgS8Aqj9z1g
$setPassword=@password[translator=de.hybris.platform.impex.jalo.translators.ConvertPlaintextToEncodedUserPasswordTranslator][default='$passwordEncoding:$defaultPassword']
INSERT_UPDATE Employee;UID[unique=true];$setPassword; ;admin; ;cmsmanager; ;cmsmanager; ;csagent; ;productmanager;

References:

  • Password Encoding

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1036 - Account Use Policies

countermeasure.name: Secure or remove unsecured components prior to moving into production in SAP Commerce
countermeasure.desc:
Unsecured components in SAP Commerce pose potential security risks that can lead to vulnerabilities, exploits, and unauthorized access. It is essential to implement measures to secure or remove these components before moving into a production environment.

Remediation:
- Test and Debug Pages 

  1. Ensure that test and debug pages, such as "debugFooter.tag," are disabled in a production environment. 
  2. Examine the source code and configurations to identify and remove any debug elements, code, or comments that may expose sensitive information or vulnerabilities. 
  3. Implement best practices for code quality and security to prevent the inclusion of debug elements in production code.

- Mocks 

  1. Do not use mocks in a production environment. Replace them with production-ready components that are designed for security and reliability. 
  2. Identify all instances of mocks within your SAP Commerce implementation and replace them with appropriate production components or functionality.

- Templates 

  1. During the implementation phase, validate and secure extensions generated from SAP Commerce templates. Ensure that security considerations are taken into account when planning, designing, and implementing custom extensions. 
  2. Adhere to security best practices while developing custom extensions based on templates. Implement necessary security measures to protect against common vulnerabilities. 
  3. Review the structure of extensions created from templates and identify any security gaps. Address these gaps to mitigate potential vulnerabilities.

References:

  • Unsecure Components
