usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Privilege abuse
threat.desc:
General threat description
This threat involves adversaries misusing elevated privileges or abusing assigned roles within SAP Commerce. When users have more access than necessary or when access controls are misconfigured, attackers or negligent insiders can manipulate system configurations, access sensitive data, or perform unauthorized actions, compromising the integrity and security of the commerce platform.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include malicious insiders, compromised user accounts, and external attackers who gain elevated privileges through phishing, social engineering, or exploitation of misconfigured role-based access controls. Attack vectors include exploiting default or excessive permissions, bypassing proper access restrictions, and using privilege escalation techniques to extend access beyond authorized boundaries.

Impacts
Exploitation of privilege abuse can lead to unauthorized data access, manipulation of critical business functions, and disruption of operations. Potential impacts include data breaches, financial losses, non-compliance with regulatory requirements, and damage to the organization's reputation.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An employee with excessive administrative rights intentionally accesses confidential pricing or supplier data and misuses it for personal gain or competitive advantage.
  • An external attacker compromises a user account with elevated privileges due to misconfigured role assignments and exfiltrates sensitive customer information.
  • A malicious insider leverages their broad access to alter system settings, resulting in unauthorized transactions that disrupt business operations and cause financial loss.

threat.name: Attackers gain access to the system by exploiting weak security configurations
threat.desc:
General threat description
This threat involves adversaries exploiting misconfigured security settings, default configurations, or poorly implemented security controls within SAP Commerce. Without proper hardening and secure configuration, the platform remains vulnerable to unauthorized access, allowing attackers to bypass authentication, gain elevated privileges, and potentially modify or exfiltrate sensitive data.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include external hackers, opportunistic cybercriminals, and malicious insiders. They may use automated scanning tools to identify systems with weak security configurations, exploit default credentials, take advantage of unpatched vulnerabilities, or manipulate misconfigured firewall and access control settings to gain unauthorized entry.

Impacts
Successful exploitation can lead to unauthorized access to critical business data, manipulation or theft of intellectual property, and disruption of commerce operations. Consequences include data breaches, financial losses, reputational damage, and potential regulatory penalties due to non-compliance with security standards.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An attacker uses an automated vulnerability scanner to detect SAP Commerce systems that have not been properly hardened, then exploits default credentials and misconfigured firewall rules to gain administrative access.
  • A cybercriminal leverages a known misconfiguration in the authentication mechanism to bypass security controls and execute unauthorized transactions or data exfiltration.
  • A malicious insider exploits lax access control settings and default configurations to escalate privileges, subsequently accessing and modifying sensitive system configurations and business data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Dictionary-based or brute force password attack
threat.desc:
General threat description
This threat involves adversaries using automated tools to systematically guess user passwords. In a dictionary-based attack, common words or phrases are used, while in a brute force attack, every possible combination of characters is attempted until the correct password is discovered. Weak password policies, default credentials, or predictable patterns increase the likelihood of a successful attack.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include external hackers, script kiddies, and cybercriminals. They typically use automated password-cracking tools, employ dictionary lists of common passwords, or execute brute force algorithms to rapidly test potential passwords against authentication systems.

Impacts
If successful, these attacks can lead to unauthorized access to user accounts and sensitive data. This may result in data breaches, unauthorized modifications of system settings, further lateral movement within the network, financial losses, and reputational damage.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An attacker deploys an automated tool to test a list of common passwords against a login portal, eventually gaining access to an account with weak credentials.
  • A cybercriminal uses a brute force method to systematically try every possible combination for a short password, eventually compromising an administrative account.
  • A script kiddie utilizes credential stuffing with a dictionary of leaked passwords, successfully accessing user accounts that use predictable password patterns.

threat.name: Attackers perform an exhaustive (brute force) search on the key space to determine the key that decrypts the cipher text
threat.desc:
General threat description
This threat involves adversaries using brute force techniques to systematically try every possible key in the encryption algorithm’s key space until the correct one is found, thereby decrypting the cipher text and obtaining the plaintext. This method is particularly effective against weak encryption schemes or when the key length is insufficient, exposing sensitive data to unauthorized decryption.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include external hackers, organized cybercriminal groups, state-sponsored actors, and other adversaries with access to high-performance computing resources (e.g., GPUs, distributed systems). Attack vectors involve using automated tools to perform exhaustive key searches, leveraging distributed computing to reduce the time required for the search, and targeting systems that employ weak encryption parameters.

Impacts
If successful, this attack can lead to the decryption of sensitive data, resulting in data breaches, loss of confidentiality, regulatory non-compliance, financial losses, and reputational damage. The compromise of encrypted information can also serve as a springboard for further attacks and exploitation of other systems.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An attacker intercepts encrypted communications from a target system and uses a brute force algorithm, distributed across multiple servers, to test every possible key until the correct one decrypts the message, exposing confidential information.
  • A cybercriminal leverages cloud-based computing resources to launch a brute force attack on an encrypted backup file secured with a short key length, eventually decrypting the file and accessing sensitive business data.
  • A state-sponsored actor utilizes specialized hardware to conduct an exhaustive search on encrypted data transmitted over a network, successfully obtaining the plaintext and compromising critical information.

threat.name: An attacker examines a target system to find sensitive data that has been embedded within it
threat.desc:
General threat description
This threat involves adversaries systematically inspecting a target system to uncover sensitive data that has been inadvertently or intentionally embedded within its files, configurations, or metadata. Such data may include hardcoded credentials, API keys, or confidential business information that were not properly secured.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include external hackers, cybercriminals, and state-sponsored actors. They often use a combination of automated tools (e.g., file scanners, forensic utilities) and manual analysis to probe for hidden or embedded information within system files, logs, and configuration data.

Impacts
Successful exploitation can lead to unauthorized access to sensitive information, enabling further compromise of the system. The exposure of embedded data may facilitate lateral movement, escalation of privileges, data breaches, and potential financial and reputational damage.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An attacker employs forensic tools to scan configuration files and discovers embedded credentials that allow access to critical system components.
  • A cybercriminal uses reverse engineering techniques on legacy applications, uncovering hardcoded secrets that enable unauthorized API access.
  • Automated file scanning reveals sensitive data embedded within log files or metadata, which is then exfiltrated and used to launch further attacks.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1063 - Security Software Discovery

threat.name: Attackers gain access to unauthorised data by exploiting vulnerabilities in the service
threat.desc:
General threat description
This threat involves adversaries identifying and exploiting security vulnerabilities within the SAP Commerce service to bypass access controls and retrieve sensitive data. Weaknesses such as unpatched software, misconfigured settings, or inadequate input validation can allow attackers to compromise the system and access confidential information without proper authorisation.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include external hackers, cybercriminals, and malicious insiders. Attack vectors may involve using automated vulnerability scanners to detect known exploits, performing SQL injection or API exploitation, and leveraging cross-site scripting (XSS) or remote code execution (RCE) vulnerabilities to infiltrate the service.

Impacts
Exploitation of these vulnerabilities can lead to significant data breaches, financial losses, regulatory fines, and damage to the organization’s reputation. Unauthorized access may expose customer data, intellectual property, or sensitive operational information, potentially resulting in further system compromise and business disruption.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An attacker exploits a SQL injection vulnerability in a public-facing API of SAP Commerce to access and extract sensitive customer records from the database.
  • A cybercriminal leverages an unpatched vulnerability in an authentication endpoint, bypassing security measures and gaining access to confidential business data.
  • A malicious insider uses automated tools to identify and exploit misconfigurations in the service, retrieving sensitive operational data without detection.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1069 - Permission Groups Discovery

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: An attacker reuses a valid session ID to spoof the target system in order to gain privileges
threat.desc:
General threat description
This threat involves adversaries leveraging a previously issued, valid session ID to impersonate an authorized user. By reusing the session ID, attackers can bypass authentication checks and gain elevated privileges, effectively spoofing the target system. The threat is exacerbated by inadequate session management practices such as weak session expiration policies or predictable session identifiers.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include external hackers, cybercriminals, and malicious insiders. Attack vectors may involve intercepting session IDs through network eavesdropping, session hijacking, or exploiting vulnerabilities in the application’s session management mechanisms. Attackers might also use social engineering or malware to capture active session tokens.

Impacts
Exploitation of this vulnerability can lead to unauthorized access to sensitive information, manipulation of critical data, and execution of privileged operations. The misuse of a valid session ID can result in data breaches, financial losses, and significant reputational damage, as well as potential regulatory consequences.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An attacker intercepts a session ID over an unsecured Wi-Fi network and reuses it to access an administrative panel, thereby gaining control over system configurations.
  • A cybercriminal exploits a flaw in session management to prolong the validity of a session ID, later using it to impersonate a high-privilege user and perform unauthorized transactions.
  • A malicious insider obtains a colleague’s session token via phishing and uses it to access restricted data, evading detection by mimicking legitimate user activity.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1135 - Network Share Discovery

threat.name: Attackers gain access to user accounts by exploiting flaws in the authentication function
threat.desc:
General threat description
This threat involves adversaries exploiting vulnerabilities within the authentication mechanisms of SAP Commerce to bypass login procedures and gain unauthorized access to user accounts. Flaws in input validation, token generation, or password handling can allow attackers to impersonate legitimate users without proper credentials.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include external hackers, cybercriminals, and malicious insiders. Attack vectors may involve brute force attacks, credential stuffing, injection attacks (such as SQL injection) to bypass authentication, and session hijacking. Additionally, attackers might exploit logic errors in the authentication process or use social engineering to obtain valid credentials.

Impacts
If successful, attackers can access sensitive data, modify or exfiltrate critical business information, and potentially escalate privileges to compromise additional systems. This breach can lead to financial loss, reputational damage, regulatory non-compliance, and increased vulnerability to subsequent attacks.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An attacker leverages a SQL injection vulnerability in the login form to bypass authentication checks and gain access to user accounts with elevated privileges.
  • A cybercriminal uses credential stuffing with leaked credentials to access user accounts, exploiting the absence of multi-factor authentication.
  • An insider exploits a flaw in the token management system to reuse valid authentication tokens, maintaining persistent access to sensitive areas of the system without re-authenticating.

threat.name: Attackers gain access to the system using default passwords
threat.desc:
General threat description
This threat involves adversaries exploiting systems that continue to use default passwords, which are commonly set during initial installation or configuration. If these default credentials are not changed, attackers can easily gain unauthorized access to the system, bypassing authentication mechanisms without needing advanced skills or tools.

Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include opportunistic hackers, script kiddies, and malicious insiders. Attack vectors typically involve automated scanning tools that search for systems with known default credentials, along with manual testing of default username-password combinations documented in vendor guidelines.

Impacts
Exploitation of default passwords can lead to unauthorized system access, data breaches, and manipulation of critical business information. This may result in financial losses, reputational damage, regulatory non-compliance, and enable further lateral movement within the network.

Example Attack Scenarios

  • An attacker uses automated tools to scan for SAP Commerce instances still running with default credentials and gains administrative access to modify system settings or extract sensitive data.
  • A script kiddie manually tests a list of default username-password pairs on a public-facing SAP Commerce server, eventually compromising the system and causing data leakage.
  • A malicious insider takes advantage of unchanged default credentials to access restricted areas of the system, exfiltrating confidential information and bypassing normal security controls.

weakness.name: CWE-250
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-250: Execution with Unnecessary Privileges The product performs an operation at a privilege level that is higher than the minimum level required, which creates new weaknesses or amplifies the consequences of other weaknesses.

weakness.name: CWE-259
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-259: Use of Hard-coded Password The product contains a hard-coded password, which it uses for its own inbound authentication or for outbound communication to external components.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-346
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-346: Origin Validation Error The product does not properly verify that the source of data or communication is valid.

weakness.name: CWE-706
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-706: Use of Incorrectly-Resolved Name or Reference The product uses a name or reference to access a resource, but the name/reference resolves to a resource that is outside of the intended control sphere.

countermeasure.name: Enhance default account security for SAP Concur
countermeasure.desc:
Default accounts in SAP Concur can pose security risks if left enabled or unchanged. To bolster overall account security, it is crucial to implement measures that disable or delete unnecessary default accounts and ensure that accounts are properly managed throughout their lifecycle.

Remediation:
1. Disable or Delete Unnecessary Default Accounts:

Review the default accounts provided by SAP Concur and assess their necessity for your organization's specific use case. 

Disable or delete any default accounts that are not required, reducing potential attack vectors for malicious actors.

2. Account Lifecycle Management:

Establish a dedicated process to periodically review and manage user accounts. 

Regularly identify and deactivate accounts of inactive users or those with changed responsibilities. This helps maintain an accurate and up-to-date account roster.
3. Least Privilege Principle:

Implement the principle of least privilege for all accounts, including default accounts. Restrict privileges to the minimum necessary for their intended function. Avoid granting unnecessary administrative rights, which can reduce the impact of potential security breaches.
4. Security Education:
Conduct regular security awareness training to educate employees about the risks associated with default accounts. Emphasize the importance of adhering to proper security practices, such as timely account deactivation, password management, and access control.

References:

  • SAP Concur Security Recommendations

standard.ref: DE.CM-1: The network is monitored to detect potential cybersecurity events
DE.CM-3: Personnel activity is monitored to detect potential cybersecurity events
DE.CM-7: Monitoring for unauthorized personnel, connections, devices, and software is performed
ID.AM-1: Physical devices and systems within the organization are inventoried
ID.AM-2: Software platforms and applications within the organization are inventoried
PR.DS-3: Assets are formally managed throughout removal, transfers, and disposition
PR.IP-1: A baseline configuration of information technology/industrial control systems is created and maintained incorporating security principles (e.g. concept of least functionality)
PR.IP-3: Configuration change control processes are in place
PR.PT-3: The principle of least functionality is incorporated by configuring systems to provide only essential capabilities
Requests to Limit Use and Disclosure of Sensitive Personal Information (m)(8)

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1018 - User Account Management

countermeasure.name: Implement best practice password security measures for SAP Concur accounts
countermeasure.desc:
Password security is a fundamental aspect of protecting SAP Concur accounts from unauthorized access and potential data breaches. By implementing best practices for password management, organizations can significantly reduce the risk of account compromise and enhance overall account security.

Remediation:
1. Unique and Strong Passwords:
Encourage users to create unique and strong passwords for each SAP Concur account. Utilize a combination of upper and lower-case letters, numbers, and special characters to increase complexity.
2. Password Sharing Avoidance:
Educate users on the importance of not sharing passwords with anyone, including support teams or colleagues. Emphasize the significance of individual ownership and responsibility for account security.
3. Avoid Easily Guessable Information:
Instruct users to avoid using easily guessable information such as names, birthdates, or common words in their passwords. Encourage the use of random combinations that are difficult to predict.
4. Security Awareness Training:
Conduct regular security awareness training to educate users about phishing attempts and how to identify and avoid them. Teach them to recognize phishing emails and fraudulent websites.
5. Change Default Credentials:
Prompt users to change default usernames and passwords immediately upon the installation or setup of SAP Concur accounts. Default credentials are commonly targeted by attackers.
6. Promote Password Managers:
Encourage the use of reputable password managers to help users securely store and manage their passwords. Password managers facilitate the use of unique, complex passwords without the need for memorization.
7. Utilize Single Sign-On (SSO):
Implement Single Sign-On (SSO) for SAP Concur accounts to streamline authentication and reduce the number of passwords users need to manage.
8. Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA):
For added security, enable Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) on top of SSO. MFA provides an extra layer of protection by requiring users to provide additional verification, such as a one-time code or biometric data, during login.

References:

  • SAP Concur Security Recommendations

standard.ref: PR.AC-1: Identities and credentials are issued, managed, verified, revoked, and audited for authorized devices, users and processes

PR.AC-7: Users, devices, and other assets are authenticated (e.g., single-factor, multi-factor) commensurate with the risk of the transaction (e.g., individuals' security and privacy risks and other organizational risks)

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1052 - User Account Control

countermeasure.name: Implement email authentication protocols for SAP Concur
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance email security and prevent unauthorized use of domains, SAP Concur supports Sender Policy Framework (SPF), DomainKeys Identified Mail (DKIM), and Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting & Conformance (DMARC). Implementing these email authentication protocols helps distinguish legitimate emails from forged ones, reduces phishing risks, and protects the organization's reputation.

Remediation:
1. SPF Implementation:
- Configure SPF records: SAP Concur can provide SPF records that list authorized IP addresses to send emails on behalf of your domains.
- Implement SPF checks: Set up SPF checks to verify incoming emails based on the email's origin and route taken.
2. DKIM Verification:
- Enable DKIM on outgoing emails: SAP Concur uses DKIM to add digital signatures to all outgoing emails.
- Implement DKIM verification: Configure DKIM verification at your end to validate email signatures successfully.
3. DMARC Implementation:
- Enable DMARC for domain protection: SAP Concur uses DMARC to prevent unauthorized use of their domains in email addresses.
- Implement DMARC verification: Set up DMARC verification alongside SPF and DKIM to specify how unauthenticated or suspicious messages should be handled by mailbox providers.

References:

  • SAP Concur Security Recommendations

standard.ref: DE.AE-1: A baseline of network operations and expected data flows for users and systems is established and managed
ID.AM-3: Organizational communication and data flows are mapped
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected
SC-16 Transmission of Security and Privacy Attributes

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1057 - Data Loss Prevention

countermeasure.name: Implement regular updates for devices accessing SAP Concur services
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure the security and integrity of devices accessing SAP Concur services, it is essential to keep their operating systems, applications, and firmware up-to-date. Regular updates address security vulnerabilities, patch known exploits, and enhance overall device performance, reducing the risk of potential cyber threats.

Remediation Steps:
1. Device Inventory and Monitoring:
- Maintain an inventory of all devices used to access SAP Concur services.
- Implement a monitoring system to track the status of operating systems, applications, and firmware on these devices.
2. Regular Security Updates:
- Set up automated updates: Configure devices to receive automatic updates for operating systems, applications, and firmware.
- Schedule regular updates: Establish a periodic update schedule for all devices to ensure timely application of security patches.
3. Test Updates before Deployment:
- Test updates in a controlled environment: Before deploying updates on production devices, perform testing in a controlled environment to ensure compatibility and identify potential issues.
4. Establish Patch Management Policy:
- Develop a comprehensive patch management policy: Create a policy that outlines the process for handling updates, including timelines, testing procedures, and rollback plans if necessary.
5. User Awareness and Training:
- Educate users about updates: Inform users about the importance of updating their devices and provide guidelines for installing updates promptly.

References:

  • SAP Concur Security Recommendations

standard.ref: SC-4 Information in Shared System Resources

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1033 - Limit Software Installation
SC-4 Information in Shared System Resources

countermeasure.name: Manage SSH keys for data exchange with SAP Concur
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure secure data exchange with SAP Concur, the use of SFTP with Username and SSH Key Authentication is recommended. Proper management of SSH keys is crucial to maintain a high level of security and protect sensitive information.

Remediation:
To implement a robust SFTP with SSH Key Authentication, follow these steps:

1. Generate RSA format keys: Create RSA format keys with a recommended key length of 2048 bits or higher to ensure strong encryption.
2. Establish key rotation policy: Set up a key rotation policy to rotate the SSH keys at least every 2 years or whenever there is a suspicion of compromise.

References:

  • SAP Concur Security Recommendations
  • Shared: AWS File  Transfer for New and  Migrated Clients and  Vendors

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1025 - Privileged Process Integrity

countermeasure.name: Use the most secure ciphers for SAP Concur integration
countermeasure.desc:
SAP Concur supports various encryption ciphers for data transfer to ensure secure communication between the client site and the SAP Concur servers. It is essential for customers to prioritize security and select the most secure ciphers to protect sensitive data during transmission.

Remediation:
1. Customer should review the list of supported ciphers by SAP Concur and ensure they are using the most secure ciphers available.
2. Allow customer file transfer software to automatically select the best cipher based on shared cipher support between the software and SAP Concur.

References:

  • SAP Concur Security Recommendations
  • Shared: AWS File  Transfer for New and  Migrated Clients and  Vendors

SC-16 Transmission of Security and Privacy Attributes

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Privilege abuse
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Privilege abuse occurs when users or accounts with elevated rights exploit their permissions to perform unauthorized actions. This can happen either intentionally or inadvertently, leading to unauthorized access to sensitive data or manipulation of system functions within SAP Concur.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Insider Threats: Employees or contractors who misuse legitimate access privileges for personal gain or malicious intent.
  • Compromised Accounts: Attackers gain control of privileged accounts through phishing or credential theft, then abuse these rights.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploiting misconfigured role-based access controls.
    • Leveraging shared or default credentials that provide unnecessary privileges.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to confidential financial, travel, or personal data.
  • Financial Loss: Misuse of privileges can lead to fraudulent transactions or expense manipulation.
  • Operational Disruption: Unapproved changes or data manipulation may interrupt normal business processes and result in compliance issues.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An employee uses elevated privileges to access sensitive financial records beyond their role, potentially selling the data for personal profit.
  2. An attacker gains access to a privileged account through phishing, then modifies system settings to cover their tracks or to enable further unauthorized actions.
  3. A user exploits a misconfigured role, accessing and altering expense reports to commit fraud.

threat.name: Attackers gain access to the system by exploiting weak security configurations
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Attackers exploit misconfigurations in SAP Concur—such as default credentials or exposed admin interfaces—to bypass security controls and gain unauthorized system access.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Use automated tools to find and exploit weak configurations.
  • Insider Threats: Legitimate users abusing misconfigured permissions.
  • Attack Vectors: Default credentials, exposed management interfaces, and insecure API endpoints.

Impacts

  • Data Breaches: Exposure of sensitive financial, travel, or personal data.
  • Financial Loss: Fraudulent manipulation of expense or travel data.
  • Operational Disruption: Interference with normal business processes and compliance violations.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker scans for vulnerable endpoints, finds an admin interface with default credentials, and accesses confidential data.
  2. A user with limited access exploits misconfigured permissions to download sensitive financial records.
  3. An attacker targets insecure API endpoints to extract user expense reports.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Dictionary-based or brute force password attack
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Dictionary-based or brute force password attacks use automated tools to guess passwords and gain unauthorized access to SAP Concur. Dictionary attacks rely on common passwords, while brute force methods try all possible combinations, making weak or reused passwords particularly vulnerable.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers & Script Kiddies: Exploit weak or reused passwords using automated guessing tools.
  • Attack Vectors: Bypassing login endpoints that lack proper rate limiting or lockout mechanisms.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Access: Leads to account compromise and data breaches.
  • Data Exposure: Sensitive financial or personal information may be accessed.
  • Operational Disruption: Fraudulent activity can interfere with normal operations.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker uses a common password list to breach an account with weak credentials.
  2. A brute force tool systematically tries various combinations on an endpoint without sufficient lockout controls.
  3. Compromised credentials are reused across accounts, enabling multiple breaches.

threat.name: Attackers could gain access to sensitive data through a man in the middle attack
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
A man-in-the-middle (MITM) attack involves an attacker intercepting and potentially altering communications between users and SAP Concur servers. By exploiting insecure connections or misconfigured encryption protocols, attackers can capture sensitive data during transmission.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Cybercriminals: Use interception tools to capture unencrypted data over public or compromised networks.
  • APT Groups: Leverage sophisticated techniques to infiltrate network traffic and monitor communications.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploiting unsecured Wi-Fi networks or public hotspots.
    • Using ARP poisoning, DNS spoofing, or weak TLS/SSL configurations to intercept data.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Exposure of sensitive financial, personal, or operational data.
  • Credential Theft: Intercepted login details can lead to further unauthorized system access.
  • Financial Loss and Reputational Damage: Resulting fraud and erosion of customer trust.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An employee accesses SAP Concur over an unsecured public Wi-Fi network, allowing an attacker to intercept login credentials and session data.
  2. An attacker deploys ARP poisoning in a compromised network segment, capturing sensitive expense reports and personal data as they traverse the network.
  3. Exploiting weak TLS configurations, an attacker decrypts data exchanged between a mobile client and the SAP Concur server, harvesting confidential information.

threat.name: Attackers gain access to unauthorised data by exploiting vulnerabilities in the service
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Attackers exploit inherent vulnerabilities in the SAP Concur service—such as unpatched software bugs, misconfigured settings, or insecure code—to bypass security controls and access unauthorized data. These vulnerabilities may exist in web interfaces, APIs, or backend systems, providing attackers with the opportunity to retrieve sensitive information.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • External Hackers: Use automated tools or manual techniques to identify and exploit known vulnerabilities.
  • APT Groups: Leverage sophisticated methods to uncover zero-day or unpatched vulnerabilities for prolonged access.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploiting software bugs or logic flaws in the service.
    • Taking advantage of unpatched systems or insecure API endpoints.
    • Utilizing injection attacks (e.g., SQL injection) to bypass access controls.

Impacts

  • Data Breaches: Exposure of sensitive financial, personal, or operational data.
  • Regulatory Non-Compliance: Unauthorized data access may lead to violations of data protection laws and potential fines.
  • Reputational Damage: Loss of customer trust and market credibility due to compromised data integrity.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker identifies an unpatched vulnerability in the service’s API, exploits it to bypass authentication, and retrieves sensitive user information.
  2. Using an injection attack, a hacker manipulates a backend query to access confidential expense reports stored in the database.
  3. A sophisticated threat actor discovers a flaw in the session management system that allows unauthorized access to user data by hijacking active sessions.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: An attacker try to perform identity fraud
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
An attacker attempts identity fraud by impersonating legitimate users to bypass security measures in SAP Concur. By using stolen credentials, forged identity information, or social engineering tactics, the attacker can gain unauthorized access and perform fraudulent activities.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Cybercriminals and Fraudsters: Exploit stolen credentials or use social engineering to impersonate trusted users.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Phishing schemes that trick users into divulging sensitive information.
    • Social engineering to manipulate support teams into granting access.
    • Exploiting weak authentication controls to assume another user's identity.

Impacts

  • Financial Loss: Fraudulent transactions and unauthorized expense approvals can result in direct financial harm.
  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access may expose sensitive personal and financial data.
  • Reputational Damage: Compromised identities can erode trust among users and stakeholders.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker sends a phishing email to capture user credentials, then logs into SAP Concur and approves fraudulent expense claims.
  2. Through social engineering, an attacker convinces support personnel to reset a victim's account password, thereby hijacking the account.
  3. Exploiting a weak authentication system, an attacker uses stolen login details to impersonate a user and initiate unauthorized financial transactions.

weakness.name: CWE-20
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-20: Improper Input Validation The product receives input or data, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input has the properties that are required to process the data safely and correctly.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-306
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-306: Missing Authentication for Critical Function The product does not perform any authentication for functionality that requires a provable user identity or consumes a significant amount of resources.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-346
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-346: Origin Validation Error The product does not properly verify that the source of data or communication is valid.

weakness.name: CWE-668
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-668: Exposure of Resource to Wrong Sphere The product exposes a resource to the wrong control sphere, providing unintended actors with inappropriate access to the resource.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Apply an RBA risk score and set up a CAPTCHA service to mitigate automated and configuration-based attacks
countermeasure.desc:
The implementation of Risk-Based Authentication (RBA) Risk Score Thresholds is essential to enhance user authentication by responding appropriately to varying levels of risk associated with login attempts. By establishing predefined risk score thresholds, an organization can automate actions such as account lockouts or additional authentication challenges, thereby strengthening security measures.

CAPTCHA (Completely Automated Public Turing test to tell Computers and Humans Apart), is one of the most popular methods of distinguishing between a human user vs. an automated attacker. SAP Customer Data Cloud enables adding a CAPTCHA challenge to the login and registration screens. The CAPTCHA service protects your site from automated hacking attempts.

Remediation:
1. In the RBA screen of the Console, add a new Global Rule.
2. Select the desired "On high risk score" rule, for example On high risk score > Account lockout.
3. The type should remain highRisk.
4. The scope can be account or IP.
5. The threshold is the number above which the RBA rule is triggered. For example, if the threshold is 0.8 and the riskScore is 0.9, the rule is triggered (in this example, the account is locked out).

References:

  • RBA Risk Score

PR.AC-1: Identities and credentials are issued, managed, verified, revoked, and audited for authorized devices, users and processes

countermeasure.name: Configure IP restrictions and enable unknown location notifications to detect or block unusual access attempts
countermeasure.desc:
You can control the IP addresses that can access Customer Data APIs on behalf of your organization by configuring allow lists, deny lists, or both, within the SAP Customer Data Console.

Remediation:
1. Navigate to the Administration section of the SAP Customer Data Cloud Console.
2. Select IP Restrictions under the Access Management section.
3. Define a list containing your IP addresses. From the List Definitions tab, select Create.
4. In the configuration window that opens, enter the IP addresses or IP range you want to include in this list, and give it a name, so you can locate it during the next steps. See examples for the required format of the IP address and range: - IP address: 108.128.177.17 - IP range: 95.213.238.40/29
5. After creating your IP list, go to the Active Listing tab to configure this IP List.
6. Click Create to begin configuring an Active Listing: - Choose whether this listing will be global at the Partner level, or pertain only to a specific API key. If only to a single API key, choose this API key from the dropdown. - Configure this listing as an allow or deny list. This tells the system to either only allow connections from the defined IPs or to only block (deny) connections from these IPs. You can add multiple IP lists to a single listing.
7. Once finished, press Save. Your configuration is now complete, however, it can take up to 5 minutes for your changes to be available in the Console and production.

References:

  • IP Restrictions

countermeasure.name: Configure policy-based access control in SAP Customer Data Cloud
countermeasure.desc:
Policies:
Organizations use policy-based access control to manage different access levels for their members. For example, while a Sales Lead may access all invoices, a Sales Representative might only see their own. This approach supports dynamic, attribute-based decision-making, complete policy lifecycle management, and run-time authorization across various assets like applications and site pages.

Business Entities:
Business Entities define a structured set of privileges that grant access to specific applications and assets. They are built hierarchically using Business Entity Attributes (such as user location or marketing language), enabling fine-grained control over rights assignment. This system allows organizations to dynamically tailor access for partners and users based on predefined rules.

Conditions:
Conditions add flexibility and precision to policies by incorporating external factors. They enable or restrict member actions based on elements such as date and time (e.g., allowing weekend activity), IP address ranges (IPv4, with CIDR notation for ranges), member attributes (like department or location), or specific request parameters. This helps refine access control beyond static attribute assignments.

Applications:
In the Organization Management context, an Application represents any business tool or system (e.g., a website or program) that interacts with organizational assets. Administrators configure which members can access these applications and define their permitted actions (viewing, downloading, modifying, etc.). By applying Conditions, organizations can further regulate when and from where access is allowed.

Remediation:
Setting Up an Asset Type:

  • Navigate to Assets & Conditions on the Organization Management page and click New Type.
  • Enter asset details (Name, Description, Security Settings).
  • Add a required Asset Attribute named Category.
  • Add at least one Asset by clicking Assets.

Creating a Policy:

  • Click Policies and then New Policy.
  • Select the Asset Type, Actions, and Asset, then click Continue.
  • Define policy availability (None, All, or Selected Organizations).
  • Configure Automated Assignments and Conditions as needed.

Creating a Business Entity:

  • Create Business Entity Type: Use the REST API or the CIAM for B2B console.
  • Create Business Entity Catalog Entry: Use the REST API or CIAM console to enter catalog details, choose a type, assign rulesets, and set availability.
  • Create Business Entity: Use the respective REST API endpoint.

Creating a Condition:

  • In the Authorization Workspace, go to Assets & Conditions and click New Conditions.
  • Provide a meaningful Name (and optional Description).
  • Choose a Condition Type (Date & Time, IP, Member Attribute, or Request Attribute) and define the rules.
  • Click Create.

Creating a New Application:

  • In the Authorization Workspace, click New App.
  • Enter the Application’s Name, optional Description, Logo URL, and customize the Color Indication.
  • Click Create to add the Application.

References:

  • Authorization Workspace
  • Policy-Based Access Control

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1018 - User Account Management

countermeasure.name: Enable security notifications (and related logging/monitoring) to quickly spot and react to suspicious activities
countermeasure.desc:
Receive security alerts to email when suspicious activity is detected on an account.
In order for you to maintain visibility on your site you may opt-in to receive Security Notifications when SAP Customer Data Cloud's ATO Engine notices suspicious activity on any of the sites in your account. You can specify whether to monitor all sites and site groups or only specific API keys/groups.

Remediation:
To receive these notifications, navigate to the Administration section of your SAP Customer Data Cloud console and go to the Security Notifications page. At the top of the page you can define up to 5 (five) email addresses to receive notifications when suspicious activity is detected. Next, you can define the sites to monitor. By default, all sites are monitored. Once you have configured the settings you can Enable the feature by toggling the button in the top-right of the page.
When defining the sites to monitor, you can use the search to narrow down the sites you want to edit. You an also select or deselect all sites at once by using the top most checkbox in the table header. If you have done a search, this select all option will only select or deselect sites that are part of the search results.

References:

  • Security Notifications

countermeasure.name: Enable two‑factor authentication (TFA) to ensure that only properly authenticated users can proceed
countermeasure.desc:
Enhance security with Two-Factor Authentication (TFA), which sends a verification code via email, SMS/phone, TOTP (authenticator app), or push notification after users enter their login credentials.

Enabling TFA Methods:

Email:

  1. Go to Identity Security > Identity Verification.
  2. Enable email verification (and optionally, code verification).
  3. Under Security > Authentication, select Email and click Save.

SMS/Phone:

  1. In Authentication > Verification Methods, select SMS/Phone and save (requires an SMS provider).

TOTP:

  1. Under Authentication > Verification Methods, choose Authenticator App.
  2. Provide a name and save (users must have an authenticator app installed).

Push:

  1. In Authentication > Authentication Types, enter your Firebase key.
  2. Select Push Notification with a default rule set and save (requires preconfigured push rules).

TFA Configuration Options:

Admin-Enabled TFA:

  • Navigate to Identity > Security > Risk Based Authentication, click the cogwheel, select a default account rule-set, and set the Account Rule-Set Override to Admin only. Save your changes.

User-Enabled TFA:

  • Follow the same steps as above but set the Account Rule-Set Override to Admin and End User.
  • Update your UI via the UI builder to allow users to opt in/out.

Customizing Templates:

Email Templates:

  1. Go to User Interfacing > Email Templates.
  2. Select TFA Email Verification, configure the default language or add additional locales.

SMS Templates:

  1. Go to User Interfacing > SMS Templates > TFA.
  2. Set the Global Default Content language.

References:

  • Admin Configuration for TFA

countermeasure.name: Implement secure signature generation to ensure data integrity and secure customer interactions
countermeasure.desc:
Constructing a Signature – Short Summary

Purpose:
Server-side signature construction validates sensitive operations in SAP Customer Data Cloud and prevents unauthorized access.

Why Sign UIDs:
API methods (e.g., socialize.notifyRegistration, socialize.setUID, socialize.notifyLogin) require a server-generated signature (UIDSig parameter) to ensure authenticity.

How to Construct a Signature:

  1. Create a Base String:
    • Format: "Timestamp_UID" (replace with actual timestamp and UID).
  2. Convert to Binary:
    • Use UTF-8 encoding for the base string.
  3. (Optional) Nonce Storage:
    • Store the base string as a nonce to prevent reuse.
  4. Prepare the Secret Key:
    • Convert your BASE64-encoded secret key to a binary array.
  5. Calculate the Signature:
    • Use HMAC-SHA1 with the binary key and base string.
  6. Finalize:
    • Convert the resulting binary signature to a BASE64 string.

Implementation Notes:

  • Server-side Only: Always perform signature generation on the server.
  • Encoding: Use encodeURIComponent() on UIDs when transmitting from the client to ensure proper verification.
  • SDK Support: If available, use the SDK’s SigUtils.calcSignature() method to simplify the process.
  • REST API: Use the designated signing algorithm for HTTP requests.

References:

  • Secure Delivery, Configuration, and Change Management
  • Signing Requests to SAP Customer Data Cloud

countermeasure.name: Set up and enforce SSL/TLS certificates
countermeasure.desc:
Why You Need an SSL Certificate:

  • Maintain Branding: Use a CNAME (e.g., https://login.yoursite.com) to keep your site's branding instead of redirecting to socialize.gigya.com.
  • Eliminate Warnings: Prevent browser security warnings during redirects to SAP Customer Data Cloud.
  • Ensure Security: Encrypt data to protect against man-in-the-middle attacks.

Before Setting Up:

  1. List Domains: Verify all domains/subdomains in the Trusted Site URLs in the SAP Customer Data Cloud Console.
  2. Define Alias: Choose a CNAME alias for your sites.
  3. Get Site ID: Locate the Site ID for your API key.
  4. DNS Setup: Create a CNAME alias in your DNS records for each site, pointing to .gigya-api.com using your Site ID.

Obtaining and Installing the Certificate:

  • Provisioning: SAP will purchase and host your certificate after you complete the pre-setup steps.
  • Verification: Follow the Certificate Provisioning instructions and verify domain ownership via email (using official WHOIS contacts).
  • Installation: Once verified, the Certificate Authority signs and sends your SSL certificate bundle, and SAP installs it—usually within one business day.

References:

  • Certificate Provisioning
  • SSL Certificates

countermeasure.name: Use FIDO authentication for strong, phishing-resistant user verification
countermeasure.desc:
FIDO is a passwordless and phishing-resistant authentication method supported on mobile devices and common desktop web browsers. In addition to single-device / device-bound credentials, multi-device credentials, or passkeys, are a new technology that makes it convenient to use FIDO's authentication methods across multiple devices, platforms, and operating systems. Passkeys are recoverable, protected against device loss, and available when and where users need them - without having to rely on passwords.

Remediation: 

  1. In the SAP Customer Data Cloud console, navigate to Identity > Security > Authentication. 
  2. Enable FIDO by selecting the checkbox and configure the contained fields. 
  3. At the bottom of the Authentication page, choose Save.

References:

  • FIDO Authentication

countermeasure.name: Validate the session during the login process
countermeasure.desc:
After a user completes a login successfully (using any of our supported authentication options such as site, social, phone number, OIDC), it is not enough to intercept the onLogin event fired by SAP Customer Data Cloud. You should also validate the user's session and the UID. Otherwise, malicious attacks can be made masquerading as a logged in user. Validation is done using an id-token JWT. To receive the id-token from the onLogin events, be sure to add "id-token" to the include parameter of your Global Configuration.
The id-token: - Is used to validate that the user has an active client session with SAP Customer Data Cloud. - Is a short-lived JWT that holds the UID of the user. - Does not hold any PII data, and is safe to transfer to third parties. - Is not treated as a session, just a proof of ownership.

Remediation: 

  • Always prefer to use a standard library for validation, as opposed to writing your own 
  • Validate the signature with our public JWT by calling accounts.getJWTPublicKey with V2 set to 'true'. 
  • Validate the issuer against your site's API key - Validate the expiration of the token 
  • Validate that isLoggedIn is 'true' before returning a session to the client to confirm that the user is logged into SAP Customer Data Cloud (as opposed to pending registration for instance)

Sample code for validating an id-token:

private async Task < string > ValidateJWT(string idToken) { var httpClient = new HttpClient(); var response = await httpClient.GetStringAsync($ "https://accounts.us1.gigya.com/accounts.getJWTPublicKey?&v2"); var jwks = new JsonWebKeySet(response); var parameters = new TokenValidationParameters{ ValidateAudience = false, ValidateIssuer = true, ValidIssuer = $ "https://fidm.gigya.com/jwt/{apikey}/", ValidateLifetime = true, IssuerSigningKeys = jwks.Keys }; var handler = new JwtSecurityTokenHandler(); handler.InboundClaimTypeMap.Clear(); SecurityToken jwt; ClaimsPrincipal claimsPrincipal = handler.ValidateToken(idToken, parameters, out jwt); var uid = claimsPrincipal.FindFirst("sub").Value; return uid;
}

References:

  • Network and Communication Security
