usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Abuse of user privileges could lead to unauthorized actions
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Abuse of user privileges in SAP Customer Data Cloud occurs when users or accounts with elevated rights perform actions beyond their authorized scope. This can result from misconfigurations, inadequate access controls, or intentional misuse, allowing unauthorized changes or data access within the system.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Insider Threats: Employees or contractors who misuse their legitimate access either accidentally or with malicious intent.
  • Compromised Accounts: Attackers who gain control over accounts with elevated privileges through phishing, credential theft, or exploitation of vulnerabilities.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploitation of misconfigured role-based access controls.
    • Abuse of shared or legacy accounts with excessive privileges.
    • Social engineering tactics to trick users into granting higher-level access.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Data Access: Sensitive customer data can be accessed, modified, or exfiltrated without proper authorization.
  • Operational Disruption: Unapproved changes can compromise system integrity, leading to service disruptions or data corruption.
  • Regulatory and Reputational Damage: Violations of data governance policies may result in legal consequences and loss of customer trust.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An employee with administrative rights intentionally accesses customer data for personal gain or espionage, leading to data exfiltration.
  2. An attacker compromises a privileged account through phishing and uses it to alter system configurations, bypassing security controls.
  3. A user inadvertently misuses their elevated access to change settings in a production environment, causing a service outage or data inconsistency.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Attackers could gain access to an open session if they have access to a user's browser
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Attackers exploiting open sessions in SAP Customer Data Cloud take advantage of active, authenticated sessions in a user's browser. This occurs when sessions remain active on devices that are left unattended or are vulnerable to session hijacking techniques. Without proper session management and secure cookie handling, attackers can intercept session tokens and bypass authentication controls.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Malicious Insiders and External Attackers: Individuals who either physically access a device or remotely exploit vulnerabilities to steal session information.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Physical Access: An attacker gains direct access to an unattended device with an open browser session.
    • Session Hijacking: Exploiting vulnerabilities such as cross-site scripting (XSS) or session fixation to capture session tokens.
    • Network Attacks: Intercepting session data over unencrypted connections or insecure networks.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Access: Attackers can impersonate legitimate users, gaining access to sensitive customer data and performing unauthorized actions.
  • Data Breach: Exposure or manipulation of confidential information stored in the SAP Customer Data Cloud.
  • Reputational and Financial Damage: Potential legal, compliance, and reputational consequences from unauthorized data access.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker physically accesses a workstation where a user left their browser logged into SAP Customer Data Cloud, using the open session to view and export sensitive data.
  2. An attacker exploits an XSS vulnerability to steal session cookies from a user’s browser, later using these cookies to hijack the session and perform unauthorized transactions.
  3. On a public Wi-Fi network, an attacker intercepts unencrypted session tokens from an active browser session and uses them to gain unauthorized access to user accounts.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1505 - Server Software Component

threat.name: Anonymous users might gain access to sensitive data if access controls aren’t enforced properly
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
In SAP Customer Data Cloud, insufficiently enforced access controls may allow anonymous or unauthenticated users to access sensitive data. This vulnerability arises when security mechanisms do not strictly verify user credentials before granting access, leaving data exposed to unauthorized parties.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Anonymous Users: Individuals without valid credentials who directly attempt to access unsecured endpoints.
  • Cybercriminals: Attackers who exploit misconfigured APIs or access control settings using automated scanning tools.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Bypassing authentication on publicly exposed APIs or web interfaces.
    • Exploiting vulnerabilities in session management and access control configurations.

Impacts

  • Data Exposure: Unauthorized disclosure of sensitive customer data, including personally identifiable information.
  • Regulatory and Compliance Issues: Potential violations of data protection regulations, leading to legal and financial repercussions.
  • Reputational Damage: Loss of customer trust and negative publicity following a data breach.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker uses automated tools to discover an unsecured API endpoint that returns customer records without requiring authentication.
  2. A misconfigured access control allows an unauthenticated user to navigate directly to a secure document repository and download confidential files.
  3. Exploiting a flaw in session management, an anonymous actor repeatedly accesses data endpoints, gradually collecting sensitive information.

threat.name: Attackers gain unauthorized connections to resources, which could lead to further system compromise
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Attackers exploit vulnerabilities or weak security configurations in SAP Customer Data Cloud to establish unauthorized connections to resources. Once connected, these attackers can leverage the access to pivot within the network, potentially compromising additional systems or extracting sensitive information.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • External Cybercriminals: Use automated scanning and exploitation techniques to identify and connect to unsecured resources.
  • Insider Threats: Individuals with legitimate access may misuse their connections to access additional resources without proper authorization.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploiting misconfigured network segmentation or firewall rules.
    • Leveraging compromised credentials to access interconnected systems.
    • Exploiting vulnerabilities in exposed APIs and web services.

Impacts

  • Lateral Movement: Unauthorized connections can serve as a stepping stone for further system compromise.
  • Data Breach: Sensitive information stored on interconnected resources may be exposed or exfiltrated.
  • Operational Disruption: Compromise of additional systems can disrupt business operations and damage the overall integrity of the environment.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker exploits a misconfigured API to gain initial access to a low-privileged resource and then uses that foothold to move laterally into more sensitive parts of the network.
  2. Using stolen credentials, a cybercriminal connects to an internal resource and establishes persistent access, eventually compromising adjacent systems and extracting confidential data.
  3. An insider misuses their access to connect to multiple systems, facilitating unauthorized data transfers and altering critical configurations without detection.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1135 - Network Share Discovery

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Without proper logging, malicious activities may go undetected, delaying incident response
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Without proper logging in SAP Customer Data Cloud, malicious activities can occur without leaving a trace, which severely delays the detection and response to incidents. Inadequate logging allows attackers to operate covertly, manipulate data, and cover their tracks, making forensic investigations and timely incident response exceedingly difficult.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: May exploit weak logging configurations or use anti-forensic techniques to erase evidence of their activities.
  • Insider Threats: Malicious insiders might disable or manipulate logs to hide unauthorized actions.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploiting vulnerabilities that allow the disabling or alteration of log settings.
    • Utilizing stealth tactics to avoid triggering any logging mechanisms.
    • Injecting false logs to mislead monitoring systems.

Impacts

  • Extended Dwell Time: Attackers can remain undetected for longer periods, increasing the potential damage.
  • Delayed Incident Response: Critical security incidents may go unnoticed, allowing further system compromise.
  • Compromised Forensic Investigations: Inadequate logs hinder the ability to reconstruct the sequence of events after an incident, making remediation more challenging.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker gains access to the system and deliberately disables logging functions to conceal their unauthorized data exfiltration activities.
  2. A malicious insider manipulates log files to erase traces of fraudulent transactions, thereby delaying the detection of the breach.
  3. An automated script targets vulnerabilities in the logging configuration, resulting in incomplete or missing logs during a coordinated attack, which subsequently hampers the incident response process.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1560 - Archive Collected Data

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Attackers exploit weaknesses in the authentication process to gain access to user accounts
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Attackers exploit weaknesses in the authentication process to bypass security measures and gain unauthorized access to user accounts. This threat arises when authentication mechanisms are inadequately implemented—such as weak password policies, poorly enforced multi-factor authentication, or vulnerabilities in session management—allowing attackers to impersonate legitimate users.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • External Cybercriminals: Use automated tools to exploit weak authentication controls, such as brute force attacks or credential stuffing.
  • Insider Threats: Individuals with limited or compromised access may abuse weak authentication measures to escalate privileges.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploiting weak or reused passwords.
    • Leveraging vulnerabilities in multi-factor authentication implementations.
    • Conducting brute force or credential stuffing attacks.
    • Hijacking sessions through vulnerabilities in session management.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Account Access: Attackers can access sensitive data and user-specific functionalities, leading to potential data breaches.
  • Data Compromise: Sensitive personal or corporate data can be exfiltrated, leading to regulatory and reputational issues.
  • Lateral Movement: Once inside, attackers may pivot to access further resources within the network, escalating the overall impact.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker uses a credential stuffing attack, leveraging leaked credentials to gain unauthorized access to multiple user accounts.
  2. Exploiting a flaw in the multi-factor authentication implementation, an attacker bypasses the second factor and logs in as a privileged user.
  3. Automated brute force attacks target accounts with weak passwords due to insufficient account lockout policies, eventually leading to account compromise.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Attackers could intercept and alter data in transit by positioning themselves between the user and the system
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Attackers may exploit insecure communication channels between the user and SAP Customer Data Cloud to intercept and alter data in transit. Without robust encryption and integrity checks, data exchanged over the network can be captured and modified, potentially leading to unauthorized transactions, data corruption, or leakage of sensitive information.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • External Cybercriminals: Utilize techniques such as man-in-the-middle (MITM) attacks to intercept and modify data during transmission.
  • Advanced Persistent Threat (APT) Groups: May position themselves within network pathways to covertly intercept data flows over extended periods.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploiting unencrypted or weakly encrypted communication protocols (e.g., outdated TLS/SSL configurations).
    • Launching ARP poisoning or DNS spoofing attacks to redirect network traffic through malicious intermediaries.
    • Compromising network devices or public Wi-Fi networks to capture sensitive data.

Impacts

  • Data Integrity Compromise: Modified data can lead to incorrect or fraudulent transactions and decision-making based on tampered information.
  • Data Confidentiality Loss: Sensitive user information and credentials may be exposed to unauthorized parties.
  • Operational Disruption: Altered or corrupted data can disrupt business processes and degrade system reliability.
  • Reputational Damage: Breaches of data integrity and confidentiality can lead to loss of customer trust and legal repercussions.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker sets up a rogue access point on a public Wi-Fi network, intercepting unencrypted data from users accessing SAP Customer Data Cloud and modifying transaction details in real time.
  2. Utilizing ARP poisoning, an attacker positions themselves between an internal user and the SAP Customer Data Cloud server, intercepting and altering sensitive communications without detection.
  3. Through DNS spoofing, an attacker redirects users to a malicious portal that mimics SAP Customer Data Cloud, capturing and altering data inputs during login and transaction processes.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1601 - Modify System Image

threat.name: An attacker might alter data while it is moving between systems or components
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
When data moves between systems or components, it is vulnerable to interception. If proper encryption and integrity checks are not in place, an attacker may intercept and alter the data in transit, leading to unauthorized modifications that compromise the accuracy and reliability of the information.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • External Cybercriminals: Use man-in-the-middle (MITM) techniques to intercept and modify data streams.
  • Insider Threats: Individuals with internal network access may exploit insecure communication channels.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploiting unencrypted or poorly encrypted data transmissions.
    • Leveraging misconfigured network devices that allow unauthorized data interception.
    • Utilizing techniques such as ARP poisoning or DNS spoofing to position themselves between communicating systems.

Impacts

  • Data Integrity Compromise: Altered data can lead to incorrect or manipulated information being processed by the system.
  • Operational Disruption: Unauthorized modifications may result in system malfunctions or incorrect business decisions based on tampered data.
  • Reputational Damage: Loss of customer trust due to compromised data integrity and potential legal or regulatory repercussions.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker intercepts an unencrypted data packet between a client and SAP Customer Data Cloud, modifies transaction details, and forwards the altered packet to the recipient, leading to financial discrepancies.
  2. By exploiting a misconfigured network device, an attacker launches an MITM attack, injecting false data into communications between internal systems, which results in corrupted records.
  3. An insider with access to network infrastructure intercepts data flows and subtly alters sensitive customer information, enabling further fraudulent activities.

threat.name: Attackers take advantage of weak or misconfigured security settings to breach the system
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Attackers take advantage of weak or misconfigured security settings in SAP Customer Data Cloud to breach the system. This threat arises when default configurations, unpatched vulnerabilities, or improperly set access controls provide attackers with an easy entry point to compromise the environment.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • External Cybercriminals: Use automated tools to scan for misconfigurations and exploit default credentials.
  • Insider Threats: May intentionally or inadvertently misuse access permissions resulting from weak configurations.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploiting default or weak credentials left unchanged during deployment.
    • Taking advantage of misconfigured firewall or network segmentation settings.
    • Leveraging unpatched software and exposed administrative interfaces.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Access: Attackers can gain control over sensitive areas of the system.
  • Data Breaches: Exposure or manipulation of confidential customer data may occur.
  • Operational Disruption: Breaches can lead to system downtime or degradation of services.
  • Reputational Damage: Loss of customer trust and potential legal or regulatory consequences.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker scans for systems with default administrative credentials and successfully logs into the SAP Customer Data Cloud to extract sensitive data.
  2. A misconfigured firewall inadvertently exposes an internal management interface to the public internet, allowing an attacker to exploit a vulnerability and gain elevated privileges.
  3. An insider discovers that security patches have not been applied to critical components, then leverages this weakness to access restricted data and perform unauthorized actions.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-359
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-359: Exposure of Private Personal Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product does not properly prevent a person's private, personal information from being accessed by actors who either (1) are not explicitly authorized to access the information or (2) do not have the implicit consent of the person about whom the information is collected.

weakness.name: CWE-611
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-611: Improper Restriction of XML External Entity Reference The product processes an XML document that can contain XML entities with URIs that resolve to documents outside of the intended sphere of control, causing the product to embed incorrect documents into its output.

weakness.name: CWE-666
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-666: Operation on Resource in Wrong Phase of Lifetime The product performs an operation on a resource at the wrong phase of the resource's lifecycle, which can lead to unexpected behaviors. A resource's lifecycle includes several phases: initialization, use, and release. For each phase, it is important to follow the specifications outlined for how to operate on the resource and to ensure that the resource is in the expected phase. Otherwise, if a resource is in one phase but the operation is not valid for that phase (i.e., an incorrect phase of the resource's lifetime), then this can produce resultant weaknesses. For example, using a resource before it has been fully initialized could cause corruption or incorrect data to be used.

countermeasure.name: Configure SSL for metadata browsing and view data services
countermeasure.desc:
Metadata browsing and view Data Services use plain text by default which could allow attackers to capture sensitive information exchanged between the Data Services and the client. This information could be used to launch further attacks on the system.

Remediation:
To enable and configure SSL communications for Metadata Browsing and View Data Services, perform the following steps:

1. Log into the Central Management Console (CMC) as a user with administrative rights to SAP Data Services.
2. Open the Applications management page of the CMC.
3. Right-click Data Services Application and choose Settings.
4. Choose Yes from the Enable SSL communication for Metadata Browsing and View Data Services list.
5. To use the default keystore and certificates that Data Services provides, perform the following substeps:
a. Choose Yes from the Use Default SSL Settings list.
b. Select Save.
6. To use custom certificates, perform the following substeps:
Your keystore must be a Java keystore file that contains a single key with all the certificates that are part of the certificate chain involved in signing the key. Provide a password for the key and a password for the keystore file.

Your keystore file must be in the \ssl\mds directory. The corresponding certificate files must be in the \ssl\mds\trusted_certs directory.

a. For multiple instances of Metadata Browsing Service or View Data Service associated with the same CMS server, copy the keystore and certificate files to all the machines where these instances are installed.
b. Choose No from the Use Default SSL Settings list.
c. Enter the name of the KeyStore file in KeyStore File.
d. Enter the applicable password in KeyStore Password.
e. Enter the applicable password in Key Password.
f. Select Save.
7. Restart the EIM Adaptive Processing Server by performing the following substeps:
a. Open the Servers management area.
b. Expand the Service Categories node and select the Enterprise Information Management Services node.
c. Select the EIMAdaptiveProcessingServer from the Server Name column in the right pane.
d. Select Action Restart Server.
The State column lists "Stopping", then "Starting", and finally "Running".

Selecting the Refresh icon helps to update the status in the State column.

References:

  • SSL for Metadata Browsing and View Data Services

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information

countermeasure.name: Configure SSL for the CMS connection
countermeasure.desc:
SAP Data Services uses the Central Management Server (CMS) to manage and control the system. The CMS connection can be secured with SSL encryption to prevent eavesdropping and unauthorized access to the data. Without SSL encryption, sensitive information such as passwords and user credentials could be intercepted by attackers.

Remediation:
To set up SSL for all CMS communication, you need to perform the following tasks:

- Deploy the SAP BusinessObjects BI platform or Information Platform Services with SSL enabled.
- Create key and certificate files for each machine in your deployment.
- Configure the location of the key and certificate files in the Central Configuration Manager (CCM) and your web application server.

For Data Services, use the sslconfig utility to configure all components that log into the CMS for SSL, including the following components:

- SAP Data Services Designer
- Job Servers
- External schedulers and the job launcher
- SAP Data Services Management Console (if deployed to a different web application server than the SAP BusinessObjects BI platform or Information platform services web tier)

Note
For J2EE web application servers, configure SSL by modifying the startup script.

By default, the sslconfig utility is installed in the following location:
- For Windows:
\SAP BusinessObjects Enterprise XI 4.0\win32_x86\sslconfig.exe

- For UNIX:
$INSTALL_DIR/sap_bobj/enterprise_xi40//boe_sslconfig

Where matches your UNIX platform.

References:

  • Configure SSL for the CMS connection

countermeasure.name: Configure SSL or TLS for SAP Data Services components
countermeasure.desc:
Unsecured communications between SAP Data Services components can lead to interception and modification of sensitive data in transit. Therefore, it is essential to encrypt the communication channels between the components.

Remediation:
To secure the communication channels between SAP Data Services components, SSL or TLS should be enabled. SSL and TLS are encryption protocols that encrypt the data transmitted over the network, preventing it from being intercepted or modified. The configuration of SSL or TLS is specific to each component, and it should be performed according to the vendor's guidelines.

For more information please see Reference URL.

References:

  • SSL or TLS for Data Services components

countermeasure.name: Do not use external data type definitions (DTDs) for SAP Data Services
countermeasure.desc:
External Data Type Definitions (DTDs) are files that define the structure and format of XML data. SAP Data Services uses XML files for data integration, and DTDs are often used to define the structure of the XML data. However, using external DTDs can introduce security risks, as they can be manipulated to execute malicious code or to access unauthorized data. By avoiding the use of external DTDs, SAP Data Services can help prevent XML-related security vulnerabilities.

Remediation:
Instead of relying on external DTDs, use internal DTDs or XML Schema Definitions (XSDs) to validate and define data structures. This approach helps to ensure that the XML data is processed securely and that there are no vulnerabilities that can be exploited by attackers.

Example:
The following code example shows an XML document with a reference to an external DTD. The DTD file note.dtd is defined in a file in the system that is external to the XML document.

References:

  • External DTD in XML documents

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1040 - Behavior Prevention on Endpoint

countermeasure.name: Encrypt temporary cache files for SAP Data Services
countermeasure.desc:
Temporary cache files created by SAP Data Services can contain sensitive information such as login credentials, data source information, and data transformation details. If these files are accessed by unauthorized users, they can be used to compromise the security of the system. Encrypting the temporary cache files can prevent unauthorized access to the sensitive information stored in them.

Remediation:
To encrypt the specific temporary cache files, perform the following steps:

1. Open the DSConfig.txt file, located in \conf.
2. Add the following parameter to the String section: pageable_cache_encrypt_data =.
3. Enter the value yes.
pageable_cache_encrypt_data = yes
4. Save and close the dsconfig.txt file.

References:

  • Temporary cache files

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information

countermeasure.name: Use firewall to secure administrative functions for SAP Data Services
countermeasure.desc:
Administrative functions in SAP Data Services, such as user management and system configuration, are critical components that require robust security measures to prevent unauthorized access. A firewall is a crucial component of a defense-in-depth security strategy that can be used to control access to administrative functions. By implementing a firewall to secure administrative functions, it helps to prevent unauthorized access and minimize the risk of data breaches and insider threats.

Remediation:
To implement a firewall to secure administrative functions for SAP Data Services:
1. Identify administrative functions: Identify the administrative functions that need to be secured, such as user management and system configuration.
2. Configure firewall rules: Configure the firewall to allow access to the administrative functions only from authorized sources and block all other traffic.
3. Test firewall configuration: Test the firewall configuration to ensure that it is working as intended and that administrative functions are accessible only from authorized sources.
4. Review and update: Regularly review and update the firewall rules to ensure that access is appropriate and up-to-date.

References:

  • Firewall for secure administrative functions

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Attackers try to take advantage of a wide attack surface
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
In SAP Data Services, "Attackers try to take advantage of a wide attack surface" refers to the risk posed by multiple exposed interfaces, endpoints, and services that could be exploited if not properly secured. A wide attack surface increases the likelihood that at least one component may have a vulnerability or misconfiguration, which attackers can use as an entry point into the system.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • External Cybercriminals: Use automated tools to scan for unsecured or misconfigured endpoints across the system.
  • Insider Threats: Individuals with internal access might exploit exposed services either intentionally or unintentionally.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploiting unprotected administrative interfaces or open network ports.
    • Targeting exposed APIs and metadata endpoints that lack robust security controls.
    • Leveraging XML injection or similar attacks against data processing components.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Access: Attackers may breach the system by exploiting a vulnerable component, gaining access to sensitive data or critical system functions.
  • Data Breach: Exposure or manipulation of confidential customer or business data could occur.
  • Operational Disruption: The compromise of one component may lead to broader system instability or service outages.
  • Increased Risk of Lateral Movement: Gaining a foothold can allow attackers to pivot to other parts of the network, compounding the overall risk.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker uses an automated vulnerability scanner to discover an unsecured administrative interface within SAP Data Services, then exploits this access to modify system settings.
  2. Exploiting a misconfigured API endpoint, an attacker injects malicious XML payloads, which compromise the integrity of the data processing system.
  3. A combination of open network ports and outdated software leads to a scenario where an attacker gains initial access through one vulnerable component, then moves laterally to compromise additional resources.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Attackers access system files through XML related attacks
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
In SAP Data Services, "Attackers access system files through XML related attacks" refers to the exploitation of vulnerabilities in XML processing mechanisms. Attackers may leverage flaws such as XML External Entity (XXE) vulnerabilities or XML injection to manipulate the parsing of XML documents. This can lead to unauthorized disclosure or modification of system files that are critical to the application's integrity.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • External Cybercriminals: Use automated tools to scan for XML parsing vulnerabilities and craft malicious payloads.
  • Insider Threats: May intentionally or accidentally expose vulnerabilities by providing unsanitized XML input.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploiting XXE vulnerabilities to read arbitrary files.
    • Injecting malicious XML code to manipulate file system access.
    • Submitting crafted XML requests through web interfaces or APIs that process XML content.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Data Disclosure: Sensitive system files, configuration details, or credentials can be exposed.
  • System Integrity Compromise: Access to critical files may allow attackers to alter configurations or execute arbitrary code.
  • Broader System Compromise: Initial file access could serve as a foothold for further exploitation, leading to extensive data breaches or system downtime.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker submits a specially crafted XML document exploiting an XXE vulnerability, which causes the parser to read and return the contents of a sensitive configuration file.
  2. A malicious payload is injected into an XML-based API endpoint, resulting in the exposure of system logs that contain confidential operational data.
  3. Automated scanning tools identify an unsanitized XML input field, allowing an attacker to retrieve system files that reveal internal network structure and credentials.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1220 - XSL Script Processing

threat.name: Attackers could gain access to sensitive data through a man in the middle attack
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
In SAP Data Services, a man-in-the-middle (MITM) attack occurs when an attacker intercepts communication between two parties—such as between a client and the server—to capture or manipulate data in transit. Without proper encryption or secure channel configuration, attackers can eavesdrop on or alter sensitive data, compromising the integrity and confidentiality of information.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • External Cybercriminals: Use techniques like ARP poisoning, DNS spoofing, or rogue Wi-Fi access points to intercept data.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploiting misconfigured SSL/TLS settings or unencrypted data channels.
    • Setting up rogue network nodes to intercept traffic between users and SAP Data Services.
    • Leveraging vulnerabilities in network infrastructure to reroute communications through controlled systems.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Sensitive information such as credentials, configuration data, and business-critical information can be exposed.
  • Data Integrity Issues: Attackers may modify data in transit, leading to corrupted or misleading information being processed by the system.
  • Reputational and Financial Damage: Loss of customer trust and potential financial losses from fraudulent activities or remedial actions.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker deploys a rogue Wi-Fi hotspot in a public area and intercepts unencrypted communications between SAP Data Services and client applications, capturing sensitive data.
  2. Exploiting outdated or misconfigured SSL/TLS protocols, an attacker intercepts and alters data packets exchanged during a session, leading to data manipulation.
  3. Using ARP poisoning on an internal network, an attacker redirects traffic from SAP Data Services to a malicious server, capturing login credentials and system configuration details.

threat.name: Sensitive data is compromised through unauthorized access to data
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Sensitive data is compromised when unauthorized individuals bypass security controls in SAP Data Services to access confidential information. This breach can occur due to weak access controls, misconfigurations, or exploitation of software vulnerabilities, allowing attackers to retrieve, alter, or exfiltrate sensitive data without detection.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Cybercriminals who exploit system vulnerabilities or use social engineering techniques to obtain valid credentials.
  • Insider Threats: Employees or contractors who misuse their legitimate access rights, either intentionally or accidentally, to access sensitive information.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploitation of misconfigured access controls or weak authentication mechanisms.
    • Credential compromise through phishing or brute-force attacks.
    • Exploiting vulnerabilities in the application or network infrastructure to bypass standard security measures.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to sensitive customer, financial, or operational data may lead to its exposure or misuse.
  • Compliance Violations: Breaches of data protection regulations could result in legal penalties and significant fines.
  • Reputational Damage: Loss of customer trust and negative publicity may adversely affect business operations and market position.
  • Operational Disruption: Unauthorized modifications or data exfiltration can interrupt business processes and lead to financial losses.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An external attacker exploits a weak authentication system to bypass login procedures, gaining access to sensitive data stored in SAP Data Services.
  2. A phishing campaign successfully compromises user credentials, which are then used to log in and retrieve confidential data.
  3. An insider misuses elevated access privileges to extract sensitive data for personal gain, bypassing normal monitoring and detection mechanisms.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-306
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-306: Missing Authentication for Critical Function The product does not perform any authentication for functionality that requires a provable user identity or consumes a significant amount of resources.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-61
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-61: UNIX Symbolic Link (Symlink) Following The product, when opening a file or directory, does not sufficiently account for when the file is a symbolic link that resolves to a target outside of the intended control sphere. This could allow an attacker to cause the product to operate on unauthorized files. A product that allows UNIX symbolic links (symlink) as part of paths whether in internal code or through user input can allow an attacker to spoof the symbolic link and traverse the file system to unintended locations or access arbitrary files. The symbolic link can permit an attacker to read/write/corrupt a file that they originally did not have permissions to access.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Apply SAP FSM security updates and enforce mobile device management (MDM)
countermeasure.desc:
Ensuring the security of SAP Field Service Management (FSM) involves actively applying security patches and updates to both cloud and mobile applications. This process requires careful coordination and adherence to organizational security policies. Here are detailed steps to implement this countermeasure:

  1. Establish a Patch Management Schedule:
    • Regularly monitor SAP's official communication channels for announcements on new patches or security updates for FSM.
    • Develop a company-specific schedule, aligning with SAP's release cycles, to apply these updates promptly.
  2. Implement Mobile Device Management (MDM) Policies:
    • Select a robust MDM solution capable of managing device compliance and updates. Popular options include Microsoft Intune, VMware Workspace ONE, and MobileIron.
    • Configure the MDM solution to enforce policies ensuring devices run the latest version of the FSM app. Require periodic checks and prompt users to update when necessary.
    • Ensure compliance by setting up alerts for devices that fall behind on version updates or fail security checks.
  3. Verify and Test Updates:
    • Thoroughly test new updates in a controlled environment to identify potential compatibility issues or bugs before deployment.
    • Engage security teams to perform vulnerability assessments post-update to confirm the integrity of the patched application.
  4. Communicate with Field Engineers:
    • Create clear communication channels to inform field engineers about the importance of regular updates and compliance with MDM policies.
    • Offer training sessions that focus on security best practices and the necessity of keeping apps updated.
  5. Monitor and Review Compliance:
    • Set up regular reviews of compliance reports generated by the MDM system. Analyze these to identify trends and areas requiring additional focus.
    • Adjust policies and training sessions based on findings to improve overall compliance rates.

References

  • SAP FSM Security & Data Protection
  • Microsoft Intune Documentation
  • VMware Workspace ONE UEM Documentation
  • MobileIron Documentation

standard.ref: Contract Requirements for Service Providers and Contractors (a)
ID.RA-1: Asset vulnerabilities are identified and documented
PR.IP-12: A vulnerability management plan is developed and implemented

countermeasure.name: Develop and regularly test an FSM-specific incident response plan
countermeasure.desc:
To effectively enhance the security posture of the SAP Field Service Management (FSM) system, it is vital to develop a dedicated incident response plan tailored to its specific needs. Below are detailed steps for implementing this countermeasure:

  1. Identify Key Stakeholders:
    • Assemble a team of stakeholders including IT staff, security experts, and operations personnel. Ensure representation from management to facilitate decision making.
    • Assign roles and responsibilities clearly, identifying who will oversee the incident response process and coordination.
  2. Threat Identification and Analysis:
    • Conduct a threat analysis to understand the specific risks such as unauthorized access, API abuse, and data leaks. Maintain an up-to-date threat intelligence database.
    • Document all potential entry points and vulnerabilities within SAP FSM that could be exploited by attackers.
  3. Create an Incident Response Plan:
    • Develop a comprehensive response plan documenting procedures for responding to each type of identified threat.
    • Include detailed steps for detection, containment, eradication, recovery, and follow-up of incidents.
  4. Implement Incident Detection and Monitoring:
    • Deploy monitoring tools to detect irregular activities and potential security incidents in real time.
    • Set up alerts and dashboards to ensure rapid identification of threats, enabling swift response actions.
  5. Conduct Regular Training and Drills:
    • Organize regular training sessions for all stakeholders involved in incident response to ensure preparedness.
    • Conduct security drills simulating different types of attacks to test and update response strategies effectively.
  6. Frequent Updates and Reviews:
    • Schedule regular reviews of the incident response plan to incorporate new threats, technologies, and changes in the organizational structure.
    • Update the response plan regularly by learning from past incidents and adapting to evolving security landscapes.

References

  • SAP FSM Security & Data Protection
  • SANS Information Security Policy Templates

countermeasure.name: Enable end-to-end TLS encryption for SAP FSM cloud and mobile communications
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of SAP Field Service Management (FSM) by ensuring encrypted communication, execute the following steps:

  1. Review Current Configuration:
    1. Verify the current TLS version being used on your servers and devices handling FSM components. Ensure that TLS 1.2 or higher is enforced.
    2. Audit all existing integration points, including third-party API connections, to ensure encrypted communication is in place.
  2. Enforce TLS 1.2 or Higher:
    1. Log into your cloud service management console (AWS, Azure, etc.) and navigate to the network settings for your instances running FSM services.
    2. Configure the security policy to reject connections that do not meet the TLS 1.2 or higher requirement.
    3. For field devices using mobile apps, ensure the mobile apps are updated to versions supporting TLS 1.2 or higher. This may require publishing updates on mobile app platforms, such as the App Store or Google Play.
  3. Secure API Communications:
    1. Review API endpoints used for integrations with FSM. Confirm that all communications are conducted over HTTPS.
    2. Implement mutual TLS (mTLS) where possible for API communications to ensure both the client and server validate each other’s certificates before data exchange.
    3. Regularly update SSL/TLS certificates used by API endpoints to avoid expiration which can lead to unprotected connections.
  4. Conduct Penetration Testing:
    1. Schedule regular penetration tests focusing on communication channels within FSM components and third-party integrations.
    2. Address any vulnerabilities found during these tests to strengthen communication security.
  5. Monitor and Update:
    1. Implement monitoring solutions to alert on suspicious connection attempts or potential downgrades in encryption standards.
    2. Stay informed of the latest developments and threats related to TLS vulnerability and encryption techniques, ensuring that your system is updated appropriately in response.

References

  • The Transport Layer Security (TLS) Protocol Version 1.2
  • SAP FSM Security & Data Protection

standard.ref: DE.AE-1: A baseline of network operations and expected data flows for users and systems is established and managed

PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information

countermeasure.name: Enforce federated authentication and role-based access control
countermeasure.desc:
The integration of SAP FSM Federated Authentication with corporate identity providers is a crucial step towards enhancing security by enabling Single Sign-On (SSO). This allows users to authenticate once and gain secure access to the SAP FSM environment and other connected systems. Coupled with Role-Based Access Control (RBAC), SAP FSM can align closely with corporate security policies and enforce the principle of least privilege effectively. Here are the steps to implement these measures:

  1. Evaluate Corporate Identity Providers:
    • Identify and evaluate your existing corporate identity providers that support SSO, like Microsoft Azure AD, Google Workspace, or any SAML 2.0 compliant provider.
    • Ensure that the chosen identity provider can seamlessly integrate with SAP FSM Federated Authentication standards.
  2. Configure SAP FSM Federated Authentication:
    • Access the SAP FSM administration panel with the required administrative privileges.
    • Navigate to the settings for identity and authentication management.
    • Select the federated authentication option and initiate the setup process for SSO integration.
    • Enter the Service Provider details as required by the SAP FSM, which typically include the Assertion Consumer Service (ACS) URL and SP Entity ID.
    • Upload the metadata file or manually input configurations from your identity provider to establish the trust relationship.
    • Test the SSO functionality with a limited access account to verify a smooth transition and identify any integration issues.
  3. Implement and Test RBAC:
    • Define roles within the SAP FSM that align with organizational job functions and responsibilities.
    • Assign specific permissions and access rights to each role based on the principle of least privilege, ensuring users access only necessary functionalities and data.
    • Map users to these roles through the SAP FSM user management interface, regularly reviewing assignments to align with any changes in job roles.
    • Conduct penetration testing and access audits to validate that RBAC configurations effectively limit access to necessary resources.
  4. Regularly Monitor and Update Policies:
    • Establish a routine monitoring process to review authentication logs for suspicious activity and compliance with security policies.
    • Conduct regular updates to authentication and RBAC policies to adapt to evolving security threats and organizational changes.
    • Provide continuous training and awareness programs for end-users on security best practices and new security features within SAP FSM.

Implementing SSO with SAP FSM Federated Authentication and configuring RBAC is a comprehensive approach to enhancing the security posture of your SAP Field Service Management deployment. These steps ensure that users have seamless and secure access while enforcing stringent access controls.

References

  • SAP FSM Federated Authentication Documentation

PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1018 - User Account Management

countermeasure.name: Implement centralized logging and security monitoring for FSM
countermeasure.desc:
Enhancing the security of SAP Field Service Management requires a robust approach to monitoring user activities and interactions, particularly those involving potential threats. This can be effectively achieved by leveraging the audit logging capabilities in SAP FSM set up to track and analyze user and API actions.

  1. Enable Audit Logging:
    • Navigate to the SAP FSM Admin Panel. This requires administrative access for configuration.
    • Under the security settings, locate the 'Audit Logging' section. Ensure the logs are enabled for your desired events such as login attempts, data access, modifications, and API requests.
    • Ensure logging levels are set appropriately to capture sufficient details without overwhelming the system with excessive data. Balance is key.
  2. Configure Alerts for Abnormal Activities:
    • Setup alert rules to notify security personnel of any anomalies such as repeated failed login attempts, unauthorized data exports, or unexpected API requests from unknown sources.
    • Alerts can be configured via the notifications section, where criteria such as IP range, user behavior anomalies, and data volume triggers can be specified.
  3. Integrate with SAP Enterprise Threat Detection:
    • Confirm that your SAP FSM instance is compatible and prepared to integrate with SAP ETD by checking version requirements.
    • Establish a secure connection between SAP FSM and SAP ETD. This process involves configuring network access and data exchange protocols.
    • In SAP ETD, customize threat detection rules to filter and manage log data received from SAP FSM. This enables real-time detection and analysis of security threats.
  4. Review and Test the Implementation:
    • Run a series of simulated scenarios to assess the effectiveness of the logging and alert systems. Include normal, borderline, and extreme cases.
    • Verify that the system generates accurate alerts and that the integration with SAP ETD functions smoothly, capturing anomalies effectively.
    • Regularly review and update logging and alerts settings to adapt to new threats and changes in system usage patterns.

For ensuring consistent effectiveness and staying up-to-date with security best practices, it’s crucial to periodically review your logging and threat detection configurations, making adaptations as necessary based on emerging threats and company policy changes.

References

  • SAP FSM Security & Data Protection
  • SAP Enterprise Threat Detection Documentation

countermeasure.name: Implement data masking and restrict customer data access
countermeasure.desc:
Implementing data masking techniques in SAP Field Service Management (FSM) involves configuring the system to obscure sensitive customer information from non-privileged users while maintaining the necessary data access for users with specific job roles. This approach enhances privacy and limits data exposure risks. The following steps outline the process:

  1. Identify Sensitive Data Fields:
    • Review the data structure contained within your SAP FSM instance to list all fields containing sensitive information, such as customer names, addresses, phone numbers, or payment details.
    • Consult with business units to ensure all critical data elements are identified accurately.
  2. Understand Role-Based Access:
    • Assess the current job roles and responsibilities within your organization, and define which roles require access to sensitive data.
    • Document these roles to facilitate clear definitions in SAP FSM configurations.
  3. Configure Field-Level Security:
    • Access the SAP FSM administrative tools and navigate to the security settings section.
    • Set up field-level security by specifying which fields are to be masked for particular job roles.
    • Create and associate policies that define access rules, specifying read, write, or hidden status for each field based on user roles.
  4. Implement Data Masking:
    • Use SAP FSM's data masking features to obscure sensitive fields for non-privileged users. This may include replacing actual data values with generic values or codes.
    • Ensure that the masked data still allows for proper functioning of user interfaces without revealing confidential information.
    • Regularly test the data masking implementation to verify it is functioning as intended, checking for any potential data leaks or insufficient protections.
  5. Regularly Review and Update Security Policies:
    • Conduct periodic audits of role-based access to ensure that the configurations align with changing organizational roles and responsibilities.
    • Update field-level security measures and data masking configurations to adjust for new data fields or changes in business procedures.

Following these guidelines will help maintain a robust defensive posture against unauthorized data access within SAP FSM, ensuring compliance with data protection regulations.

References

  • SAP FSM Security Guidelines
  • SAP Community Wiki: Security in SAP FSM

countermeasure.name: Secure API authentication and enforce OAuth 2.0 for FSM integrations
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of third-party integrations with SAP Field Service Management (FSM), it is essential to implement OAuth 2.0 for authentication and restrict access via predefined API scopes. Additionally, conducting regular audits of API keys and access permissions is crucial. The following step-by-step guide outlines the implementation process:

  1. Implement OAuth 2.0 Authentication:
    • Begin by understanding the OAuth 2.0 framework. Refer to official documentation for a grasp on the fundamentals of roles such as Resource Owner, Client, Authorization Server, and Resource Server.
    • Configure an Authorization Server capable of handling OAuth 2.0. Common options include solutions like SAP Authorization Service or third-party offerings like Auth0 or Azure AD.
    • In the SAP FSM environment, register each third-party application as an OAuth client. Define client IDs and client secrets for each, ensuring that these credentials are stored securely.
    • Integrate the Authorization Code Flow if user interaction is required or Client Credentials Flow for non-interactive access scenarios.
    • Test the OAuth integration to ensure that tokens are issued correctly and that scopes are respected.
  2. Define and Restrict API Scopes:
    • Analyze the functionalities that each third-party application requires, and define API scopes accordingly.
    • Implement least privilege by granting only the necessary scopes to each client application.
    • Regularly review and update scopes based on the evolving requirements and security policies.
  3. Conduct Regular Audits of API Keys and Access Permissions:
    • Establish a schedule for regular audits, at least quarterly, to review all active API keys and access permissions.
    • Use logging and monitoring tools to detect any anomalies or unauthorized access attempts on API endpoints.
    • Revoke unnecessary or unused API keys promptly to minimize the attack surface.
    • Document any changes made during the audit and update records to reflect current permissions and configurations.
    • Implement alert mechanisms for when changes to API permissions or key usage occur unexpectedly.
  4. Maintain Documentation and Training:
    • Keep detailed documentation of the OAuth 2.0 implementation and API scope configurations.
    • Provide training for development and security teams to handle OAuth configurations and audits efficiently.

Ensuring secure third-party integrations with SAP FSM by following these guidelines helps protect sensitive data and maintain overall system integrity.

References

  • OAuth 2.0 Authorization Framework
  • SAP FSM Product Information
  • Auth0 Documentation
  • Azure AD OAuth 2.0 Documentation

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Lack of monitoring for FSM activities and API usage
threat.desc:
General threat description
Without continuous monitoring, suspicious activities within FSM, such as unauthorized API calls or data exfiltration, may go undetected.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized actors who have gained access to FSM through compromised credentials or system vulnerabilities may execute malicious API calls or extract sensitive data.
Impacts
Potential impacts include unauthorized access to sensitive customer and business data, service disruptions, and loss of data integrity. Financial and reputational damage could also occur due to data breaches.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to the FSM system using stolen credentials and performs API calls to extract client information. Another scenario might involve an internal user who exploits a vulnerability to exfiltrate proprietary data without detection.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1526 - Cloud Service Discovery

threat.name: Insecure API integrations with third-party field service tools
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improperly secured integrations between SAP FSM and external field service management tools can introduce vulnerabilities and allow unauthorized data access.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat actors may exploit weak integrations to gain unauthorized access to sensitive data exchanged between SAP FSM and external tools. This could be achieved through insecure APIs or insufficient authentication mechanisms.
Impacts
Unauthorized access to data can lead to data breaches, exposure of sensitive information, and potentially damage the reputation of the organization. It may also result in financial losses due to compromised data integrity and confidentiality.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker intercepts data transmitted between SAP FSM and a third-party service due to an insecure API connection, enabling them to access confidential customer information. Another scenario involves exploitation of poorly configured authentication settings to gain unauthorized access to integration points between SAP FSM and other field service tools.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1555 - Credentials from Password Stores

threat.name: Unauthorized access to FSM customer data
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improperly configured access controls can lead to unauthorized exposure of sensitive customer information within FSM.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers or unauthorized personnel exploiting weak access configurations to gain access to restricted data.
Impacts
Potential breach of customer confidentiality, legal repercussions, financial loss, and damage to reputation.
Example Attack Scenarios
If access controls are not properly configured, an unauthorized user might query the FSM system and retrieve sensitive customer information without detection.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to FSM applications and mobile services
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized users may exploit weak authentication mechanisms in SAP FSM web applications or mobile services, which may result in data exposure and operational disruption.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Potential attackers include cybercriminals or malicious insiders who can exploit vulnerabilities in the authentication system through brute force attacks or credential stuffing.
Impacts
Such unauthorized access can lead to the exposure of sensitive data, disruption of operations, damage to the organization's reputation, and potential financial losses.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker successfully performs a brute force attack on weak passwords of the SAP FSM system's mobile application, gaining unauthorized access to service data and altering service orders, which causes delays and service disruptions.

threat.name: Insecure data transmission between FSM cloud and mobile devices
threat.desc:
General threat description
Sensitive data transmitted between SAP FSM cloud services and field service engineers' mobile devices could be intercepted if encryption is not enforced.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Cyber attackers who exploit insecure communication channels, such as public or unencrypted Wi-Fi networks, to intercept data transmitted between mobile devices and cloud services.
Impacts
Compromise of sensitive business information, which may include customer details, service records, and personal data. This could lead to unauthorized access, data breaches, and potential regulatory compliance issues.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker uses a Wi-Fi sniffer in a public area to capture unencrypted data as a field service engineer syncs their device with the SAP FSM cloud service. 2. A malicious individual sets up a rogue Wi-Fi hotspot that mimics a legitimate network used by field service engineers, capturing sensitive information transmitted without encryption.

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Weak incident response for FSM security breaches
threat.desc:
General threat description
The absence of a structured incident response plan can result in inefficient handling and resolution of security incidents within SAP Field Service Management, leading to prolonged exposure to potential threats and increased vulnerability.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers may exploit this gap by launching systematic attacks or employing social engineering tactics, knowing that incident response may be sluggish and uncoordinated.
Impacts
Delayed incident response can lead to increased damage from attacks, including data breaches, financial losses, and reputational harm for the organization.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker breaches the system through a known vulnerability and exfiltrates sensitive data over an extended period because the organization fails to detect and respond promptly due to the lack of an effective incident response framework.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Unpatched vulnerabilities in FSM cloud and mobile applications
threat.desc:
General threat description
Attackers could take advantage of unpatched security vulnerabilities present in the SAP Field Service Management (FSM) system components, such as cloud services, mobile applications, or third-party integrations.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
These vulnerabilities may be targeted by malicious actors, including hackers or competitors, who seek to access sensitive data or disrupt services. The attack could originate through various entry points, including network connections, user interfaces, or external integration points.
Impacts
The exploitation of these vulnerabilities could result in unauthorized access to sensitive company data, service disruption, data loss, reputational damage, legal consequences, and financial losses.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker identifies and exploits a vulnerability in the SAP FSM mobile application, gaining access to customer and service data. Alternatively, a third-party integration point with outdated security protocols might be exploited, allowing attackers to inject malicious code into the cloud services, resulting in data theft or manipulation.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-434
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-434: Unrestricted Upload of File with Dangerous Type The product allows the attacker to upload or transfer files of dangerous types that can be automatically processed within the product's environment.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

countermeasure.name: Configure SSL for SAP Fiori
countermeasure.desc:
SAP Fiori is a web-based interface that connects to various SAP applications and databases. Enabling SSL (Secure Sockets Layer) for SAP Fiori can help ensure secure communication between users and the system, as it encrypts data in transit and prevents unauthorized access to sensitive information.

Remediation:
SAP Fiori Client supports HTTP and HTTPS protocols. The application supports Basic authentication and mutual authentication.

If the certificate error dialog appears, this indicates that the certificate authority used by the Fiori server is not trusted by the device. To correct this, determine the certificate authority used and then, if needed, add it to your device's list of trusted certificates as instructed below. Also, the SAP Fiori Client does not operate in an environment where a self-signed SSL certificate is used to configure the Fiori server.

Installing a Certificate on a Windows Device

To install a certificate on a Windows device:
1. To open Certificate Manager, choose Start.
2. Type certmgr.msc into the search box, then choose Enter. If prompted, enter an administrator password or confirmation.
3. Choose the folder into which you want to import the certificate, then choose Action>All Tasks>Import.
4. Choose Next, then follow the instructions.

References:

  • Security Configuration

SC-16 Transmission of Security and Privacy Attributes

countermeasure.name: Implement virus scanning for SAP Fiori
countermeasure.desc:
Virus scanner and scan profiles are vital for SAP Fiori apps that provide the possibility to upload or display documents.
Uploaded documents are displayed in SAP Fiori apps without further security-related checks. If a document contains malicious content, unintended actions could be triggered at the front end during download or display, which might lead to cross-site scripting vulnerabilities. Various SAP Fiori apps offer the possibility to upload or display documents. If you use one of these apps, you have to install an appropriate virus scanner and define sufficiently restrictive scan profiles to prevent upload of malicious content.

Remediation:
Scan Profiles for SAP Fiori Apps

The virus scanner will reject all documents that are not compliant with the rules defined in the settings of the scan profile. These rules need to disallow dangerous MIME types (such as documents with active content like html or javascript).

The documents are checked with a scan profile before being stored in the Knowledge Provider (KPro). The following scan profiles are available for the SAP Fiori apps offering the possibility to upload or display documents:

Area: Standard
Scan Profile: /SCMS/KPRO_CREATE

References:

  • Virus Scanning
