countermeasure.name: Regularly update SAP Fiori launchpad
countermeasure.desc:
SAP Fiori Launchpad is the entry point to SAP Fiori applications and hence it is important to ensure that it is regularly updated. Updating the launchpad with the latest software and security patches can help to fix any known vulnerabilities and ensure that the system is protected against potential threats.

Remediation:
If you have already built and deployed your own SAP Fiori launchpad in an earlier release, you can just update it to the latest version.

To update your own SAP Fiori launchpad, you need to replace the CommonDataModel.json file in your SAP Fiori launchpad project.

Procedure

1. In SAP Web IDE, navigate to your SAP Fiori launchpad project and open the portal folder and then the portal-site subfolder.
2. In the portal-site subfolder, navigate to the CommonDataModel.json file.
3. Download the zip file of the current product SAP Fiori launchpad based on your subscription. For a list with all current SAP Fiori launchpad zip files, see Downloading and Importing Own SAP Fiori Launchpad.
This zip file contains the latest version of the CommonDataModel.json file.
4. Open the downloaded zip file and unzip it.
5. In SAP Web IDE, open the current CommonDataModel.json file and replace the content with the content of the newly downloaded CommonDataModel.json file.
6. Rebuild and redeploy your own SAP Fiori launchpad so that all your changes are applied.

References:

  • Updating Own SAP Fiori Launchpad

standard.ref: Contract Requirements for Service Providers and Contractors (a)
ID.RA-1: Asset vulnerabilities are identified and documented
PR.IP-12: A vulnerability management plan is developed and implemented

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Reverse engineer an executable to expose assumed hidden functionality or content
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
This threat involves attackers reverse engineering a SAP Fiori executable to uncover hidden functionalities or content that were assumed to be concealed. By decompiling or disassembling the binary, adversaries can expose undocumented features, secret configurations, or backdoors that may compromise the security of the application.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Hackers and Competitors: Individuals or organizations aiming to understand internal logic or steal intellectual property.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Static analysis using reverse engineering tools such as IDA Pro or Ghidra.
    • Dynamic analysis with debuggers to observe runtime behavior and uncover hidden code paths.
    • Exploiting debug or diagnostic modes unintentionally left in the executable.

Impacts

  • Exposure of Sensitive Information: Revealed hidden features may disclose confidential configuration details or security flaws.
  • Expanded Attack Surface: Knowledge of undocumented functionalities can enable attackers to craft targeted exploits.
  • Intellectual Property Theft: Competitors may obtain proprietary algorithms or logic, undermining the vendor's competitive advantage.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker downloads the SAP Fiori executable and uses reverse engineering tools to reveal a hidden administrative interface, which is then exploited to gain unauthorized access.
  2. Through static analysis, a hacker identifies an undocumented API endpoint within the executable, allowing them to bypass standard authentication controls.
  3. A competitor reverse engineers the application to extract proprietary algorithms, which are then used to replicate key functionalities in a competing product.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter

threat.name: Attackers could gain access to sensitive data through a man in the middle attack
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
This threat involves an attacker positioning themselves between the SAP Fiori client and server to intercept and potentially alter data during transmission. By exploiting vulnerabilities in the encryption or configuration of secure channels, attackers can capture sensitive information exchanged between users and the system.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Cybercriminals: Hackers who leverage network vulnerabilities to intercept communications.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploiting misconfigured or outdated SSL/TLS settings.
    • Intercepting data on unsecured or poorly secured public Wi-Fi networks.
    • Using techniques such as ARP poisoning or DNS spoofing to reroute traffic through malicious intermediaries.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Sensitive data such as user credentials, session tokens, and confidential information may be exposed.
  • Data Integrity Issues: Attackers might alter data in transit, leading to corrupted or manipulated information.
  • Reputational Damage: Loss of trust from users due to compromised communications.
  • Regulatory Consequences: Potential fines and legal issues if data protection standards are violated.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker sets up a rogue Wi-Fi hotspot near a corporate office, intercepting SAP Fiori communications from employees who unknowingly connect to it.
  2. Exploiting an outdated TLS configuration, an attacker intercepts and decrypts data exchanged between a SAP Fiori client and the server, capturing sensitive session details.
  3. By executing an ARP poisoning attack on a local network, an attacker redirects SAP Fiori traffic through a malicious device, allowing the capture and possible modification of transmitted data.

threat.name: Attackers gain access to unauthorised data by exploiting vulnerabilities in the service
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
In SAP Fiori, this threat involves attackers identifying and exploiting vulnerabilities—such as software bugs, misconfigurations, or unpatched components—to bypass security controls and access restricted data. By leveraging these weaknesses, attackers can retrieve unauthorised data from the service without proper authentication.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Hackers: Utilize automated scanning tools to identify vulnerabilities in the SAP Fiori service and exploit them to gain unauthorised access.
  • Insider Threats: Employees or contractors who misuse their access or inadvertently expose vulnerabilities through misconfigurations.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploitation of unpatched vulnerabilities in the service.
    • Abuse of misconfigured settings or permissions.
    • Injection attacks that bypass authentication or data validation controls.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Exposure of sensitive customer or business data leading to privacy violations.
  • Regulatory Non-Compliance: Potential fines and legal consequences due to failure in protecting confidential information.
  • Reputational Damage: Loss of customer trust and negative publicity resulting from compromised data security.
  • Operational Disruption: Unauthorized data access may lead to service interruptions and impact business processes.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker exploits an unpatched vulnerability in the SAP Fiori service interface, bypassing authentication controls to access confidential customer records.
  2. Automated tools discover a misconfiguration in the service settings, allowing an attacker to retrieve sensitive data from an internal database.
  3. A malicious actor performs an injection attack against an input field in SAP Fiori, successfully extracting unauthorised data stored within the system.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1210 - Exploitation of Remote Services

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-770
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-770: Allocation of Resources Without Limits or Throttling The product allocates a reusable resource or group of resources on behalf of an actor without imposing any restrictions on the size or number of resources that can be allocated, in violation of the intended security policy for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-89
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-89: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an SQL Command ('SQL Injection') The product constructs all or part of an SQL command using externally-influenced input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could modify the intended SQL command when it is sent to a downstream component.

countermeasure.name: Enforce secure communication with SNC and TLS
countermeasure.desc:
Secure Network Communication (SNC) Configuration for SAP GUI

  1. Log in to the SAP system with a user that has administrative privileges.
  2. Navigate to the SAP NetWeaver Administrator and access the Configuration tab.
  3. Search for SNC parameters. To locate them, use the transaction code RZ11.
  4. Ensure the parameter snc/enable is set to a value of 1, indicating that SNC is enabled.
  5. Check the parameter snc/gssapi_lib and make sure it points to the correct library path of the cryptographic library that supports SNC.
  6. Enter the transaction code SU01 and select user profiles to add the SNC name under the SNC tab of the user master record.
  7. For user-based configuration, ensure that each user's SNC name is correctly mapped and that the SNC attribute is set to secured if necessary.

TLS 1.2+ Enforcement for HTTP/HTTPS

  1. Open SAP NetWeaver Administrator and navigate to Configuration Management > Security > SSL.
  2. Identify and edit the SSL provider responsible for HTTP/HTTPS connections.
  3. In the SSL Management area, ensure that the Supported Protocols field only includes TLSv1.2 and above.
  4. Disable older versions by removing them from the list of supported protocols.

Regularly Update Cryptographic Libraries and Disable Weak Cipher Suites

  1. Periodically review updates from SAP on cryptographic libraries and apply new patches/releases as they become available.
  2. Update the security configuration through SAP Support Portal to obtain the latest library versions compatible with your SAP NetWeaver installation.
  3. To disable weak cipher suites, access the Access and Connectivity settings in SAP NetWeaver Administrator.
  4. Select View SSL configurations and uncheck cipher suites considered weak, such as those based on RC4 or DES.
  5. Test the SSL configuration to verify that only strong cipher suites are available for use in connections.

References

  • SAP NetWeaver Documentation
  • Using TLS or SSL on SAP NetWeaver AS ABAP

standard.ref: DE.AE-1: A baseline of network operations and expected data flows for users and systems is established and managed
ID.AM-3: Organizational communication and data flows are mapped
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected
SC-16 Transmission of Security and Privacy Attributes

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information

countermeasure.name: Enforce secure development and code validation
countermeasure.desc:
To strengthen the security posture of the SAP NetWeaver Application Server, follow these detailed steps to implement the proposed countermeasures:

  1. Utilize SAP Code Vulnerability Analyzer:
    1. Access the SAP Code Vulnerability Analyzer tool available within your SAP environment.
    2. Run an initial scan of all custom ABAP and Java applications to identify existing security vulnerabilities. Ensure your environment is configured to permit scanning of all relevant code repositories.
    3. Review the scan report generated by the Vulnerability Analyzer to understand the existing vulnerabilities.
    4. Prioritize the vulnerabilities based on severity and potential impact.
  2. Implement Strict Input Validation:
    1. Identify all input fields within your ABAP/Java applications where user data is processed.
    2. Develop comprehensive input validation routines that include checking for appropriate data types, limiting input length, and rejecting any illegal characters or patterns.
    3. Integrate the input validation routines into your application's codebase and ensure it is applied consistently across all input fields.
    4. Conduct user acceptance testing to confirm that the input validation does not interfere with legitimate user activities.
  3. Use Parameterized Queries:
    1. Review all database interactions, especially where user input is integrated into SQL statements to identify instances of dynamic query construction.
    2. Refactor these SQL statements to use parameterized queries, thereby separating SQL logic from user input and mitigating SQL injection risks.
    3. Test the refactored queries in a staging environment to ensure they return accurate results and maintain application functionality.
  4. Regularly Apply SAP Security Patches:
    1. Subscribe to SAP's security advisory notifications to stay informed about new patch releases.
    2. Establish a patch management process within your organization, defining roles and responsibilities for assessing, prioritizing, and applying SAP security patches.
    3. Schedule regular patch windows to minimize disruption and allow safe implementation of the updates.
    4. After applying patches, perform regression testing and monitor your system for any anomalies post-patch application.

By following these guidelines, you can systematically address potential security concerns within your SAP NetWeaver Application Server environment. Implementing these countermeasures will also help ensure the integrity, confidentiality, and availability of your critical business applications.

References

  • SAP Code Security Guide

standard.ref: Contract Requirements for Service Providers and Contractors (a)
ID.RA-1: Asset vulnerabilities are identified and documented
PR.IP-12: A vulnerability management plan is developed and implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1013 - Application Developer Guidance

countermeasure.name: Enforce strong authentication and authorization policies
countermeasure.desc:
1. Implement Strong Password Policies:
    1. Navigate to the SAP NetWeaver Administrator console.
    2. Go to Security > Authentication > Policies.
    3. Create a new password policy or modify an existing one to enforce:
      • A minimum password length of at least 8 characters.
      • Use of alphanumeric characters and at least one special character.
      • A mechanism for preventing the re-use of the last five passwords (password history).
      • Mandatory password expiration within 90 days.
    4. Save and apply the policy changes.
  2. Enforce Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA):
    1. Access the SAP Identity Management (IdM) console.
    2. Under Identity Services, configure MFA by choosing an MFA provider compatible with SAP NetWeaver.
    3. Integrate the MFA solution by following the configuration guide provided by your chosen vendor.
    4. Designate critical users and roles who require MFA, typically those with access to sensitive data or high-level administrative functions.
    5. Test the configuration with a pilot group before rolling it out to all critical users.
  3. Restrict Access to Sensitive Transactions via SAP RBAC:
    1. Conduct an audit of existing role assignments to identify high-risk transactions.
    2. Use the SAP Role Management tool to create or modify custom roles with precise access requirements.
    3. Implement role hierarchy to ensure least privilege access.
    4. Utilize the SAP Access Control solution to automatically check for Segregation of Duties (SoD) conflicts.
    5. Regularly review role and access assignments at least quarterly to ensure conformity with organizational policies.
  4. Regular Review and Removal of Inactive User Accounts:
    1. Set up periodic reporting and alerts for user accounts that have been inactive for a specific period, such as 90 days, using the SAP User Information System (SUIM).
    2. Review inactive accounts to determine ownership and necessity.
    3. Validate with department managers whether these accounts are required for business operations.
    4. Safely deactivate and document the deactivation process of unnecessary accounts in a change log.
    5. Ensure all deletions or deactivations comply with organizational data retention and privacy policies.

References

  • SAP Security Guide - User Authentication
  • Administering SAP NetWeaver Application Server Using AS ABAP - SAP Community
  • SAP Support Portal - Knowledge Base

standard.ref: Consumers Less Than Under 13 Years of Age (c)
PR.AC-1: Identities and credentials are issued, managed, verified, revoked, and audited for authorized devices, users and processes
PR.AC-6: Identities are proofed and bound to credentials and asserted in interactions

PR.AC-7: Users, devices, and other assets are authenticated (e.g., single-factor, multi-factor) commensurate with the risk of the transaction (e.g., individuals' security and privacy risks and other organizational risks)

countermeasure.name: Implement network and application-layer DoS protection
countermeasure.desc:
• Implement SAP Web Dispatcher and Firewalls:
    1. Download and install the latest version of SAP Web Dispatcher from the SAP Software Downloads website.
    2. Configure SAP Web Dispatcher as a reverse proxy by setting the "icm/HTTP/redirect_" parameters to direct incoming requests to the appropriate SAP NetWeaver Application Server instance.
    3. Define filter rules in the Web Dispatcher's configuration to block or allow traffic based on IP addresses, URLs, or other request characteristics. Use the "Security Rules" section in the SAP Web Dispatcher profile to achieve this.
    4. Integrate SAP Web Dispatcher with your firewall to reinforce the filtering mechanism. Configure firewall policies to allow only specific traffic to and from the Web Dispatcher.
    5. Regularly update the firewall rules and Web Dispatcher configuration to adapt to emerging threats and newly identified vulnerabilities.
  • Enable SAP NetWeaver Workload Management:
    1. Access the SAP NetWeaver Administrator console using a user account with administrative privileges.
    2. Navigate to the "Configuration Management" section and select "Workload Management."
    3. Enable workload management by checking the corresponding options to activate resource usage controls.
    4. Configure resource limits and threshold values for system resources such as CPU, memory, and network bandwidth based on the expected load and criticality of the services.
    5. Implement monitoring processes to continuously assess resource usage and adjust configurations as necessary to prevent resource exhaustion and maintain performance.
  • Implement Rate-Limiting Policies on External-Facing Services:
    1. Identify all external-facing services hosted on the SAP NetWeaver Application Server that are exposed to end users or third-party systems.
    2. Within the SAP NetWeaver Administrator, define rate-limiting policies for each of the identified services. This involves setting the maximum number of allowable requests per time interval from a single client IP or session.
    3. Configure rate-limiting parameters using SAP NetWeaver's capability to throttle and buffer excessive request rates, ensuring smooth operation and protecting against denial of service attacks.
    4. Test the effectiveness of the rate-limiting policies by simulating high-traffic scenarios to ensure that legitimate traffic is maintained while throttling excessive requests.
    5. Continuously monitor service logs and analytics dashboards to detect patterns that may indicate the need for policy adjustments or additional protective measures.

References

  • SAP Security Hardening Guide
  • SAP Software Downloads
  • Firewall Best Practices for SAP Environments

standard.ref: DE.CM-1: The network is monitored to detect potential cybersecurity events
PR.DS-4: Adequate capacity to ensure availability is maintained
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1031 - Network Intrusion Prevention

countermeasure.name: Regularly apply SAP security patches and harden configurations
countermeasure.desc:
1. Subscribe to SAP EarlyWatch Alert: Begin by subscribing to the SAP EarlyWatch Alert service. This service will provide you with important reports regarding the performance, stability, and security aspects of your SAP systems.
    • Access the SAP Service Marketplace and log in using your credentials.
    • Navigate to the 'EarlyWatch Alert' section and complete the subscription process to receive regular alerts.
  2. Utilize SAP Security Notes: Proactively monitor SAP Security Notes to stay informed about new vulnerabilities and their corresponding security patches.
    • Regularly visit the SAP Support Portal and check the 'Security Notes' section.
    • Set up automatic notifications or alerts for new notes that apply to your version of SAP NetWeaver AS.
  3. Schedule Regular Security Patch Applications: Develop and maintain a patch management schedule.
    • Review the SAP Patch Day, held monthly, and integrate the patch announcements into your patch schedule.
    • Test patches in a non-production environment before rolling them out to prevent disruptions.
    • Document and track the implementation of updates using a change management system.
  4. Disable Unnecessary Services: Reduce the attack surface by disabling services that are not in use.
    • Conduct a thorough review of services running on your SAP servers.
    • Disable services that are not required for your specific environment, adhering to the principle of least privilege.
  5. Follow SAP Security Configuration Guidelines: Implement security policies and hardening measures as specified by SAP's configuration guidelines.
    • Access SAP's documentation on security configurations applicable to your NetWeaver AS version.
    • Apply recommended settings such as secure parameter selections, password policies, and network configurations.
    • Document the configurations applied and periodically review them for compliance with evolving standards.

References

  • SAP Security Notes
  • SAP NetWeaver 7.5 Documentation

standard.ref: Contract Requirements for Service Providers and Contractors (a)
ID.RA-1: Asset vulnerabilities are identified and documented
PR.IP-12: A vulnerability management plan is developed and implemented

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Denial-of-service (DoS) attacks
threat.desc:
General threat description
Attackers can exploit the SAP NetWeaver Application Server by flooding it with an overwhelming number of requests, causing disruption of service and degradation in performance.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors may use automated tools to generate high volumes of traffic targeting the SAP NetWeaver Application Server, possibly utilizing distributed networks or botnets to intensify the attack.
Impacts
Legitimate users may experience significant delays, denial of access to services, or complete unavailability of the application due to the server being unable to handle the excessive load.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker could initiate a distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attack through a botnet to continuously send superfluous requests to the application server, effectively exhausting system resources and causing a slowdown or shutdown of services, thereby impacting business operations and user accessibility.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Exploitation of outdated or misconfigured SAP services
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unattended updates or weaknesses in configuration setups can be leveraged by unscrupulous entities to intrude into systems or cause operational interruptions.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Exploitation by malicious insiders or external hackers who discover vulnerabilities through unaddressed service patches or incorrect settings.
Impacts
This may result in unauthorized data access, potential data manipulation, and increased downtime due to disrupted services.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker could identify and target a specific unpatched service of the SAP NetWeaver Application Server, executing scripts that provide them access to sensitive data; Alternatively, by exploiting incorrect system configurations, they may introduce network disturbances resulting in prolonged service outages.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

threat.name: Unauthorized access to SAP NetWeaver
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized individuals could infiltrate the SAP NetWeaver Application Server due to insufficient authentication measures or improperly set user roles, risking data exposure and improper access level upgrade.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers may exploit weak login credentials or gaps in role configurations to penetrate the system and elevate their access rights without proper authorization.
Impacts
The integrity, confidentiality, and availability of sensitive business data may be compromised, resulting in financial losses and operational disruption.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker guesses a weak password or utilizes default credentials to log into the system and modifies their role privileges to gain access to restricted areas and confidential information.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Insecure network communication
threat.desc:
General threat description
Data transmitted between SAP NetWeaver Application Server and clients or integrated systems is vulnerable to interception or modification when encryption mechanisms are improperly configured.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers may exploit network vulnerabilities, using techniques such as man-in-the-middle attacks or packet sniffing to access unencrypted data.
Impacts
Unauthorized access to sensitive data, potential data breaches, integrity loss of data, and compliance violations.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker monitors network traffic between an SAP server and a client, intercepting unencrypted login credentials, which are then used to gain unauthorized access to the system.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Code injection via custom SAP applications
threat.desc:
General threat description
Poorly developed or unvalidated custom applications deployed on SAP NetWeaver can introduce serious vulnerabilities. These vulnerabilities may include forms of SQL injection or operating system command execution, which can provide attackers with the ability to manipulate system behavior to their advantage.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unsophisticated validation during the development and deployment of custom applications could allow malicious actors to craft input that exploits these vulnerabilities, thus granting them unauthorized access or the ability to execute arbitrary commands on the host operating system.
Impacts
The exploitation of these vulnerabilities could lead to unauthorized access to sensitive data, system compromise, data integrity issues, or denial of service. This could further escalate to financial losses as well as reputational damage to the organization utilizing the SAP system.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker submits specially crafted input into a web form that is not properly validated, resulting in a SQL injection that exfiltrates sensitive data from the database. Alternatively, a threat actor might exploit a flawed script in a custom application to execute commands on the underlying OS, compromising the entire server.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-352
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-352: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) The web application does not, or can not, sufficiently verify whether a well-formed, valid, consistent request was intentionally provided by the user who submitted the request. When a web server is designed to receive a request from a client without any mechanism for verifying that it was intentionally sent, then it might be possible for an attacker to trick a client into making an unintentional request to the web server which will be treated as an authentic request. This can be done via a URL, image load, XMLHttpRequest, etc. and can result in exposure of data or unintended code execution.

countermeasure.name: Configure support for SNC components in SAP NetWeaver Gateway
countermeasure.desc:
Configuring support for Secure Network Communication (SNC) components in SAP Gateway provides enhanced security by allowing only SNC connections and enforcing the use of encryption for communication. By enabling this feature, non-SNC connections are restricted, ensuring that only secure connections are accepted by the gateway.

Remediation:
To configure support for SNC components in SAP Gateway:

Use
The parameter snc/enablespecifies whether the gateway is to support SNC (see Gateway and SNC Interface). If this parameter is deactivated ( snc/enable = 0, default value), no SNC connections are accepted.

If this parameter is activated ( snc/enable = 1), only SNC connections are accepted.

The gateway checks whether connections to non-SNC programs are permitted. If the parameter snc/permit_insecure_start = 1, connections to non-SNC programs are permitted.

Prerequisites
The gateway specifies its own path name for the SNC library in the command line parameter. If the program you want to start is running on the same host, the environment variable SNC_LIB does not need to be set. If it isn't, the environment variable SNC_LIB does need to be set in the relevant login shell or in the user environment. This variable specifies the respective shared library of the security product that is being used.

Procedure
Define the relevant parameters and environment variables.

The SNC parameters are described in Parameterization of the SAPGatewayunder SNC Parameters.

Using SAProuter to Secure the Connection Between Two Gateways

Alternatively you can secure the channel between gateways of different SAP Systems by using two SAProuters (gateway1 - SAProuter1 - SAProuter2 - gateway2), which encrypt and de-encrypt the datastream by SNC. Then you do not need to configure the system for SNC.

References:

  • Configuring Support of SNC Components

standard.ref: PR.AC-5: Network integrity is protected (e.g., network segregation, network segmentation)
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1057 - Data Loss Prevention

countermeasure.name: Setup access control lists (ACL) for SAP NetWeaver Gateway
countermeasure.desc:
Setting up Access Control Lists (ACL) for SAP Gateway allows you to control the acceptance and denial of connections based on IP addresses. By implementing ACL, you can enhance the security of the gateway by explicitly permitting or denying specific client connections. Without ACL, the gateway will accept all connection requests, potentially exposing it to unauthorized access.

Remediation:
To set up ACL for SAP Gateway, follow these steps:

1. Create an ACL file using the syntax described below.
2. In the instance profile of the gateway instance you set parameter gw/acl_file to the file path of the ACL file.

Caution
If this parameter is not set, the gateway accepts all connection requests.

Syntax of the ACL File

Lines in the ACL must have the following syntax:
[tracelevel] 1

Where,

- permit = permits a connection, and deny = denies a connection.

- : The IP address must be an IPv4 or IPv6 address in the following form:

IPv4: 4 byte, decimal, '.' separated: e.g. 10.11.12.13

IPv6: 16 byte, hexadecimal, ':' separated. '::' is supported

- : If a mask is specified, it must be a subnetwork prefix mask:

IPv4: 0-32

IPv6: 0-128

- : Trace level, with which ACL hits (matches of addresses based on the subnetwork mask) are written to the relevant trace file (default value 2).

- <# comment> : Comment lines begin with a hash sign ( # ).

- The file can contain blank lines.

- As the last rule a general ban is inserted automatically.

To make it obvious, an explicit deny should be entered anyway as the last rule. The rules are checked sequentially from the "top down" . The first relevant rule determines the result ( "first match" ).

References:

  • Setting Up Access Control Lists (ACL)

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.PT-3: The principle of least functionality is incorporated by configuring systems to provide only essential capabilities

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1052 - User Account Control

countermeasure.name: Set up Gateway logging for SAP NetWeaver Gateway
countermeasure.desc:
Gateway logging plays a crucial role in monitoring and maintaining the activities of SAP Gateway. By configuring and enabling gateway logging, administrators can track and record various gateway actions, providing valuable insights for troubleshooting, auditing, and security analysis, ensuring transparency and accountability in SAP Gateway operations.

Remediation:
You can set up the logging in profile parameter gw/logging or in the gateway monitor (transaction SMGW ). SAP recommends the following configuration for the gateway monitor.

1. Call the gateway monitor (from the menu or in transaction SMGW )
2. Choose Goto > Expert Functions > Logging.
3. Define a name for the log. To do this enter a name in the File Name field where you can set the specified time stamp variables. The default setting is gw_log-%y-%m-%d . The file will then be called gw_log-2007-06-19.
4. Choose the gateway actions that you wan to log in the log file
For the complete table please see Reference URL.
5. Choose the Toggle Criteria (in the lower section of the screen). You can configure the following:
- Time-Controlled Toggle : You can specify a time period after which a new file is opened. Possible values are no toggle, and toggle after one hour, one day, or one year.
- Maximum File Size (kByte) : You can set the maximum size of the file (specified in kilobytes). If the log file exceeds this size, the file is closed and a new one opened. A new file name is assigned provided you use the timestamp variables when you name the file (see above).
- Specify Old File : You select this checkbox to prevent a new file being created. The old file is then overwritten when the time-controlled toggle condition is applied or when the maximum file size is exceeded.
6. Select Activate to accept your settings.

Caution
The settings you make here are saved in the shared memory of the instance. They are retained when the gateway is restarted. However, if the whole instance is closed down, the settings are lost. If you want to make general logging settings, you have to set parameter gw/logging in the profile file.

Recommendation
You can set the profile parameter as follows:

gw/logging=ACTION=SPXLOGFILE=gw_log_$(SAPSYSTEMNAME)_$(SAPLOCALHOST)-%y&m%d SWITCHTF=day

Then signals, profile parameter changes, and security actions will always be logged, and if required, you can also extend the logging as described above.

References:

  • Setting Up Gateway Logging

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Attackers try to take advantage of a wide attack surface
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat involves exploiting the extensive exposure and multiple endpoints inherent in SAP NetWeaver Gateway. With a broad interface available for connectivity, any misconfigurations, unpatched vulnerabilities, or default settings can provide attackers with numerous potential entry points to compromise the system.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Threat Agents: External hackers, cybercriminal groups, opportunistic attackers, and script kiddies.
  • Attack Vectors: Automated scanning for open ports and endpoints, exploitation of unpatched vulnerabilities, brute force attacks on administrative interfaces, and leveraging misconfigurations or default credentials.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive data and system functionalities.
  • Lateral movement within the network, potentially leading to broader system compromises.
  • Operational disruptions, downtime, and degradation of service performance.
  • Reputational damage and legal consequences stemming from data breaches.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. Automated Reconnaissance: An attacker deploys automated tools to scan the SAP NetWeaver Gateway for open and misconfigured endpoints, eventually discovering one with weak authentication. This weakness is then exploited to gain unauthorized access and extract sensitive data.
  2. Targeted Exploit: An attacker identifies a known vulnerability in one of the exposed APIs of the Gateway, crafts a targeted exploit, and uses it to bypass security controls, leading to unauthorized system modifications or data exfiltration.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Attackers gain access to the system and are not detected
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat involves attackers infiltrating the SAP NetWeaver Gateway without triggering any detection mechanisms. The attackers establish covert access, allowing them to operate within the system for an extended period while avoiding traditional monitoring and logging systems.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Threat Agents: Advanced persistent threat groups, sophisticated cybercriminals, and malicious insiders.
  • Attack Vectors: Exploiting unpatched vulnerabilities, using stealth malware, leveraging compromised credentials, and bypassing or disabling security monitoring tools to avoid detection.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to system functions and sensitive data over an extended period.
  • Increased risk of data manipulation, exfiltration, and further compromise of connected systems.
  • Delayed response and remediation efforts due to the stealthy nature of the intrusion.
  • Significant operational, financial, and reputational damage as a result of prolonged undetected access.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. Stealth Vulnerability Exploit: An attacker exploits a zero-day vulnerability in the SAP NetWeaver Gateway, deploying a low-profile backdoor that disables standard logging mechanisms. This enables ongoing data extraction without alerting system administrators.
  2. Insider-Assisted Intrusion: A trusted employee with elevated privileges intentionally or inadvertently provides access to external attackers. The attackers then install custom malware designed to avoid detection, gradually accumulating sensitive information over time.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Attackers could gain access to sensitive data through a man in the middle attack
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat involves an attacker intercepting or altering the communication between SAP NetWeaver Gateway and its connected clients or backend systems. By positioning themselves between the legitimate endpoints, attackers can capture sensitive data, modify messages, or inject malicious content without the knowledge of either party.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Threat Agents: External cybercriminals, state-sponsored actors, and sophisticated hackers.
  • Attack Vectors: Exploiting unsecured or poorly encrypted network connections, utilizing ARP poisoning, DNS spoofing, or setting up rogue network devices to intercept and manipulate traffic.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized disclosure of sensitive data such as credentials, financial records, or proprietary information.
  • Compromised data integrity, leading to potential system manipulation or fraudulent activities.
  • Loss of trust in the security of the network communications, potentially affecting overall system reliability.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. Rogue Access Point Deployment: An attacker sets up a rogue access point within the corporate network vicinity. Unsuspecting users connect to this network, and the attacker intercepts the data traffic between SAP NetWeaver Gateway and its clients, capturing sensitive information.
  2. ARP Spoofing Attack: An attacker leverages ARP spoofing within a local network, redirecting the communication flow between the SAP NetWeaver Gateway and its connected systems through a malicious intermediary that decrypts and logs confidential data before passing it on.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

countermeasure.name: Restrict access to the URL/path of OData content
countermeasure.desc:
1. Identify OData Service Endpoints: Begin by cataloging all the SAP OData service endpoints and the corresponding URLs or paths. This ensures you have a comprehensive list of all points where access controls need to be implemented. This can be achieved through inspection of the SAP NetWeaver Gateway or a similar infrastructure monitoring tool that provides endpoint visibility.
  2. Define Access Control Policies: Work with business stakeholders to define the access control policies for each OData endpoint. These policies should specify which users or roles are permitted to access or modify the data. Ensure these policies adhere to the principle of least privilege, allowing only the necessary level of access.
  3. Implement Role-Based Access Controls (RBAC): In your SAP system, configure role-based access controls to enforce the defined policies. SAP's User Management Engine (UME) offers capabilities to assign roles and permissions to users, which in turn can be mapped to specific OData service endpoints. Navigate to SAP NetWeaver Administrator, and configure UME roles ensuring they align with the access policies.
  4. Use Secure OAuth Tokens: For enhanced security, implement OAuth for user authentication and authorization. Configure OAuth tokens with scopes that restrict access to authorized endpoints. This provides a mechanism for an additional layer of access control at the API level. Refer to SAP Help Portal for guidance on integrating OAuth with SAP services.
  5. Encrypt Communications: Implement HTTPS to encrypt data in transit between the client and server. This helps to prevent unauthorized interception or modification of data. Configure SAP’s Internet Communication Manager (ICM) to enforce HTTPS using SSL/TLS certificates.
  6. Audit and Monitor Access: Establish logging and monitoring to track access to OData services. This involves configuring SAP Solution Manager to record access logs, and such logs should be reviewed on a regular basis to detect possible unauthorized access attempts.
  7. Regularly Update and Patch: Ensure that your SAP systems, including all OData services, are kept up to date with the latest security patches. Regular updates help to mitigate known vulnerabilities that could be exploited for unauthorized access.
  8. Conduct Periodic Security Assessments: Regularly conduct security assessments and penetration testing to identify and rectify potentially overlooked vulnerabilities in the OData service configurations.

References

  • SAP Help Portal: OAuth 2.0 Authorization Framework
  • SAP Security Guide

countermeasure.name: Restrict authorization to start OData Service
countermeasure.desc:
Step-by-Step Implementation for Restricting Access to SAP OData Services

  1. Define Access Control Policies: Begin by outlining clear access control policies that specify which users or roles should have the permission to initiate SAP OData services. Consider business requirements and least privilege principles while defining these policies.
  2. Role-Based Access Control (RBAC): Utilize the Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) method within SAP to enforce the defined policies. Ensure each user is assigned to the appropriate role that grants them access to initiate SAP OData services. Roles should be reviewed regularly to align with the organizational structure and access requirements.
  3. Implement SAP Gateway Security Settings: Configure SAP Gateway to enforce these policies. This includes setting up trust relationships and enabling Secure Network Communications (SNC) to protect user credentials during authentication.
  4. Enable OAuth 2.0 for Authentication: Implement OAuth 2.0 for authentication to support secure and standardized access token-based authentication for OData services access. This ensures that only authenticated users can initiate services with tokens that have specific scopes matching their roles.
  5. Deploy Logging and Monitoring: Enable verbose logging of access requests to SAP OData services and monitor these logs for any unauthorized access attempts. Implement Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) tools to automatically detect anomalies in access patterns.
  6. Regular Access Review and Audits: Schedule regular audits of access logs and review user role assignments periodically. It’s crucial to identify and rectify any inappropriate access that may have been granted, particularly when employee roles change or when they leave the organization.
  7. Educate and Train Users: Conduct regular training sessions to ensure users understand the security policies in place, including appropriate use of credentials and safeguarding of authentication tokens.

References

  • SAP Gateway Documentation
  • Introduction to Role-Based Access Control in SAP

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1025 - Privileged Process Integrity

countermeasure.name: Restrict user select authorization for OData services
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of SAP OData services by limiting user authorizations, follow the detailed steps below to ensure that only authorized personnel can access specific functionalities:

  1. Identify the Sensitive Functionalities:
    • Conduct a comprehensive review of the SAP OData services to identify all functionalities and data that require restricted access based on your organization's security policy.
    • Collaborate with business stakeholders to determine which user roles need access to these functionalities.
  2. Configure Authorization Objects:
    • Access the SAP system using a suitable role that allows authorization configuration.
    • Navigate to the SAP transaction code PFCG (Role Maintenance) to define or modify user roles.
    • Create or choose existing authorization objects that match the identified sensitive functionalities.
    • Ensure that these authorization objects are updated to include permissions aligned with business requirements and security policies.
  3. Assign Authorization Profiles:
    • Use PFCG to assign the newly configured or updated authorization objects to specific user roles.
    • Ensure that each role is assigned the minimum permissions required to perform the necessary business tasks (Principle of Least Privilege).
    • Use the Role Administration menu to generate profiles for these roles and ensure they are active.
  4. Testing and Verification:
    • Perform thorough testing by simulating user access with different roles to validate that roles and authorizations are correctly implemented.
    • Verify that unauthorized attempts to access restricted functionalities are denied and properly logged.
  5. Implement Continuous Monitoring and Review:
    • Set up a regular review process for role and authorization assignments, adjusting as necessary to reflect changes in job functions or security requirements.
    • Use SAP's built-in audit and logging tools to monitor access and identify any unusual patterns or potential security breaches.
    • Ensure that any changes in business processes or IT infrastructure that could impact authorizations trigger a review of the affected roles.

References

  • SAP Authorization Concept
  • SAP Community - Security

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Privilege abuse
threat.desc:
General threat description
Granting excessive privileges to users may result in unauthorized access or manipulation of sensitive information within the SAP OData service.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious insiders or external attackers who manage to exploit users with excessive privileges can act as threat agents. This can occur through social engineering, phishing attacks, or exploiting vulnerabilities in authentication mechanisms.
Impacts
Unauthorized data access and modification can lead to data breaches, integrity issues, financial loss, reputational damage, and non-compliance with data protection regulations.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker could impersonate a user with excessive privileges to exfiltrate sensitive business data or modify key business information to disrupt operations. Alternatively, an employee with more access than required might inadvertently change critical data, leading to data corruption or loss.

weakness.name: CWE-20
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-20: Improper Input Validation The product receives input or data, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input has the properties that are required to process the data safely and correctly.

weakness.name: CWE-233
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-233: Improper Handling of Parameters The product does not properly handle when the expected number of parameters, fields, or arguments is not provided in input, or if those parameters are undefined.

weakness.name: CWE-259
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-259: Use of Hard-coded Password The product contains a hard-coded password, which it uses for its own inbound authentication or for outbound communication to external components.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

countermeasure.name: Enforce encrypted communication for all integrations
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of SAP Process Orchestration, it is critical to ensure that all integration endpoints utilize encrypted channels. Follow these step-by-step instructions to configure secure communication channels:

  1. Identify Integration Endpoints:
    • List all endpoints involved in your SAP Process Orchestration landscape. This may include web services, RFC destinations, and other third-party integrations.
  2. Enable HTTPS for Web Services:
    • Navigate to the SAP NetWeaver Administrator.
    • Under the Configuration tab, access the security settings.
    • Set up HTTPS by configuring SSL with the appropriate certificates.
    • Enable and enforce HTTPS-only communication for relevant services.
  3. Implement TLS 1.2/1.3:
    • Access the Java NetWeaver settings and configure the ICM (Internet Communication Manager) parameters to support TLS 1.2 or 1.3.
    • Update the server-default.xml configuration file to reflect TLS version requirements.
    • Test the compatibility of your endpoints with the selected TLS protocols.
  4. Configure SNC for Internal Communication:
    • Identify internal communication channels that can benefit from SNC.
    • Install and configure the SAP Cryptographic Library on each relevant server.
    • Set up SNC parameters in the instance profiles and SAP GUI to enforce secure network communication.
  5. Regularly Audit Encryption Configurations:
    • Establish a schedule for periodic review of encryption settings.
    • Create automation scripts or use available SAP tools to check compliance with the latest security standards.
    • Log the audit results and take corrective measures promptly if discrepancies or outdated configurations are found.

By following these steps, you can significantly bolster the security integrity of data exchanged across your SAP Process Orchestration environment, protecting it from unauthorized access and interception.

References

  • Security aspects of process orchestration
  • SAP Knowledge Base

countermeasure.name: Enforce least privilege access and secure authentication
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of SAP Process Orchestration, the implementation of a robust role-based access control (RBAC) and strong authentication mechanisms is essential. This countermeasure aims to restrict access based on job responsibilities, enforce multi-factor authentication (MFA) for heightened security, and ensure user permissions are regularly reviewed and compliant with established policies.

Step-by-Step Implementation Guidance:

  1. Define Roles and Permissions:
    1. Start by identifying all the roles within your organization that interact with the SAP Process Orchestration system.
    2. Collaborate with business stakeholders and IT security teams to define the specific permissions each role should have based on their job functions and responsibilities.
    3. Document these roles and permissions in alignment with your organization's security policies.
  2. Implement Role-Based Access Control:
    1. Access the SAP NetWeaver Administration console.
    2. Navigate to the user management module and utilize the role maintenance section to create the defined roles.
    3. Assign the appropriate permissions to each role ensuring that they are restricted to the minimum necessary access required for their job functions.
  3. Enforce Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA):
    1. Ensure that MFA is enabled for all administrative and high-privileged user accounts to protect sensitive operations.
    2. Configure MFA by integrating a secure authentication service provider that supports commonly used methods, such as authentication apps or hardware tokens.
  4. Regularly Review User Permissions:
    1. Establish a schedule for the periodic review of user roles and permissions. This review should ideally occur quarterly or in response to significant changes in job roles or responsibilities.
    2. Utilize SAP's audit tools to generate reports on current user access rights and verify they align with documented security policies.
    3. Make any necessary adjustments to user access rights based on these reviews to ensure compliance and address any security gaps.

By methodically applying these steps, organizations can significantly reduce the risk of unauthorized access and strengthen the security posture of their SAP Process Orchestration environment.

References

  • SAP NetWeaver Security Guide
  • SAP Help Portal
  • SAP Security Optimization Self-Service
  • SAP Community

countermeasure.name: Implement continuous monitoring and anomaly detection
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security posture of SAP Process Orchestration, it is crucial to enable comprehensive logging for all integration events and transactions. Integrating these logs with a Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) system will facilitate real-time anomaly detection and alerting. Below is a step-by-step guide to implementing this security countermeasure:

  1. Access the SAP NetWeaver Administrator:
    • Log in to your SAP system using authorized credentials.
    • Navigate to the SAP NetWeaver Administrator portal, typically accessible via a web browser with the appropriate URL.
  2. Configure SAP Security Audit Log:
    • In the SAP NetWeaver Administrator, go to the "Operations" section.
    • Select "Logging and Tracing" -> "Logs and Traces Configuration."
    • Set up the security audit log by defining what events should be logged. Make sure to include integration events specific to SAP Process Orchestration.
    • Ensure that the security audit log is configured to collect sufficient data to trace integration transactions and detect anomalous activity.
  3. Integrate with a SIEM Tool:
    • Select a SIEM tool that suits your organization's needs and has compatibility with SAP systems. Popular choices include Splunk, IBM QRadar, or ArcSight.
    • Configure your SAP system to forward logs to the SIEM tool. This often involves using SAP-supported interfaces or connectors to the SIEM platform.
    • Ensure the integration handles the secure transmission of logs, including encryption and authentication mechanisms.
  4. Setup Automated Alerts for Unusual Activity:
    • Within the SIEM tool, define rules and thresholds that constitute unusual or suspicious activity based on your organization's security policy.
    • Configure alerts to notify the security team via email, SMS, or other notification methods when these thresholds are exceeded.
    • Test the alerting system to ensure that alerts are generated and delivered reliably.
  5. Monitor and Review:
    • Ensure that logs are regularly reviewed to understand the typical patterns of integration events.
    • Perform periodic audits to validate that logging is capturing all necessary events and that no gaps exist in the security coverage.
    • Adjust logging configurations and alerts based on insights gained from these reviews to enhance detection capabilities continuously.

References

  • SAP NetWeaver Security Monitoring
  • SAP Security Log Integration with SIEM Products

countermeasure.name: Regularly apply security patches and restrict script execution
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of SAP Process Orchestration, it's essential to keep the system updated and implement secure scripting practices. Follow these steps to effectively apply the recommended security countermeasures:

  1. Regularly Update SAP Process Orchestration:

    • Access your SAP service marketplace or appropriate service adviser platform to check for the latest patches.
    • Subscribe to SAP Security Patch Day updates to stay informed about new releases.
    • Follow the official SAP patch application process to ensure patches are applied correctly without disrupting services. Test patches on a non-production environment before deployment.

  2. Disable Unnecessary Scripting:

    • Review all active scripts within your SAP Process Orchestration environment.
    • Disable scripts that are not required for the immediate operations of your processes. Document each script's purpose before disabling it.
    • In the SAP NetWeaver Administrator, navigate to the required settings to disable unnecessary scripts globally.

  3. Restrict Execution of External Scripts:

    • Implement a whitelist policy to ensure that only scripts from trusted, verified sources are executed.
    • Regularly review and update the list of trusted sources as part of your security review protocol.
    • Configure script execution policies in the SAP Process Orchestration system to enforce the whitelist.

  4. Configure Secure Execution Policies:

    • In SAP Process Orchestration, use the provided tools to establish security roles and permissions tailored to your organizational needs.
    • Ensure execution policies require authentication and authorization, preventing unauthorized execution of scripts or processes.
    • Audit and adjust these policies regularly to cope with changing security landscapes and organizational needs.

By addressing these areas, you significantly reduce the risk of malicious exploits and ensure that your SAP Process Orchestration environment remains secure and compliant with best practices.

References

  • SAP Security Update Guide
  • SAP Knowledge Base
  • SAP Process Orchestration Documentation

standard.ref: Contract Requirements for Service Providers and Contractors (a)
ID.RA-1: Asset vulnerabilities are identified and documented
PR.IP-12: A vulnerability management plan is developed and implemented

countermeasure.name: Secure and monitor technical user accounts
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of SAP Process Orchestration, it is crucial to address the risks associated with default technical user credentials. The following step-by-step guidance will help implement improved credential management practices:

  1. Replace Default Credentials: Access the SAP Process Orchestration system and locate any accounts using default technical user credentials. Update each account with a unique, strong password that combines letters, numbers, and special characters following the SAP password policy guidelines.

  2. Password Rotation Policy: Establish a password rotation policy. This policy should enforce password changes every 60-90 days to mitigate the risk of credential compromise. Configure automatic reminders within SAP Process Orchestration to alert administrators and users of impending password expirations.

  3. Assign Minimum Required Privileges: Conduct a privilege audit for all technical user accounts. Identify each account's necessary access rights based on its role and responsibilities. Modify or remove any excessive privileges to ensure each account operates under the principle of least privilege.

  4. Enable Activity Logging: Configure the logging feature within SAP Process Orchestration for all technical user activities. This includes login attempts, system changes, and critical operations. Ensure logs are securely stored and regularly reviewed for anomalies.

  5. Implement Suspicious Behavior Alerts: Integrate monitoring tools that analyze the logs for unusual patterns, such as multiple failed login attempts, access from unfamiliar locations or times, and unauthorized account changes. Set up an alerting mechanism that notifies stakeholders of such suspicious activities for prompt investigation.

By following these steps, you will significantly strengthen the security posture of your SAP Process Orchestration environment, minimizing the risks associated with technical user account management.

References

  • SAP Process Orchestration Security Guidelines
  • SAP Security - Best Practices for Password Complexity
  • Monitoring and Logging in SAP
