customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1026 - Privileged Account Management

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to integration processes
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized access to sensitive integration processes may occur, allowing data exposure or service interruptions within SAP Process Orchestration.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious insiders or external attackers could exploit vulnerabilities or use stolen credentials to gain unauthorized access.
Impacts
Potential consequences include data breaches leading to loss of sensitive information, as well as disruptions to business operations that rely on SAP Process Orchestration.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker uses phishing to steal credentials of a legitimate user and accesses critical integration configurations, extracting sensitive data and causing processing delays.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1133 - External Remote Services

threat.name: Compromise of technical user accounts
threat.desc:
General threat description
Technical user accounts with elevated privileges, if not properly secured, can become a target for exploitation by malicious actors, potentially resulting in unauthorized access and data loss.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers focus on discovering and exploiting unsecured technical user accounts with elevated privileges. They may use phishing, brute force attacks, or exploit known vulnerabilities to gain access.
Impacts
Unauthorized access to sensitive information, alterations to data integrity, service disruptions, and significant business losses due to compromised accounts.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker identifies a weak password associated with a privileged account, uses brute force methods to compromise the account, and gains access to sensitive areas within the system.
2. An internal employee with access to an elevated privileges account uploads a malicious script to grant unauthorized access to external attackers.
3. By exploiting known software vulnerabilities, an attacker gains access to a privileged technical account and manipulates system configurations to exfiltrate sensitive data.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Inadequate monitoring of integration activities
threat.desc:
General threat description
Without proper monitoring, malicious activities or system anomalies within SAP Process Orchestration may go undetected, leading to prolonged security incidents.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers or insiders leveraging the lack of monitoring to perform unauthorized actions or introduce system anomalies unnoticed.
Impacts
Extended duration of security breaches, potential data loss, compliance violations, and increased recovery time and costs.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker exploits an unmonitored vulnerability to gain unauthorized access, remaining undetected for an extended period, causing data exfiltration. Alternatively, an insider with access privileges performs unauthorized transactions that go unnoticed due to insufficient monitoring.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1069 - Permission Groups Discovery

threat.name: Data interception during transmission
threat.desc:
General threat description
Sensitive data transmitted between systems through SAP Process Orchestration could be compromised without adequate encryption measures in place.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors could intercept unencrypted data being transmitted between systems.
Impacts
Interception of unencrypted data by unauthorized entities could lead to data breaches and exposure of sensitive information.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker positioned within the network could use sniffing techniques to capture and decipher sensitive data communicated between SAP systems if encryption protocols are insufficient or absent.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Execution of malicious code
threat.desc:
General threat description
Attackers may take advantage of weak points in the system to run unauthorized code within the SAP Process Orchestration environment, potentially resulting in a compromised system.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors, such as hackers or insiders, may utilize various tools and techniques to identify and exploit vulnerabilities within the SAP Process Orchestration setup. This could involve directly targeting exposed services or leveraging social engineering to gain access.
Impacts
The execution of unauthorized code could allow for data breaches, alteration or deletion of critical business data, disruption of business processes, and loss of system integrity. There could also be financial and reputational damage as a result.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker could use a vulnerability scanner to detect an unpatched remote code execution flaw in the SAP Process Orchestration environment, then deliver a payload to gain administrative-level access. Another scenario may involve an insider exploiting access permissions to insert malicious scripts, compromising sensitive business logic.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1059 - Command and Scripting Interpreter

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-266
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-266: Incorrect Privilege Assignment A product incorrectly assigns a privilege to a particular actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-521
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-521: Weak Password Requirements The product does not require that users should have strong passwords, which makes it easier for attackers to compromise user accounts. Authentication mechanisms often rely on a memorized secret (also known as a password) to provide an assertion of identity for a user of a system. It is therefore important that this password be of sufficient complexity and impractical for an adversary to guess. The specific requirements around how complex a password needs to be depends on the type of system being protected. Selecting the correct password requirements and enforcing them through implementation are critical to the overall success of the authentication mechanism.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-706
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-706: Use of Incorrectly-Resolved Name or Reference The product uses a name or reference to access a resource, but the name/reference resolves to a resource that is outside of the intended control sphere.

countermeasure.name: Create network zones for SAP HANA components
countermeasure.desc:
SAP HANA is a complex system that is comprised of multiple components, including application servers, database servers, and web servers. Creating network zones using a network firewall can help to protect the different components of SAP HANA from unauthorized access. By segmenting the network, access to one component does not mean access to all components, which can help to limit the potential damage caused by a security breach.

Remediation:
Separate network zones, each with its own configuration, allow you to control and limit network access to SAP HANA to only those channels required for your scenarios, while ensuring the required communication between all components in the SAP HANA network.
These network zones can be basically described as follows:

1. Client zone
The network in this zone is used by SAP application servers, by clients such as the SAP HANA studio or Web applications running against the SAP HANA XS server, and by other data sources such as SAP Business Warehouse.

2. Internal zone
This zone covers the interhost network between hosts in a distributed system as well as the SAP HANA system replication network.

3. Storage zone
This zone refers to the network connections for backup storage and enterprise storage.

In most cases, the preferred storage solution involves separate, externally attached storage subsystem devices that are capable of providing dynamic mount-points for the different hosts, according to the overall landscape. A storage area network (SAN) can also be used for storage connectivity - for example, when running SAP HANA on IBM Power.

For more information, please see Reference URLs.

References:

  • SAP HANA Administration Guide for SAP HANA Platform
  • SAP HANA Security Guide for SAP HANA Platform

standard.ref: PR.AC-5: Network integrity is protected (e.g., network segregation, network segmentation)
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected

countermeasure.name: Encrypt data at rest for SAP HANA
countermeasure.desc:
Data at rest in SAP HANA databases can be vulnerable to unauthorized access or theft if the storage media or database files are compromised. Encrypting data at rest provides an additional layer of protection by rendering the data unreadable without the proper decryption key. This helps prevent data breaches and ensures compliance with regulatory requirements.
SAP HANA provides comprehensive encryption capabilities both for data at rest. You can perform administration tasks related to data-at-rest encryption, for example, configuring encryption and managing encryption keys using the SAP HANA cockpit and SAP recommends that you do so where possible.

Remediation:
To protect data saved to disk from unauthorized access at operating system level, the SAP HANA database supports data encryption in the persistence layer for the following types of data:
- Data volumes
- Redo log volumes
- Data and log backups

Enabling Data and Log Encryption in a New Database

Ideally, encryption is enabled in the database immediately on creation. You can ensure that this is the case for new tenant databases with the following parameters in the database_initial_encryption section of the global.ini configuration file in the system database:

- persistence_encryption
- log_encryption

To ensure that any subsequently created tenant databases automatically have encryption enabled, set the value of these parameters to on. If a particular tenant database does not require encryption, it can be switched off. By default these parameters are set to off.
Who can enable or disable data and log volume encryption (as well as backup encryption) in a newly created tenant database depends on how the encryption_config_control parameter in the database_initial_encryption section is configured.

Note: In a system-replication configuration, enable (or disable) encryption in the primary system only. The setting will be propagated to all secondary systems. The secondary systems must be running and replicating.

Enabling Data and Log Encryption in a Running Database

It is possible to enable data volume encryption in a tenant database that already exists and is already in operation. However, only the pages in use within the data volumes are initially encrypted. Pages in the data volumes that are not in use may still contain old content and will only be overwritten and encrypted over time.
Furthermore, if you enable redo log encryption after the database has been in operation, only future redo log entries are encrypted. Existing redo log entries remain unencrypted until they are overwritten. Log segment files are cyclically overwritten once they have been backed up. This means that data in data and log volumes will only be fully encrypted after some delay.
Although encryption can be switched on at any point in time, unencrypted data can remain on disk. If this is not wanted, you will need to install a new database on a fresh hard drive, activate encryption, import a backup, and low-level erase the old disks.

Enabling Backup Encryption in Tenant Databases

You can enable backup encryption at any time. By default, backup encryption is not enabled in a new tenant database. This is controlled by the backup_encryption parameter in the database_initial_encryption section of the global.ini configuration file of the system database.
To ensure that backup encryption is automatically enabled when new tenant databases are created, set the value of this parameter to on. If a particular tenant database subsequently does not require backup encryption, it can be switched off. By default, this parameter is set to off.
Who can enable or disable backup encryption (as well as data and log volume encryption) in a newly created tenant database depends on how the encryption_config_control parameter in the database_initial_encryption section is configured.

References:

  • Managing Data Encryption in SAP HANA
  • SAP HANA Security Guide for SAP HANA Platform

standard.ref: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information
SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

countermeasure.name: Encrypt data in transit for SAP HANA
countermeasure.desc:
Encryption of data in transit is an important security measure that protects data as it travels over networks. SAP HANA data can be accessed from various sources, including remote clients, web applications, and other systems. Encryption ensures that the data is protected from unauthorized access or interception during transmission.
SAP HANA supports encrypted communication for network communication channels. SAP recommends using encrypted channels in all cases where your network isn't protected by other security measures against attacks such as eavesdropping, for example, when your network is accessed from public networks. Alternatively, use virtual private network (VPN) tunnels to transfer encrypted information.

Remediation:
Encryption of data communication in the network

Secure communication based on the Transport Layer Security (TLS)/Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) protocol can be configured separately for external communication between individual databases and JDBC/ODBC clients. Separate key and trust stores must be available and configured for each database. For this purpose, SAP recommends using certificates and certificate collections stored in the database as opposed to the file system.
For communication with HTTP clients, a per-database configuration of TLS/SSL keys and certificates is also possible.

1. Configure SAP HANA to require TLS for all network communication between clients and the server. This can be done using the SAP HANA cockpit or command-line interface.
For example:
Enforced TLS/SSL for Client Connections

To force all clients communicating with the SAP HANA database through the SQL interface to use a secured connection, you can set the parameter sslEnforce in the communication section of the global.ini configuration file to true. The database subsequently refuses SQL connection attempts that do not use SSL.

2. Obtain a trusted SSL/TLS certificate from a reputable Certificate Authority (CA) and install it on the SAP HANA server.
3. Configure the SAP HANA server to use the latest version of TLS (TLS 1.2 or later) and disable outdated encryption protocols, such as SSL and TLS 1.0/1.1.
4. Configure SAP HANA clients to use the latest version of TLS and connect to the server using the hostname specified in the SSL/TLS certificate.
5. Test the configuration by verifying that all network communication between clients and the server is encrypted using a network analyzer tool.

Note: These are general technical steps and may vary based on the specific environment and configuration of SAP HANA. It is recommended to refer to SAP HANA documentation and security best practices for detailed guidance.

References:

  • SAP HANA Security Guide for SAP HANA Platform
  • Securing Data Communication

countermeasure.name: Enforce password policy for SAP HANA database users
countermeasure.desc:
The passwords of database users are subject to certain rules. These are defined in the password policy.
The SAP HANA database comes with a default password policy. You can change this default password policy in line with your organization's security requirements. If you manage users in user groups, you can also configure group-specific password policies.

Remediation:
1. The organization can configure the password policy of SAP HANA to meet its security requirements. It is essential to enforce strong passwords that include requirements for length and a combination of upper and lowercase letters, numbers, and special characters. The password policy should also enforce a regular password rotation schedule to reduce the risk of compromised passwords.

2. Configure SAP HANA to enforce the password policy by setting the appropriate parameters in the system.

a. Database Password Policy

The password policy of the database is defined by parameters in the password policy section of the indexserver.ini configuration file for tenant databases and the nameserver.ini configuration file for the system database.
The database password policy is valid for all database users unless the user is in a user group with its own dedicated password policy.

Caution
Do not change configuration files directly. Such changes cannot be audited.

You can view and change the database password policy on the Password Policy and Exclude List page of the SAP HANA cockpit.
You can also query the system view M_PASSWORD_POLICY to see the current database password policy

b. User Group Password Policy

If the users of a user group have different password requirements, you can configure group-specific values for the individual parameters of the password policy in the definition of the user groups.

Example
CREATE USERGROUP Training SET PARAMETER 'password_layout' = 'A1a!', 'minimal_password_length' = '16' ENABLE PARAMETER SET 'password policy';

Note
If a group-specific value is not explicitly set for a parameter, the value configured in the password policy of the database appears as the user group value in USERGROUP_PARAMETERS.

You can configure the password policy for a user group in the SAP HANA cockpit.

The parameter set password policy must be enabled for the user group in order for configured
password policy parameters to take effect.

c. Effective Password Policy

To determine which password policy a user is currently subject to, query the system view
M_EFFECTIVE_PASSWORD_POLICY.

Sample Code
SELECT * from "PUBLIC"."M_EFFECTIVE_PASSWORD_POLICY" where USER_NAME ='';

3. Notify users of the new password policy and the steps they need to take to comply with it.

References:

  • SAP HANA Security Guide for SAP HANA Platform

PR.AC-7: Users, devices, and other assets are authenticated (e.g., single-factor, multi-factor) commensurate with the risk of the transaction (e.g., individuals' security and privacy risks and other organizational risks)

countermeasure.name: Implement role-based access control (RBAC) for SAP HANA
countermeasure.desc:
When a user accesses the SAP HANA database using a client interface (for example, ODBC, JDBC, or HTTP), his or her ability to perform database operations on database objects is determined by the privileges that he or she has been granted.
All the privileges granted to a user, either directly or indirectly through roles, are combined. This means that whenever a user tries to access an object, the system performs an authorization check on the user, the user's roles, and directly granted privileges.
Roles are the preferred way to assign privileges to SAP HANA database users. It is recommended that you assign roles to users instead of granting privileges individually.

Remediation:
Assign or remove roles using the Role Assignment app of the SAP HANA cockpit:

1. On the Database Overview page, with the Security and User Management or All view selected, navigate to the User & Role Management card and choose Role Assignment.
2. In the Assign Roles app, choose how you want to assign roles, by user or by role, and proceed accordingly:
For user:
a. Find the user.
A list of all the roles the selected user has is displayed, not only those assigned directly to the user but also those assigned indirectly through inheritance.
b. Choose Edit and then Add.
c. Find the role(s) you want to assign to the user and choose Select.
d. If you want the user to be able to grant the role to other users, choose Grantable to Others.
e. Choose Save.
For Role:
a. Find the role you want to assign.
A list of all users that have the selected role is displayed.
b. Choose Edit and then Assign User.
c. Find the user(s) you want to assign the role to and choose Assign.
d. If you want the user to be able to grant the role to other users, choose Grantable to Others.
e. Choose Save.

Roles Best Practices

For best performance of role operations, in particular, granting and revoking, keep the following basic rules in mind:

- Create roles with the smallest possible set of privileges for the smallest possible group of users who can share a role (principle of least privilege).
- Avoid granting object privileges at the schema level to a role if only a few objects in the schema are relevant for intended users.
- Avoid creating and maintaining all roles as a single user. Use several role administrator users instead.

References:

  • SAP HANA Administration with SAP HANA Cockpit
  • SAP HANA Security Guide for SAP HANA Platform

countermeasure.name: Keep SAP HANA up to date
countermeasure.desc:
Keeping SAP HANA system up to date with the latest security patches and updates is critical to ensuring that known vulnerabilities are addressed and the system remains secure. Attackers are constantly looking for new ways to exploit vulnerabilities in software, and outdated software can leave a system vulnerable to attacks.
SAP strongly recommends to keep systems up to date by installing the latest SAP HANA revision and monitoring SAP security notes.

Remediation:
Regularly check for new security patches and updates for SAP HANA and apply them as soon as possible. This should be done in a test environment before applying the updates in a production environment to ensure that the updates do not cause any compatibility or functionality issues

SAP HANA Revisions

Security-related code improvements and corrections for SAP HANA are shipped with SAP HANA revisions. SAP publishes information related to security corrections and improvements through SAP security notes. In general, security notes contain information about both the affected SAP HANA application areas and specific measures that protect against the exploitation of potential weaknesses. Additional security measures are also documented here. SAP security notes are released as part of the monthly SAP Security Patch Day.

SAP recommends that you regularly review new security notes for SAP HANA application areas and decide whether they are relevant in the context of your systems and environment.

For more information about SAP security notes and the SAP Security Patch Day, see SAP Support Portal at http://support.sap.com/securitynotes

Note
To get full access to SAP Support Portal, you need an authorized user ID.

For a list of all SAP HANA application areas, see the SAP HANA Master Guide.
For more information about updating SAP HANA to a new revision, see the SAP HANA Server Installation and Update Guide at the References section.

Operating System Patches

Install security patches for your operating (OS) system as soon as they become available. If a security patch impacts SAP HANA operation, SAP will publish an SAP Note where this fact is stated. It is up to you to decide whether to install such patches.

References:

  • SAP HANA Security Guide for SAP HANA Platform
  • SAP HANA Server Installation and Update Guide

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Attackers try to take advantage of a wide attack surface
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat involves attackers exploiting the extensive and varied interfaces of SAP HANA. With numerous endpoints and services exposed, the probability of encountering unpatched vulnerabilities, misconfigurations, or weak security controls increases, thereby offering attackers multiple pathways to breach the system.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Threat Agents: External hackers, cybercriminal groups, and opportunistic attackers.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Scanning for open ports and exposed services.
    • Exploiting unpatched vulnerabilities or misconfigurations in SAP HANA components.
    • Utilizing automated tools to identify and target weak security controls across the environment.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive data stored in SAP HANA.
  • Potential data manipulation or exfiltration leading to financial and reputational harm.
  • Disruption of critical system operations and service availability.
  • Increased risk of lateral movement within the network, potentially compromising additional systems.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. Automated Vulnerability Scanning: An attacker deploys automated tools to scan the SAP HANA network for open ports and exposed interfaces. Upon identifying an unpatched service, the attacker exploits the vulnerability to gain unauthorized access and extract confidential data.
  2. Exploitation of Misconfigurations: An attacker identifies a misconfigured access point within SAP HANA’s network zones. Leveraging this weakness, the attacker bypasses authentication mechanisms, infiltrates the system, and manipulates or exfiltrates sensitive information without detection.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Privilege abuse
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat involves the misuse of excessive privileges within SAP HANA, allowing unauthorized actions beyond intended permissions.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Malicious insiders and external attackers using compromised credentials.
  • Vectors: Exploiting misconfigurations, phishing, or abuse of overly permissive roles.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized data access and manipulation.
  • Potential system compromise and compliance violations.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An insider misuses administrative rights to access sensitive data.
  2. An attacker phishes an admin’s credentials and exploits elevated privileges.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Attackers gain access to unauthorised data by exploiting vulnerabilities in the service
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat involves attackers identifying and exploiting weaknesses in the SAP HANA service to bypass security controls, thereby gaining access to data without proper authorization.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: External hackers, cybercriminals, and state-sponsored actors.
  • Vectors: Exploiting unpatched software vulnerabilities, misconfigurations, and known flaws in the service.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized exposure of sensitive or confidential data.
  • Data manipulation and potential further system compromise.
  • Damage to system integrity and loss of stakeholder trust.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An attacker leverages an unpatched vulnerability in the SAP HANA service to access restricted datasets.
  2. An attacker exploits a misconfiguration in the service, allowing unauthorized data retrieval and subsequent lateral movement within the network.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

threat.name: Attackers could gain access to sensitive data through a man in the middle attack
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat involves an attacker intercepting communications between SAP HANA and its clients to capture or alter sensitive data.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, hackers, state-sponsored actors.
  • Vectors: Exploiting unsecured or weakly encrypted network channels using techniques like ARP spoofing or DNS poisoning.

Impacts:

  • Exposure of confidential data such as credentials and business information.
  • Data integrity issues and potential for further system compromise.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An attacker sets up a rogue access point, intercepting unencrypted SAP HANA traffic.
  2. An attacker uses ARP spoofing to redirect traffic, capturing sensitive data in transit.

threat.name: Dictionary-based or brute force password attack
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat involves attackers systematically guessing passwords using dictionary lists or brute force techniques to gain unauthorized access to SAP HANA.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Cybercriminals and opportunistic attackers.
  • Vectors: Employing automated tools to test large volumes of password combinations, exploiting weak or reused credentials.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to accounts and sensitive data.
  • Compromise of system integrity and potential lateral movement within the network.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An attacker uses an automated script to perform a dictionary attack on SAP HANA, eventually finding a valid password from a common list.
  2. A brute force attack exploits weak password policies, with the attacker iterating through numerous combinations until access is granted.

threat.name: Sensitive data is compromised through unauthorized access to data
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
This threat occurs when unauthorized users gain access to sensitive data within SAP HANA due to weak access controls, misconfigurations, or exploited vulnerabilities.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: External hackers, malicious insiders, cybercriminals.
  • Vectors: Exploiting weak credentials, bypassing access restrictions, and leveraging unpatched vulnerabilities.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized disclosure of confidential information.
  • Potential legal, regulatory, and reputational consequences.
  • Increased risk of further exploitation using the exposed data.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An attacker gains access to sensitive customer data by exploiting weak authentication measures.
  2. A malicious insider uses elevated privileges to extract confidential business information.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-770
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-770: Allocation of Resources Without Limits or Throttling The product allocates a reusable resource or group of resources on behalf of an actor without imposing any restrictions on the size or number of resources that can be allocated, in violation of the intended security policy for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-915
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-915: Improperly Controlled Modification of Dynamically-Determined Object Attributes The product receives input from an upstream component that specifies multiple attributes, properties, or fields that are to be initialized or updated in an object, but it does not properly control which attributes can be modified.

weakness.name: CWE-922
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-922: Insecure Storage of Sensitive Information The product stores sensitive information without properly limiting read or write access by unauthorized actors. If read access is not properly restricted, then attackers can steal the sensitive information. If write access is not properly restricted, then attackers can modify and possibly delete the data, causing incorrect results and possibly a denial of service.

countermeasure.name: Encrypt all sensitive data in transit and at rest
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that all sensitive business data is encrypted both at rest and in transit using strong encryption standards such as AES-256 for data at rest and TLS for data in transit. Review and update encryption configurations regularly to maintain compliance with the latest security standards.

countermeasure.name: Implement multi-factor authentication (MFA)
countermeasure.desc: Implement multi-factor authentication (MFA) to ensure that users need more than just a password to gain access. MFA should be enforced for all users with access to critical data. The implementation should support a variety of MFA methods, such as hardware tokens, authenticator apps, or SMS-based codes.

countermeasure.name: Implement rate limiting and DoS protection mechanisms
countermeasure.desc: To prevent denial-of-service attacks, rate limiting should be configured to restrict the number of requests any user or IP address can send within a specific time frame. Additionally, network firewalls should be configured to detect and block known DoS attack patterns.

standard.ref: DE.CM-1: The network is monitored to detect potential cybersecurity events
PR.DS-4: Adequate capacity to ensure availability is maintained
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected

countermeasure.name: Implement role-based access control (RBAC)
countermeasure.desc: Implement strict role-based access control (RBAC) to ensure that users only have access to the data and systems necessary for their role. Review access permissions regularly to ensure compliance with the principle of least privilege.

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties

countermeasure.name: Secure API configurations and schema validation
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that all API endpoints in SAP S4 HANA are secured using industry-standard authentication and authorization mechanisms. Implement schema validation to ensure that only valid data can be processed by the APIs, and use logging to detect any unusual activity.

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Denial of Service attack via resource exhaustion
threat.desc:
General threat description: Attackers may launch denial-of-service (DoS) attacks against the SAP S4 HANA environment by flooding it with requests, consuming system resources, and making the system unavailable to legitimate users.
Threat agents/Attack vectors: The attack could be carried out by external actors using botnets or by insiders with access to internal resources. Attack vectors include network flooding, application-layer DDoS, or CPU/memory exhaustion.
Impacts: A successful DoS attack could render SAP S4 HANA services unavailable, leading to significant business disruption and operational downtime.
Example Attack Scenarios: An attacker uses a botnet to flood the SAP S4 HANA application servers with fake requests, causing system overload and denial of service.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Insecure storage and transmission of sensitive business data
threat.desc:
General threat description: Sensitive business data stored in SAP S4 HANA, such as financial records or customer information, may be compromised if not properly encrypted at rest and in transit.
Threat agents/Attack vectors: Attackers may exploit weak or non-existent encryption methods to access or modify sensitive data. Insider threats or external attackers intercepting unencrypted data transmissions pose significant risks.
Impacts: The exposure of sensitive data could lead to severe financial and reputational damage, legal consequences, and regulatory penalties.
Example Attack Scenarios: An attacker intercepts unencrypted financial transactions being transmitted between SAP S4 HANA and other business systems, leading to data leakage.

threat.name: Insider threat leading to unauthorized access to privileged data
threat.desc:
General threat description: Malicious or negligent insiders could exploit their access to SAP S4 HANA to gain unauthorized access to privileged or sensitive data, leading to data breaches or other security incidents.
Threat agents/Attack vectors: Employees or contractors with authorized access may misuse their credentials to access sensitive information without proper authorization.
Impacts: Insider attacks can lead to significant data breaches, financial losses, and damage to organizational trust.
Example Attack Scenarios: A disgruntled employee uses their elevated privileges to access and exfiltrate sensitive business reports from the SAP S4 HANA system.

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to critical business data through compromised credentials
threat.desc:
General threat description: An attacker could gain access to sensitive data in SAP S4 HANA by compromising user credentials via phishing, brute force attacks, or social engineering. This could allow unauthorized users to access, manipulate, or steal critical business data.
Threat agents/Attack vectors: The threat actors could range from external hackers to malicious insiders. Attack vectors include phishing attacks, brute force attacks, or exploiting weak password policies.
Impacts: Unauthorized access to financial data, intellectual property, and other sensitive business information could lead to financial losses, legal implications, and reputational damage.
Example Attack Scenarios: An attacker launches a phishing campaign, tricking employees into providing their login credentials, leading to unauthorized access to sensitive financial reports.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Data manipulation through exploitation of insecure APIs
threat.desc:
General threat description: An attacker could exploit insecure API endpoints in SAP S4 HANA to manipulate data, leading to data corruption or unauthorized changes in business processes.
Threat agents/Attack vectors: The attackers could exploit unprotected or poorly secured APIs, gaining unauthorized access to manipulate system data. External attackers or malicious insiders can target API vulnerabilities.
Impacts: Unauthorized data changes could compromise the integrity of business processes, resulting in financial losses or incorrect business decisions.
Example Attack Scenarios: An attacker exploits a misconfigured API to alter inventory data, leading to incorrect stock levels being reported to management.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application
